TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer received any written advice from the Commonwealth Treasury about the ongoing deterioration of the world economy and the threat that that deterioration presents to the growth forecast of 3 per cent that was included in the 1992-93 Budget?

—I have received no such advice from the Treasury. At the time the Budget forecasts were put together, the Treasury made a very pragmatic assessment about what was happening in the world economy. I think it was probably more realistic than some others around the world, who were rather more rosy than we were in our assessments. I have received no advice that we need to change or revise the Budget forecasts for growth on the basis of international developments.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports about the prospect of credit card interest rate decreases? Will the Treasurer advise the House of the impact of such rate reductions for credit card holders?

—I have seen references in the media to likely reductions in credit card interest rates. That speculation has been contributed to by the remarks of the Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority, Professor Fels, in his public comments today. I have made comments on credit card interest rates over the past few months, most particularly on 16 June, when I said that I believed the banks should reduce the interest rates they were charging their credit card customers. Since that time there have been some reductions in credit card interest rates. They are now at their lowest levels since the mid-1980s.

PARA.TAB: I think there is still room for further reductions as far as credit card interest rates are concerned. It should be recalled that cash rates are at 5.75 per cent. On that basis, one would expect that credit card interest rates could be much lower than they are at the moment. As Professor Fels said in his comments today, there was a linkage between a general deregulation of credit cards and the interest rate that is charged for them. One of the crucial issues here is whether or not the banks, or the providers of these credit cards, should be able to charge some kind of up-front fee, which at the moment is prohibited by State legislation.

The Minister for Consumer Affairs, in the context of the Council of Consumer Affairs Ministers, has been looking at this. Indeed, her predecessor and her predecessor's predecessor had been looking at these matters over the years. As yet, the States have not come to a view about how this matter should be handled; I think they are awaiting the PSA report before they do.

I have no philosophical objection to some modest up-front fee, so long as this is reflected in a substantial reduction in interest rates charged for credit cards. The point is that at the moment the cost of providing the credit card facility is borne entirely by those who actually pay the interest. Of course, there are some who have the capacity to avoid paying interest by ensuring that they square off their credit card accounts in the interest-free period. This means that those people who have the capacity to do that receive a free service, whereas others who perhaps require the credit over a longer period end up paying a much higher interest rate and, therefore, end up bearing the entire burden of providing the credit facility afforded by these credit cards.

This area is long overdue for reform. The Commonwealth has been quite clear in its view that reform should occur. We hope the States will come to that view readily—hopefully unanimously—once they meet again on this question. I believe there will be room for even greater reductions once the general reform has been agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have had our diversion, I ask a question of the Treasurer. Last Friday it was reported that OECD officials had revised down their forecasts for growth in the OECD in 1993. Given that downward revision of growth in our trading partners, why is Senator Button's revised forecast for a weaker recovery this year wrong?

—I was in the OECD 10 days ago talking to the officials who are responsible for looking at not only the world economy but also Australia's part in it and it is true that they had reduced their forecasts for world economic growth. I asked what the implications were for Australia's rate of growth as a result of that. They said that they believed our Budget-time forecasts were on line. One of the reasons they said that was that we were one of the economies in the world that had had the capacity to provide a fiscal stimulus in order to encourage a higher rate of growth than otherwise would have been the case.

PARA.TAB: I do not know why the Deputy Leader is pursuing this point. Of course what happens in the rest of the world is one of the factors that will determine how well we go; but it is only one factor. At the time of the Budget we said that the sources of growth should be private consumption, housing and public investment, while the rural sector and private investment should also begin to turn around. What happens in the rest of the world is just one of the factors; the other factors have to be borne in mind as well.

Nothing that has occurred in the world economy in the intervening period has required me or the Treasury to revise the estimates. Indeed, since the Budget I have spoken with the Secretary to the US Treasury and the Japanese Minister of Finance, as well as with Alan Greenspan and the officials I mentioned from the OECD. None of those people would suggest that we should make any revision of the estimates we made at the time of the Budget in relation to the impact on Australia of slower world growth.

As to what is happening in Australia, what happens in retail sales is significant. But the Deputy Leader should not make the mistake of leaping on to one month's data and trying to talk down the economy. We will not know until early December what the growth rate in the September quarter is. I think it is probably unlikely that we will see an acceleration of growth in the September quarter from the June quarter. Even if that were to be the case, that would still not require us to adjust the Budget-time forecast for the 3 per cent growth year on year that we made at Budget time.

I cannot understand why the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who is totally disinterested in what I am saying, is interested only in plucking out from what is a disparate and partial set of data those bits that he thinks make his point about talking down the economy. Why, for instance, does he not talk about the housing sector, which is making a stronger contribution to the economy than was expected at Budget time? But no; that would fly in the face of the Opposition's basic tactic: generally to spread a bit more gloom around and to portray an economy that is in distress, when even the Deputy Leader of the Opposition acknowledged in recent times that we are doing better than the rest of the world. We are doing better than the rest of the world precisely because of the policies we put in place both in February and during the Budget, policies that I remind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition he and his Leader oppose. They actually want less fiscal stimulus. Their policy is to have slower growth in this economy. They are not in favour of taking the action we have taken in order to encourage recovery in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister inform the House whether the pick-up in traineeships is continuing. Have any alternative approaches been tested? If so, what has been their success relative to the traineeship system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government's position on traineeships, as it is on a whole lot of labour market and training programs, has been to develop a most careful program tailored to the needs of the people who are trainees, the employers who employ them, and the economy overall by providing it with the skills that are needed in order for us to grow and in order for our work force to be able to take advantage of new job opportunities that will emerge over the next decade. The traineeships are basically structured around the notion of a one-year period during which some 75 per cent of the time is spent on the job and 25 per cent in formal training. The trainees who are employed under this scheme also attract to an employer a subsidy of around $2,000 to $4,000 from the Federal Government. That structure has been built upon by the States, who have acknowledged the success of these programs.
—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein will cease interjecting.

—Most of the States provide some element of payroll tax relief and in some cases, such as in Victoria, they also provide extra subsidies. The incentives that have been put in place are producing a very substantial effect. What happens as a result of these programs is that a trainee receives very solid work experience, a formal qualification which is very important to industry standards, and a reasonable living wage. An employer gets a keen young worker, who is rapidly acquiring a high level of training, but is required to pay only 75 per cent of the award rate, and that is further reduced by a subsidy of anywhere between $38 and $77 a week. As I said, State subsidies come in over the top of that.

PARA.TAB: In the last three months there has been an increase of 90 per cent, compared with the September quarter last year, in take-up of traineeships. Increases by State ranged as high as 240 per cent in Victoria, where the State Government provides extra subsidies. More young people started in traineeships in these last three months than over the first six months last year.

The question from the honourable member for Robertson asked about alternative approaches. At the time when the Leader of the Opposition talked about abandoning these sorts of schemes and going for the notion of establishing effectively a youth wage subsidy, provided by the youth as opposed to either the Government or the employer, a great deal was said on this side of the House about the notion, challenging the intellectual capacity of the proposition. None of that made any impact. Earlier this month the Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: My answer is that you can solve youth unemployment with the youth wage. There is no doubt about that.

PARA.TAB: Some of those evidently, according to the Age over the weekend which picked up on this, who have subsequently experimented with the propositions put forward by the Opposition whereby the unemployed youth in this particular aspect provide their own subsidy as opposed to its being provided by the Government, have found it a massive failure. I only go on the report that has appeared but the gentleman concerned, Mr Steve Stavreas, who runs a jewellery store in Canberra and in neighbouring Queanbeyan, is quoted extensively. Having experimented with the propositions of the Opposition and finding them total failures, he had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: I just don't think that the system that Dr Hewson is talking about will work. Unless there are some very big changes, the kids are not going to be interested.

Basically the problem that he ran into, evidently from this article, was the obvious problem that, upon the individual employer, is flung the whole responsibility for devising of training arrangements. A particular TAFE course, or whatever, is supposed to be negotiated between a 16- or 17-year-old kid and an employer, who has better things to do with his time. He is out there trying to make money and produce the goods that his company produces. He is not there to be a professional educator or there to devise education and training systems; he is there to respond to what is offered. The obvious point that needs to be made from all this is that it is not a substitute to just stand up and say that the unemployed people can provide themselves with their own subsidy by our amending awards across the board to say that you can walk in and get 50 per cent or 75 per cent of the agreed wage, or whatever, and at some point you might be able to negotiate time off with the employer. That will produce absolutely nothing at all—no skills, no jobs—nothing that this economy needs.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to see that over the last three months there has been an opportunity to test both propositions—the proposition of the Opposition, and the proposition of the Government. There can be no question from the statistics that it is the Government's proposition which is successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House whether the Government intends that employers and employees may vary the working week, penalty rates and holiday loadings through enterprise bargains? Is he aware of any misunderstandings about the scope and nature of enterprise bargaining conducted with the Government's encouragement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me assure the House that hours of work, penalty rates and holiday loadings not only can be varied in enterprise bargains but are being varied in many of the 350 bargains which have already been registered with the Industrial Relations Commission. The honourable member for Bennelong said last month—it is an interesting quote:

ANSWER.PARA: The most important message to come from the Opposition in the area of industrial relations is the quite dramatic proposal to move away entirely from the concept of a fixed working week.

The fact is that the fixed working week is no longer, as hundreds of enterprise agreements now attest. Penalty rates and holiday loadings can be negotiated. For example, the National Australia Bank and the ANZ Bank have developed agreements which allow their employees to choose any combination of working hours which, in the case of NAB, amount to at least 38 hours a week or 152 hours a month—that is, any combination of working hours.

PARA.TAB: Similarly flexible arrangements exist in the Sheraton Towers agreement, the Coles supermarket agreement, the Southern Cross Machinery agreement and many hundreds of agreements now being negotiated. The Sheraton Towers agreement has folded ordinary time earnings and penalty rates together into an annual salary regardless of hours worked. The Coles supermarket agreement provides wage increases in return for greater flexibility in working hours and reductions in night shift penalty rates. Workers in Southern Cross Machinery agreed to arrange their working hours so they receive one week's salary by working less than 38 hours a week in winter and around 42 1/2 hours in summer. There are endless examples in a list too long to read.

The only condition we impose in all of this flexibility, upwards and sideways, is that the agreements not leave employees worse off than they were before. This is, of course, a condition that the honourable member for Bennelong wishes to attack. He is not after flexibility up and out; he is after flexibility down. That is one thing that the set of generic arrangements in place now for enterprise agreements, under the scrutiny of the Commission, will not allow. They will allow all manner of flexibility—penalty rates, changes to annual leave, working hours, maternity and sick leave, the lot; it is all negotiable, and it has been negotiated in hundreds of agreements—but the arrangements will not allow flexibility down. The one thing that the Liberal Party wants is to drive Australian wages down further.

Figures from the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics show that in 1991 hourly labour costs for production workers in manufacturing in Australia were 20 per cent below the OECD average. That is, we are already hugely competitive in wages, and the notion that wages need to be pushed down further is simply about depressing Australian living standards and giving Australians the sorts of wage levels which obtain to our near north in developing countries. It is not, as members of the Opposition claim, for flexibility in the labour market and the workplace. Under the Opposition's proposals all these agreements and all Federal awards would be automatically cancelled. The only way any agreement would obtain is if both the employees and employers agreed. Otherwise, the whole award structure and agreement falls away.

What is the transitional arrangement? The transitional arrangement is that the new agreements would be common law contracts, which would need a QC to enforce them. How is an ordinary person, say a metal stamper in a metals business, going to deal with the employer? If the employer happens to be a car company or a steel fabrication company, how is one small person going to deal with the employer? He is pushed into a common law contract and his only recourse is to get a QC to represent him in a common law case, which might take a year or two to be listed. In other words, all the Industrial Relations Commission machinery goes away. The machinery that is there now to look at any disputes where the agreement is not clear or where a matter needs to be settled goes. You damn some poor person on a common law contract to find a QC to represent him. The strength between labour and business, now that the wage share of GDP is at 1960s levels—as the American bureau says, 20 per cent below the OECD average—is not enough for you.

There is this claim that you need to have flexibility when you can roll penalty rates, hours of work, holiday pay, maternity leave and sick leave into any agreement you like, with any sort of flexibility, as has been done in hundreds of cases; you can do it up and out but you cannot go down. The flexibility you want is down. This ranks with the GST as one of the most pernicious policies being offered by the Opposition. This is the one that will actually rip into living standards at source. All Australian working persons who value their wage, their pay packet, their holiday leave, their hours of work or, in the case of women, their maternity leave—
Mr Taylor interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Groom will cease interjecting.

—When they understand that all that will be put asunder, not to provide more flexibility, as the honourable member for Bennelong or the Leader of the Opposition assert, but simply to drive their gross earnings down—

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—their total remuneration down, their recourse will be with a QC in the courts. That is when people will understand what the Reverend Wansbrough says about human beings, what the Catholic Church says about the issues in Fightback, about the rights of human beings, the right to live in dignity, with reasonable wages and conditions, and not to have them put asunder in some phoney quest for flexibility which is already there, but where you make totally unequal the battle between business and an employee: that is, the weight of a business and its management against one single person, denying people the right to band together, without the agreement of the employer, other than to make a common law contract. This is what the Liberal Party is after. It is after flexibility all right, but it is flexibility downwards.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Has the Minister seen comments that the rich spend three times as much on food as the poor? To what extent does the cost of food impact on the cost of living for pensioners and other social security recipients? Are assumptions about the level of food intake by different socioeconomic groups factored into his Department's rates of payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Prospect for her question.
—If the honourable member for Ballarat interjects out of his place again, I will name him.

—I certainly am aware of a number of comments that the rich spend more on food than the poor. That is not a surprising statement, but it seems to have been referred to much of late. The important thing is that the impact of any change in food prices is relevant in terms of the proportion of income that people spend on food, not the absolute dollars. One would have thought that would have been clear to everybody but, as I shall show, it is certainly not clear to many people in the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: When we look at those people on social security, our best estimate is that on average social security beneficiaries spend about 40 per cent of their income on food. The base levels of the pension and benefit have been set, historically, to allow for the purchase of these basic necessities, because they figure much more prominently in the shopping baskets of the less well off, of the beneficiaries, than those of the rich. Therefore, any change in the prices of food will have a much more disproportionate effect on the less well off.

That is why I think there is so much concern in the community about the impact of proposed changes to the prices of food. These changes are widely seen, and rightly seen, as being regressive. They hit the poor harder than they hit the rich. A much higher proportion of the income of the poor is spent on a tax on food. The GST is such a tax.

This was what the Catholic Social Welfare Commission was pointing out. I want to read this statement again. Honourable members will hear it a lot in the next few months, but it is an essential statement in the debate. The statement says:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . that taxing people for their consumption of food . . . contravenes the Catholic social principles of the common good, human solidarity, human dignity, preference for the poor and the common use of goods.
That is a moral argument as well as an economic argument.

PARA.TAB: What did we find from a gaggle of Opposition leaders in response to that statement? They ran around the country telling us that to exempt food from the GST would be unfair on the less well off because the rich spent more in dollar terms on food. It was an extraordinary argument, but honourable members will find it in the statements of the Leader of the Opposition, in the statements of the shadow Treasurer and most clearly and explicitly in the statements of the honourable member for Pearce.

The honourable member for Pearce will always take these things to extremes. What the honourable member for Pearce has discovered is that a food tax is possibly a progressive tax. To be fair to him, let me quote what he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The taxing of all food, rather than the exemption of essential foodstuffs, may well be progressive.
They are his weasel words—`may well be'. He is the first person in economics I have ever known to argue that a food tax may be progressive.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what underlies this extraordinary argument. It is true that if one checks with the ABS then one will find that, in dollar terms, the wealthy spend more on food than do the poor. Let us look at the percentages. Take the wealthiest 10 per cent of this community. They spend 9 per cent of their income on food. Therefore, the wealthiest 10 per cent spend 9 per cent, but the poorest 10 per cent spend 50 per cent of their income on food.

It is no good saying, `This tax isn't regressive because the rich spend more on food than the poor'. You have to look at those percentages. They clearly show the regressive nature of this tax. The lowest 10 per cent in the community spend 50 per cent on food and the top 10 per cent spend only 9 per cent, which means that that food tax would have five times the detrimental impact on the bottom 10 per cent as it would have on the top. I do not see that anywhere in a papal encyclical you could find support for that sort of proposition.

Moreover—and this is important in relation to what the honourable member for Pearce said—there are further elements of regression in this whole approach to taxation of food. Dr Terry Dwyer in his paper points out—
Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.
—You get the same attitude to any critic. Let me quote from that paper—

PARA.TAB: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!
—evidence overwhelmingly supported by the statistics. The paper said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the higher income groups' expenditure . . . is concentrated heavily in restaurant meals and takeaway foods, snack foods, soft drinks, chocolate, ice cream and confectionery.

That is, not on the necessities of life. Therefore, the discretionary element—the ability to avoid those—becomes much greater. Also, if you take things such as soft drinks, ice-creams and confectionery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sales tax on ice-cream?

—Yes, because those which figure very prominently in the higher expenditure of the rich are affected only at the level of 4 per cent by the Opposition's changes. As to the basic necessities, vegetables rise in price by 10 per cent; dairy products, 10 per cent; and cereals, meat and seafood, 9 per cent. Here is another element of regression built into this tax. When you take all these things into account, you have totally inadequate compensation. You cannot remedy, with what has been proposed, the extent of that regression. You simply make people more reliant on the social security system.
—Don't you remember Keating's speech to the Press Club?
—If the honourable member for Mayo interjects again, I will name him.

—Unlike the honourable member for Mayo, I am interested in the present debate, not some past reference. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that in 16 of the some 20 countries that have taxes comparable to a GST or consumption tax, there is a special attitude taken to the taxing of food. In many of them food is exempt; in most cases it is lower rated. Given the disquiet in the community and the real criticism being made of this tax, will the Leader of the Opposition not look at his proposals and look at an amendment in these terms?

—Mr Speaker, I have a question for you. I draw your attention to the fact that, of the 14 questions remaining on the Notice Paper for 1991, 10 are directed to the Treasurer. Will you ask the Treasurer to address his attention to that?

—As the honourable member for Wannon, who has been here for some little time, would know, it is up to Ministers as to when and if they respond to questions. A criticism in the past of his former colleague was that he never used to respond to certain questions either. It is a matter for Ministers.
—Mr Speaker, I have a question to you, if I may.
—I am always happy to try to answer a question from the honourable member for Bass.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Just before Question Time I had confirmed to me by the Sound and Vision Office that there has been a change to the arrangements for the direct broadcast of Question Time. Previously, before a directive which I understand you gave, the cameras would pan on the person who had the call, at the dispatch box or wherever that person might be, which is in accord with guideline No. 1 of the report to the Parliament of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Televising of the House of Representatives about how we should broadcast the proceedings—we hope the cameras are now doing as they ought to do.
—To see the honourable member for Bass knocking over the flag?

—Yes; it is now back up again. The Sound and Vision Office advises that, according to your directive, when a member takes a point of order during Question Time, rather than a head and shoulders shot, which has been the practice up until your direction, it now goes to a wide angle shot. I ask whether this secret directive you have given will be subject to an explanation from you to the Parliament. I ask you to do so. It appears to me that fundamentally it does not accord with the primary guideline the House has set down for the broadcast of these proceedings.

Changes are made from time to time to make the proceedings more intelligible to viewers. One of the procedural changes we are trialling at present is that when points of order are taken there is a wider shot that takes in both the person taking the point of order and me in my response. —Ought this not to be a matter that goes to the Committee that has been established by the Parliament to consider this matter more fully? I think it ought to be a matter for the joint parties to be discussing, rather than your making the decision on your own.

—The honourable member for Bass will resume his seat. The honourable member for Bass should know how to ask a question that does not end up being a little diatribe about what he does and does not think and what he thinks I ought to think. He can ask a question and he will get an answer. I do not want to have to give him a little lesson in these things. As the honourable member for Bass pointed out at the beginning, the guidelines are guidelines that I promulgate. The trials of procedural changes are trials that I authorise. If those trials are going to become permanent, I will advise the House. I think that makes better television.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The persistent failure of the Government to give the Australian public a full and realistic assessment of the state of the economy as evidenced by yesterday's pressure on the Industry Minister to withdraw his statement that he lacked confidence that the growth figures in the Budget forecasts will be attained.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last 24 hours we have had yet another example of this Government caught out attempting to deceive the Australian public about the state of our economy. It is not new; it has happened on many occasions in the past. This Government has on many occasions failed to take the action which would have secured a more prosperous Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: I can go back to 1987, in the old Parliament House, sitting across on this side and listening to the then Treasurer handing down a Budget. He said, `Tonight I can report that Australia is winning'. Do Opposition members remember the Budget back in 1988 when he said, `This is the one that brings home the bacon'—not that any of us knew he was going into the piggery business then. But every year we get the same thing.

In 1989 the then Treasurer said that we were entering a golden era of economic change, yet behind closed doors he and the Minister for Finance had set in train the deliberate engineering of the recession. Before we went into the 1990 election—and Pinocchio's nose was growing longer by the year—he announced with typical arrogance, `I will not let there be a recession'. Do honourable members remember when he was elected Prime Minister? At that press conference the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said, `I've just got three things to say to the Australian public'. The first thing that he wanted to pledge to the Australian public was basically this: `Forget what I've told you in the past; in the future I'm going to tell you the truth'. Those opposite never tell people the truth about the Australian economy.

It is a very sensitive issue at this point in time. The fact is that we are in the worst recession for 60 years. Australia is going through very troubled economic circumstances as a result of 10 hard years of Labor. Those opposite are trying to paint a rosy picture that things will be great next year. That is basically their line. They say it with increasing desperation as every day goes by and as we get closer to the next election. I think anybody who is involved with the Parliament would know that for the whole of this year the Prime Minister has been trying to create a window of opportunity to rush off and go to an early election so that he can avoid facing an election next year when people will be able to see as plain as the nose on their face that our economic circumstances are such that the recession still rolls on.

Last week we had a classic. On the first day of sitting last week, the Prime Minister came in here and said, `Look, this recession was over long ago'. There was no qualification, `I don't know what you're all complaining about'. It was like that famous one of Gough's when he went down to the farmers in Warragul and said, `You've never had it so good'. It was a `let them eat cake' situation. So on the first day of sitting the Prime Minister said that the recession was over long ago. The next day he came in here and repeated the statement. Then he announced that he was the one who saved Australia. So not only is the recession over, but he saved us. Then on the third day of last week's sitting, to add insult to injury, he came in here and said, `Not only is the recession over and not only am I the one who saved you, but I'm going to give you your future back'. The incredible arrogance of this bloke!

We can imagine the phone calls on Friday night and Saturday from all the blokes on the other side. Frontbenchers and backbenchers on the other side of the House are getting increasingly worried that this Prime Minister has completely lost control; his mouth is completely out of control. The more he says, the more desperate the untruths that he states, the less their chances are of getting back into office. As we saw last week, the Prime Minister said in the Parliament that the recession was well over long ago. But no-one in the country believed him. It was just incredible the disbelief across the land as a result of that statement. There was no-one saying, `Hallelujah! Paul Keating saved Australia. Thank you for the worst recession for 60 years'.

On Sunday morning, Senator Button had a television interview with Laurie Oakes. Senator Button is no Johnny-come-lately to Federal politics. He is no chicken. He did not come down in the last shower. He has been around this place for a long time. He has a deserved reputation for being a bit more frank and honest about how things are than the Prime Minister and, I must say, his new Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). On the Sunday program Senator Button was at great pains to be very careful in announcing what he thought was the state of the economy. Mr Oakes kept saying, `Do you want to go over the top like the Prime Minister did and declare that the recession is over?'. Senator Button was actually asked a question by Mr Oakes, and it is worth quoting and giving the context of it. Laurie Oakes said:

SPEECH.PARA: How long will it be before Paul Keating, or anybody else, can stand up and say the recession is over, without people saying, `Well, he's technically correct, but . . .'? When do we lose the `but'?
John Button said:
Let me say that I don't think we will lose the `but' very quickly. The Opposition doesn't expect,—
that is not bad; he is calling us in to support his position—

or the more serious commentators amongst the Opposition do not expect, we will lose the `but' quickly. The reason for that is the same as it is in every other western economy at the present time. These structural adjustments have been taking place. There is the slow down in the world economy and nobody can say with certainty when that `but' will be removed from the discussion. But I'm optimistic about it.
Here is the critical crunch. He says:
I mean we gave growth figures in the Budget forecasts. I'm not absolutely confident that we will attain those now but as we move towards them employment will improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a considered remark.

—That was a considered remark. He went to the Channel Nine studios on Sunday morning with a premeditated intention to blow the whistle on the Prime Minister's very optimistic, over the top claims from the week before. This was no slip of the tongue; this was a statement that was volunteered. I read out the question to honourable members. It was not a situation of Laurie Oakes's getting into Senator Button like a terrier, and asking, `What are your forecasts? Where do you stand on this?', he just brought it out on his own accord, and he did so quite deliberately. He volunteered it, not as some incompetent who is just blundering through an interview with Laurie Oakes but as a person who has had a lot of experience as the third most senior economic Minister in the Government.

PARA.TAB: That is a very clear statement which just blew apart all the claims that the Government has been making. Its claim is that things are going to be much better next year, we have this growth of 3 per cent. Senator Button is saying that he does not believe so. I do not just rely upon his experience and reputation on this matter. If honourable members have been reading the papers, they would have seen that the Government has been receiving advice upon which Senator Button presumably came to that assessment. We saw in the Australian Financial Review on Friday—presumably Senator Button read this if he needed to—the following quote:
However, senior government officials and advisers have returned from northern hemisphere trips over the past fortnight bearish about the outlook for the world economy. . .

SPEECH.PARA: There it is. We have confirmation through a very close source to the Government, Michael Stutchbury. He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Australian officials now recognise that their Budget forecasts for the world economy are also probably on the high side.

SPEECH.PARA: It is as clear as the nose on your face. The fact is that Treasury, the Government and DITAC have been receiving advice that the basis upon which the Budget forecasts were prepared, which is an assessment of the world economy, has been slipping away from them and has been eroding. That is fresh advice that the Government has been receiving. Instead of trying to give the public a reasonable assessment of the state of the Australian economy, we have nothing but deception. I also have no doubt that, not only in that source of advice but also in the possible parliamentary question briefings that the Treasurer and Senator Button would have had for last week's parliamentary, there would have been commentary on the state of the Australian economy which has obviously stuck in Senator Button's mind and upon which he made his claim yesterday. We have an experienced Minister who I am sure has been given advice in the last week or so which confirms and provides the basis upon which he made his claim on Sunday. But the fact is that it has all happened before.

PARA.TAB: There have been some celebrated cases. Remember that one back in May 1990? The Prime Minister had caused the recession but he did not want to admit that the economy was in recession. Someone asked him whether we were technically in a recession. He said, `What is this technical recession nonsense? I know a recession when I see one. I do not see one now. I will tell you what a recession is: high unemployment, bank failures and people selling assets that they have not got'. That was a bit galling for Senator Button, but it is still true of course. A few days later—we took this quote out at random from the Age—he is reported as saying:

PARA.TAB: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked for a realistic assessment of the state of the economy. I do not think there could have been a more realistic assessment of the state of the economy than that which was provided in the Budget. The Budget is still before the House; it is still being debated in the House, and the economic prospects contained in the Budget are there for all to see and for the Opposition to debate if it likes. It is a realistic assessment. There has been, as I said at Budget time, no gilding of the lily. That was a very sober assessment of what we believed the Australian economy could do in 1992-93.

I have made the point on many occasions that, rather than denigrating this as an outlook for the Australian economy, we should be reflecting on the fact that we in Australia are doing rather better than practically every other OECD country. The point I find so difficult to comprehend so far as the Opposition's position is concerned is that it homes in on those aspects which it thinks bolsters its case for a depressed economy, an economy which it says persists in this state, when on all of the evidence the Australian economy is performing comparatively well compared with other economies around the world.

I am sure that Mr Bush, as he moves towards the presidential election, would much rather be defending our growth prospects than his own. I am quite sure that the Chancellor of the Exchequer in Great Britain would have had a much easier time of it at the recent Conservative conference had he been defending our prospects for economic growth than his own, which continue to foresee negative growth in the United Kingdom.

Where is the evidence that suggests that the assessment we provided at Budget time was somehow wrong? Where is the evidence to suggest that we have, as claimed by the Deputy Leader, gilded the lily as far as our growth estimates are concerned? It is perhaps worth taking the views of those who make their living out of forecasting the economy, giving advice to people about where they think the economy is going. If we look at those people in Australia who operate in that way we find that almost all of them, if not all of them, have growth forecasts in excess of those that were included in the Budget. Mr Fiedler at AMP suggests that 4.3 would have been a better figure; Jeff Schubert, 3.5; John Stroud, 4.3; Nicki Hutley, 3.5; Chris Caton, 4.2; Grant Bailey, 3.8; and so it goes on, with the average of all of those forecasters, as reported in the Business Review Weekly in June of this year, being 3.9 per cent.

Therefore it was not surprising that in the period immediately after the Budget there was a view that, if anything, the Government had erred on the cautious side as far as prospects for economic growth were concerned. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition makes a big point about the fact that the world economy is not growing very fast. That is precisely the same point that I have been making when I have said that the Australian economy is growing faster than most of the rest of the world.

It is true that the developed part of the world is growing slowly; and we are not going to have that part of the world economy pulling the Australian economy through to more rapid rates of growth. But, of course, this is not something that has struck us just in the last couple of weeks; it is something with which we have been familiar for some time. We have seen the reports of the OECD. We have seen that the OECD has been progressively revising downwards its estimates of world economic activity. But we were aware of this circumstance when we put together our Budget estimates in the course of July and early August. So this is not something which has just struck us, even if it has just struck the Opposition or if some other commentators around the world have just become aware of this point.

The fact is that the world economy is growing slowly. In some countries their economies will not grow but will continue to shrink, and some of the earlier forecasts of growth are being revised downwards. But that is not automatically a reason why, just a few weeks after having made our estimates of Australia's rate of growth, we should be revising ours down. The quite empty and mischievous assertions that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made, alleging that I have received advice, which I am keeping a secret, that in fact there is a case for revising down our estimates of growth in Australia, are simply not true. I have received no such advice, although I have received assessments that some of the earlier published assessments of world economic activity will not be achieved. But there is nothing new about that; we were already aware of that. We were already aware that some of the published data of the IMF and OECD was unlikely to be achieved, and that was factored into the estimates that we made for our Budget a month or so ago.

I just repeat the point that in the Budget Papers it was indicated that the sources of growth in the Australian economy should be private consumption, housing and public investment, while the rural sector and private investment should begin to make a contribution in the course of the year.

Of course, it would not be surprising if some of the sources of the composition of growth did vary somewhat in the course of the year. But the aggregate growth forecasts remain unchanged because, whilst the evidence on the retail side has been a little less encouraging, the evidence on the housing side has been more encouraging. So these factors tend to balance each other out.

The important thing about all this is that the sources of growth in the Australian economy during this financial year are largely going to have a domestic orientation. It is because of that, because we realised that we could do something about spurring Australian economic growth, that we decided to provide the fiscal stimulus that we provided in the Budget, on top of what had already been provided in the One Nation statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). But, intriguingly, members of the Opposition are now saying that the prospects for Australian growth will be less than we forecast in the Budget. Are they still sticking to their absurd proposition that we should not be providing the fiscal stimulus responsibly provided within this Budget in order to promote economic recovery?

It seems to me that they cannot have it both ways. They cannot say that it was irresponsible to provide that fiscal stimulus—and, indeed, on their say-so, they would reduce the Budget deficit and therefore the fiscal stimulus by some $6 billion or $7 billion; that is their prescription—and then say that, in fact, the economy is growing slower than it should be. The very consequence of the policy which they are advocating is one of very much slower growth and very much higher unemployment.

In this debate that we are having about the prospects for the Australian economy it ought to be made very clear where the Government stands and where the Opposition stands. The Government stands on the side of providing in a responsible way a stimulus from the Budget to promote a recovery which will not be excessive. In other words, it will be a sustainable one. It will be sustainable because inflation is low and can be maintained low. This is largely because we have a wages policy dedicated towards maintaining low levels of inflation, with inflation at or below the level of our trading partners. On top of that, we are providing the kind of stimulus from the Budget which would ensure that the economy grows more rapidly than otherwise and would ensure that we are doing everything we can to improve the economic prospects for the nation and the prospects for individuals in Australia, particularly those who are out of work.

On the other hand, the Opposition advocates a slower growing economy, one that would have only half the stimulus. Those opposite would actually fight against the automatic adjustments which occur in the Budget when the economy slows down. They would fight against that. They would drive the economy not faster into recovery but into reverse; that is, back into recession. They would probably create unemployment in excess of an additional 120,000 people as a result of their policy. On top of that, they would pursue policies which would see the inflation rate go up, not down. They have no policy instruments on the wages side to deal with that, other than high interest rates.

It is very clear, beyond all of the nonsense which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition got up and speculated about today, what their prescription actually is. Their policy is to return the economy to recession—to do that by reducing the fiscal stimulus and then to increase inflation by the introduction of their consumption tax; then, in order to contain the inflationary impact and to try to ensure that it does not get into wages, to increase interest rates; therefore, further stifling the economy.

It is not surprising that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said in January that under his policies he foresees a decade of despair and a decade of recession. He thinks that Australia is entirely at the whim of the rest of the world, whereas we see there are things that can be done by this country and things which we have already done to try to stimulate economic growth—not economic growth which is unsustainable but economic growth which is about the average level of that of our trading partners.

The old-fashioned view of the Opposition has come through very clearly in this debate, because those opposite think that what is happening in the industrialised world, particularly Europe and North America, determines our fate. They ought to wake up. They ought to realise that more and more of the determinants of our economic fortunes live just to our north in those rapidly growing economies in Asia. We have set about trying to reorient our trade towards those economies so that we can have this higher rate of growth than some of the more stodgy, industrialised countries were able to achieve this year. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Full-time jobs fell 0.5 per cent in August, resuming their downwards trend, while the unemployment rate continues to trend upwards and the rise in part-time jobs suggests that any eventual pick-up in full-time ones will not be as great as in previous recoveries.

The article continued:

PARA.TAB: Make no mistake about it, this debate is not about us saying to the Government `Look, we think your policies are wrong', or trying to identify some failing in the Treasury or the Budget itself. It is not us; it is the third most senior member of the Government saying that it has got it wrong. What is this all about? I put it to the House that it is something a little more fundamental than just the falling apart of the figures in the Budget. It is really about the falling apart of the Government.

Senator Button is not the only person from the Hawke camp who has given projections in the last few weeks which are quite contrary to those the Treasurer would have us believe. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley)—we know he is no great friend of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating); nor the Prime Minister of him—warned us on 8 October that `unemployment would not fall notably before the end of 1992'. We heard the Treasurer today and last week telling us that unemployment was going to fall below 10 per cent by the middle of next year. His Minister for Employment, Education and Training is either getting briefings from a different source or he knows what it is about. The reality is that unemployment is still trending to increase.

The other one which fascinated me was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). We all know that he is not exactly a great friend of the Prime Minister; nor the reverse. He said last week that the average broad-acre farmer was forecast to lose $25,700 this financial year—proof that the rural recession continues. There we have it. We have somebody—one of the `friends' of the Prime Minister—identifying that things will continue to be bad in the rural recession; we have another `friend' of the Prime Minister telling us that unemployment will be down; and we have the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce telling us that the growth projections are not likely to be met. This is really quite fundamental to the capacity of the Government to govern.

What worries me is that the Government has also forgotten one of the other fundamental factors. We heard about the embroidery—as the Prime Minister likes to call it—and about how the fiscal stimulus of which the Treasurer boasts in the Budget will ensure that we get the growth rate the Government has projected. I point out to him that over the last four years business investment has fallen. This Budget predicts a further decline of 2 per cent in business investment. As far as John Ralph and the Business Council of Australia are concerned, they have said that they expect that business investment will fall more than twice that. I do not think that bodes very well for the economy.

Our concern is that, faced with this dilemma and crisis, all the Treasurer can do is talk about fiscal stimulus and yesterday's figures and try to defend a number that is indefensible. The reality is that not only is the number indefensible but so also is the policy of the Government. While it continues to project uncertainty and doubt about its capacity to provide solutions, what do honourable members think is happening out there? There is a real climate of uncertainty.

There is not doubt that even he, when he gets out in the real world, finds how doubt and uncertainty plague the average Australian. There is no doubt that he has to accept, as he said yesterday, that there is a `real problem' for his Government and he has brought a lot of suffering to people. It is no use his turning to the same `spirit of experimentation' that united Australia in the midst of drought and depression a century ago. That is not the basis for recovery in 1992. The basis for recovery in 1992 is to get rid of the present Government and introduce some positive policies. I suggest that the Government might start by looking at Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be able to follow the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). Of course, it is only the internal politics of the Opposition that keep the honourable member on the back bench; obviously, if there were some genuine reward for people on the basis of ability the right honourable member would not be on the back bench.

PARA.TAB: Although he made a spirited contribution to the debate, the basic essence of his argument was totally flawed. The Budget forecast of 3 per cent is a modest one. It is a forecast tha is sustainable and I think will be borne out. We have already seen in the last year growth of 1.6 per cent. It does not mean that there has to be a great acceleration in growth for that Budget forecast of 3 per cent to be met. Indeed, a number of economic indicators and forecasters have put the view that that Budget forecast is right on line.

I point to Market Insights, the most recent publication produced by Westpac, which honourable members would have received in their rooms today. A flick through that document indicates that Westpac—Australia's largest bank and, I would have thought, an organisation that could claim some sort of background in making financial predictions—forecasts that economic growth will be 4 per cent by the end of next year. In fact, that is even higher than the Budget forecasts we are debating today.

What is the basis of the Budget forecast? The Budget forecast was not built on some sort of concept that we will have a booming world economy and Australia will be dragged out of its slow economic path by the world economy. It was based on the assumption that economic growth throughout the world would be slow and that the United States, Japan and Europe as a whole would be going through a period of subdued growth. That is the whole basis of the Budget strategy. It is because Australia is in a period of slow growth that the Government considered it appropriate to go through a process of public infrastructure work and expand the Budget deficit so that there was an increase in local demand.

That is the point of this debate—not whether Senator Button changed his mind and later that day retracted his statement made on the Sunday program. The fact is that Senator Button's initial statement was wrong. He was overly pessimistic and he corrected that through a statement he issued later that day. The real debate we should be concentrating on is: what are the policies that will help Australia? The major concern in my electorate is not what Senator Button is uttering; people want to know what will happen about employment, the basics of government services, health, education, and what sort of future they will have for themselves and their kids.

That is what the Budget should be all about; it should be about tackling those major problems. That is what this Budget is about and that is what that growth forecast is all about. It is about putting together a series of policies that will ensure that Australia has a reasonable level of growth that is sustainable for our economic conditions. That is why we have put in place a series of expansions in public infrastructure. That is why both the One Nation statement and the Budget concentrate on road building, the Australian rail network, and the education system through the development of TAFE. That is why it is a Budget that is appropriate for the circumstances in which Australia finds itself.

In contrast—and we were urged by the right honourable member for New England to make a contrast—we have an Opposition promoting its Fightback policies. The right honourable member for New England said that the Government should have a look at Fightback. One would assume from the nature of this debate that the whole basis of what the Opposition is saying is, `Look, we can do better. We can supply better growth through out forecasts.' That is an interesting concept and I think we should look at it.

The Sydney Morning Herald recently conducted a survey of some 37 leading Australian economists. They were asked a series of questions about the prospects for various economic conditions under the Government's program in the One Nation statement and the Budget as opposed to the policies outlined by the Opposition in Fightback. It went through a series of questions about economic performance as predicted by these 37 leading economists under both sets of policies. The first question they were asked was obviously about growth, and that is what the debate is about today. The question posed to the 37 economists was: will growth be higher at the end of the next three-year term under the coalition or under Labor? Some eight of the economists predicted that growth would be better under the coalition and 24 of the country's leading economists predicted that growth would be higher under Labor.

Of course, it does not end there. We turn to unemployment. Which party, according to Australia's leading economists, has the policies in place that will be best for unemployment? Thirteen economists nominated that the Opposition's policies would lead to higher unemployment and only four believed that would be the outcome under Labor. Clearly, the economists believe that Labor will have a better record of tackling unemployment.

What about inflation? Nineteen economists out of this group predicted that inflation would be higher under the coalition than it would be under Labor; only 13 believed it would be higher under Labor. What about interest rates—a vital issue for my electorate and for the electorates of many honourable members. It is an important issue for many first home buyers and people throughout Australia who are in the home market at the moment. In fact, housing is one sector of the economy which is performing strongly. It is one sector which is leading to a fair amount of growth in the Australian economy. What would be the impact of the Opposition's policies as opposed to the Government's policies on interest rates? Some 23 of the country's leading economists surveyed believed that interest rates would be higher over the next three years under a coalition government while only six contended that interest rates would be higher under Labor's policies.

That was a fairly damning assessment by 37 of Australia's leading economists: first, they predicted that growth would be higher under the Government's policies; second, that unemployment would be lower under the Government's policies; third, that inflation would be lower under the Government's policies; and, fourth, that interest rates would be considerably higher under the policies being promoted by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about unemployment?

—They predicted that unemployment would be higher under the Fightback proposals than it would be under the Government's policy as set out in the One Nation statement and the Budget. One does not have to be a leading economist to come to that same conclusion. What is the basic assumption of the Opposition's proposals? The whole basis of Fightback is to withdraw something like $5 billion to $6 billion from government spending. I see that the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) is nodding and conceding that that is an important part of the Opposition's program.

PARA.TAB: One does not have to be a leading economist or a genius to work out that, if we are in a period of very slow growth, if we are in a period of sluggish demand, and something like $6 billion is drawn out of the economy through government slashing its programs, people will lose their jobs. This involves not just public servants losing their jobs, although obviously large numbers would do that; it takes in all of the things which government purchases from Australian business. The Federal Government alone purchases something like $10 billion worth of goods and services annually from Australian businesses.

The Opposition is talking about kicking the guts out of Australian business by withdrawing demand at the very time that—by its own argument—it is saying that growth is weak in this country, that the economic conditions are not conducive to continuing strong growth, and that we are looking at a period of uncertainty in terms of the economic conditions and the world economy. Yet, after conceding all of those points, after saying that it believed that the growth forecast—and it is making the argument—should be weak, its prescription is not to try to do something to counteract that; it is to reduce the size of government and not do the sorts of public infrastructure works that the Government has put in place.

The Opposition knows—and the economists in this survey also confirm it—that that would mean lower growth, higher unemployment, higher inflation and higher interest rates under the Liberals. That is the prescription which the Opposition gives to the Australian people.

The Budget forecasts are on track. The forecasts for growth are on track. We will have steady growth under this Labor Government, falling unemployment, low interest rates and low inflation, and Australia can look forward to a renewed future throughout the rest of this decade.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time allowed for the discussion of Estimates there are not many matters that I am able to raise in the area of the environment, so I am going to confine myself to two specific matters and then make some more general comments about the administration of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. The first matter I want to raise is one of very great conservation significance. It is quite a specific matter; that is, the control of the weed pest mimosa pigra.

PARA.TAB: There is a substantial infestation of mimosa near Oenpelli in Arnhem Land. Mimosa is one of the most significant weed pests in northern Australia. It has a severe impact on Top End wetlands and spreads very quickly if not controlled. The significance of the problem is such that mimosa was the only weed specifically mentioned by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his `Our Country, Our Future' statement.

Last financial year, the Commonwealth provided $2m to control an isolated 8,000 hectare infestation near Oenpelli, which is also close to Kakadu. The problem involves significant local Aboriginal employment. Follow-up herbicide treatment of the entire area was planned this year at a projected cost of $1.2m to prevent regrowth and give competitive plants a chance re-establish in the area. Unfortunately, this year's Federal Budget contained no commitment to continue the program and it is proving quite difficult—as I am informed by the Northern Territory Government—to secure a firm commitment from the Federal Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). It is a bit hard to work out why this was left out of the Budget. It could have been just a mistake.

I have actually looked at the problem on the ground. The matter is very serious. The mimosa is like a bush that grows to shoulder height or a bit higher. Once it has taken over an area, it is not possible for animals to move through it. It kills off everything else in the surrounding area. It is moving across Arnhem Land, and it threatens Kakadu. Unless there is a very determined program of eradication, it could take over vast areas of land in northern Queensland, the Northern Territory and, possibly, Western Australia. It is a serious matter.

The real problem—this is a very practical matter and I am not making the point in a political way—is that a lot of money has been sunk into the program to date. There is a lot of Aboriginal employment involved in the follow-up part of the program. If the money is not available to continue the herbicide treatment, all the efforts to date will be lost. I ask the Minister to look closely at this matter. Somebody from the Minister's office has said that the money will be available, but it has not been possible for the Northern Territory conservation Minister to get a firm commitment from the Federal Minister, so I would like the Minister to look closely at it.

The second matter I wish to mention involves the huskies in Antarctica and the Department's Antarctic program. When the negotiations were proceeding for the protocol to the Antarctic treaty to preserve the environment of the Antarctic, which was signed in Madrid on 4 October 1991, there was a requirement not to introduce exotic animal species to the territory. There was also a requirement to move out the huskies that were already there by a date in 1994. This has been a matter of considerable concern to those who have worked with the huskies in the Antarctic. The scientists and support staff who have spent a considerable amount of time down there have worked with these dogs over many years. The dogs themselves have been an integral part of the research program. Also, they sometimes provide a safer means of transport around the bases than vehicles do.

The people supporting the retention of the huskies in the Antarctic do not challenge the fact that eventually they will need to be phased out under this agreement, but they do object to the decision of the Minister that within about one month they will have to be moved to a site in Minnesota in the United States—a completely alien environment. This has caused an outcry from those who have worked closely with the huskies in the Antarctic over many years. As honourable members can imagine, it is a very emotional subject for them, and it is a matter for which one can have a great deal of sympathy.

I have been following this matter up as best I can, and I have some new information. The British, who have dogs there also, have taken a very different line from the one our Minister has taken. I quote from a letter from Mr Caton, the Third Secretary of the British High Commission in Canberra:

I understand that you are interested in details of the British position on huskies in Antarctica. This is contained in the following statement recently released by the Director of the British Antarctic Survey, Dr Drewry:
"At Rothera BAS—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the British Antarctic Survey—

has 20 huskies, all born in the Antarctic, and they include 5 young pups. By the summer of 1993-94 only 14 will remain due to the age factor. Of these, 7 will be 7 years of age (at the end of their working life), 2 will be 6 years of age (past major expedition age) and 5 will be 3 years of age.

PARA.TAB: In anticipation of the ban on huskies, BAS stopped all breeding in 1990. No huskies will be removed from Antarctica by the UK and all the present animals will be allowed to live their natural active life-span in the only environment the dogs know.

BAS recognises the very important role huskies have played in the heritage of Antarctica and continue to play in maintaining the morale and excitement of an Antarctic base. Winter journeys with huskies have provided the most testing times for the mountaineers whose summer occupation is to assist scientists collect data safely.

Britain is therefore committed to removing dogs currently in the Antarctic, by means of phasing out the British huskies by natural means. The deadline of April 1994 contained in Annex II to the Environmental Protocol (which will only enter into force after ratification by all Parties) is not considered a legally binding constraint at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a perfectly sensible way of handling this matter. The Minister has indicated, in response to representations, that it was absolutely vital to agree to the removal of the huskies quickly in order to get the environment protocol signed. The Minister has put a very high political price on this. Generally speaking, the advice we are getting from the British and from others is that that really was unnecessary; it was a relatively minor part of the whole deal. We think she is going too far and we ask her to reconsider that decision and not to send these dogs to Minnesota, where they would be in an alien environment, but to leave them as the British have—to stop them breeding and let them live out their lives where they have already spent all of their time.

PARA.TAB: The final point I make is perhaps a more political one. There is a very strong pattern in the Minister's activities in this Department of giving conservation groups some kind of indication that their demands will be met—to a great extent, knowing that those promises are undeliverable—and subsequently backing down. This has happened in lots of ways. It has happened, very broadly, with the promises that were made in the last election.

The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, has pointed out that the Labor Party has broken over half of the 71 promises it gave to the Greens in the last election. There is a great deal of disappointment about that. There was the environmental kit for schools, which was rather an extreme publication catering to the more extreme areas of the green movement. That was subsequently withdrawn. It was an absolute fiasco. There was the Benders Cave incident and, most recently, there was the Endangered Species Protection Bill—a Bill which had no chance of getting through Cabinet colleagues but which was put up as an apparent gesture to the Greens.

The Greens do not appreciate this kind of behaviour. It is a very erratic way for a senior Minister to behave. It certainly is not appreciated by anyone with a deep interest in the environment, including people from the various conservation groups. I am getting a lot of feedback that this type of behaviour on the part of the Minister is not appreciated. I will be raising those matters in other forums as best I can. This is a matter of grave concern to the Opposition and, I believe, to the green movement, to the conservation movement and also to this Parliament.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this portfolio debate I want to discuss the excellent level of funding for sport that the Commonwealth Government has given over past years. I refer especially to that announced recently by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). I then want to contrast that significant Commonwealth support for sport in Australia with what the Opposition proposes, which is not only a cut in the level of Commonwealth support for sport and recreation in this country but also loading onto ordinary sports men and women the impact of a goods and services tax, which will make everything from registering as a player going into a competition and travelling the country to buying footy shorts and socks more expensive and thus make sport a not easily obtained option for Australians. As Australians, we have become used to being easily able to engage in sport. It is a right of all Australians to participate, to become active and to be able to get into sport.

PARA.TAB: The Minister announced in this year's Budget that the Commonwealth Government will provide $83m for sport and recreation in 1992-93. Of that $83m, the Australian Sports Commission will receive $59.6m this year and a similar amount in each of the next three years. This means the continuation and enhancement of existing programs for elite athletes, existing programs for the support of national sporting organisations and, consistent with a balanced approach to sports development, new and enhanced programs for sports participation. It means that the Government's commitment amounts to some $293m over the next four years. That compares with $217m during the previous four years, which marks a 35 per cent increase.

I do not think there is any doubt that there is a direct relationship between the amount of support the Commonwealth gives and the success that Australian sports men and women have had in international play over the past couple of years. I want to congratulate a woman from my electorate, Lisa McShea, who is the current junior Wimbledon doubles title holder; she also made the quarter finals in junior Wimbledon singles some months ago. Lisa is from the city of Redcliffe in my electorate and I had the pleasure of playing tennis with her on the courts here at Parliament House just a couple of weeks ago. We played doubles and she very sensibly chose me as her partner. Of course we won—although I will not give honourable members the score. She is a good player and is now well advanced on a career. She is rated about 400 in the world already. This is an 18-year-old from my electorate.

She has been able to get such a good start because she has a Commonwealth scholarship; she has support from the taxpayer to pursue her career. She is based at the Australian Institute of Sport and has to spend much time and money out of the country circulating and competing. I congratulate Lisa and I congratulate the Commonwealth Government for the support it gives to Lisa. In a sense, she will become an ambassador for Australia. She is a delightful individual, and her great talent and skills mean that the name of Australia is being made all over the tennis courts of the world.

Contrast that, though, with the miserly attitude the Opposition has to the support of sport in Australia. Senator Baume, who is the Opposition spokesperson on sport, has said that the Opposition has promised to cut $17m from the sport and recreation budget. That will affect adversely a lot of top class sports men and women in Australia. In addition to the cutting of expenditure that the Opposition wants to go on with, unfortunately its figures do not add up, and we need to put this on the record. The Opposition claims that $3m a year would be cut from the capital spending of the Australian Institute of Sport. The problem there is that the capital expenditure in 1992-93 is estimated at just $1.2m. We cannot cut $3m out of a total expenditure of $1.2m. So Senator Baume should go back and do his figures again. I do not want him to cut one penny out of sports administration funding in this country, but if he is going to go on about that sort of nonsense, he should get his figures right in the first place, for goodness' sake.

Senator Baume also wants to cut $4m from what he calls administration costs. Unfortunately, he does not understand that a lot of the significant programs of the Australian Institute of Sport are written up as administration costs. For example, if he cuts $4m out of expenditure here, things such as sports science, medicine and information programs, the Australian Coaching Council and other aspects of the Institute programs are also going to be cut. So Senator Baume is not fiddling about making the administration of sport in Australia more efficient; he is cutting to the bone important programs that will affect the progress of our best Australian sports men and women. He should not deny it; that is what will happen.

He also wants to knock about one of our most successful programs, the community cultural recreation and sports facilities program, which has enabled millions of dollars to be spent specifically at a local level on sports facilities. Senator Baume should come up to my electorate and tell my cricket players at Aspley and Albany Creek, my clay target shooters in Clontarf, my hockey players in Redcliffe, and even the amateur fishermen up on the Redcliffe Peninsula, that they cannot have the facilities that we, the Commonwealth, have built for them over the past couple of years. They would not have those facilities in my electorate to make cricket, tennis, clay target shooting, fishing and all the rest such a joy if the Opposition were in government. It would cut the sorts of programs that put bricks and mortar on the ground for the enjoyment of Australian sports men and women.

So there is an enormous contrast with what we believe is money well spent through the Commonwealth's support of recreation and sport and the Opposition wanting to cut those funds away. In addition, if the Opposition were to impose a goods and services tax it would have an enormous impact on people's ability to afford sport and recreation and also on their ability to administer sport.

Let me take the Committee through some of the impacts of a GST on sport. Think about the increased cost of actually playing a game were a GST to be introduced. First of all, registration fees for sporting clubs, which are not currently taxed, would have a 15 per cent GST on top of them. Entry fees, which are not currently taxed, would have a 15 per cent GST whacked on them. Admission charges to games and so on, which are not currently taxed, would have a 15 per cent GST bunged on them. All the uniforms—socks, tracksuits and shorts—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give the other side of the question. You are only giving one side of the question.

—The honourable member for McEwen should be quiet and listen. All sorts of sporting equipment and clothing are not currently taxed. I know the argument about taking tax out of it, but these are things that are not currently taxed and they will suffer the imposition of a 15 per cent goods and services tax. Tracksuits, shorts, jumpers, socks and boots will be taxed at least 11 or 12 per cent more, deducting the sorts of taxes that are already imposed on those goods at the moment, and a full 15 per cent where there are no current taxes on them.

PARA.TAB: Coaching courses, because they are not currently taxed, would suffer the full 15 per cent imposition. Travel to tournaments and championships would suffer from the further imposition of a tax. In addition, accommodation costs will increase. Members of sporting clubs go away; I used to do a great deal of travel as a hockey player.
