My parents would have to come up with the $300 or $400 to send little Gary away for a week to play hockey in New South Wales. It will now cost 15 per cent or whatever more in net terms.

What an idiotic situation it is when the Opposition not only withdraws direct government finance for these people but also begins to tax sports men and women in Australia. The treasurer of an amateur sporting club works his little tail off all year long just to get all the facts and figures together. He would have to become a tax collecting agent for the purposes of collecting the GST and passing it on to the Australian Taxation Office. The poor old treasurer would have to put in an enormous amount of time, effort and knowledge just to run the dinky local sporting club. It will be more difficult to administer, more expensive to play, and the Commonwealth Government will not help out. There are three different ways in which sport will be cruelled in this country if that mob ever gets in. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very interesting to hear the dialogue, or should I say the diatribe—
—One sided.

—It was a very one sided description of what is proposed in Fightback. It is obvious that the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) cannot come up with a policy that will be more positive than Fightback. So, like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and many others, he is resorting to scare tactics as the only means of defence.

PARA.TAB: The shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), in the course of his remarks a few minutes ago spoke about a major problem in the tropics that is confronting us all, the problem of mimosa pigra. Having been a member and deputy chairman of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts for six or seven years, I know that we have been confronted with a major problem. As the shadow Minister has indicated—and I know the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is also very concerned about it—it is a very serious problem. The shadow Minister said mimosa pigra grows only to about shoulder height; in fact, in many areas it is over 12 feet high.

It is a major headache at the moment for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service in the Northern Territory. It is able to engage only in a control exercise. Very importantly, a lot of work is being done with regard to biological control, which is one of the newer ways of coming to grips with some of these exotic problems that we have in our nation and that other nations have. We remember coming to grips with the problem of rabbits, by the introduction of myxomatosis.

So far some progress has been made with regard to mimosa pigra in the form of biological experiments. The larvae of a moth that has been introduced now penetrate the stem and are able to reduce the productivity of seeds by 60 per cent. This is a very pleasing advance in the control of that very serious problem—and the seriousness cannot be underestimated—of that exotic weed in the Northern Territory. That still leaves 40 per cent of seeds being spread around and that, in itself, is still creating a very vast problem. I probably would be fairly safe in saying that the Government is very concerned about it as well, and I encourage those opposite to pay particular attention to what is a very serious problem. I have been to see it three or four times and I have been amazed at the progress that is being made in that area.

One of the other areas that concern me is that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts tables reports from time to time. One of the most recent reports is entitled Biodiversity: The contribution of community-based programs. We tabled that in June, along with another report on the moving pictures inquiry, which is a full scale inquiry into the Australian film industry. I believe that a number of recommendations in the biodiversity report, which were emphasised at the time of tabling the report, ought to have been taken notice of in the preparation of the current Budget. Recommendation 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: that funding for the STB program—
that is, the save the bush program—

be immediately increased to $5m in recognition of its vital contribution in maintaining biodiversity and ecosystem processes and in the implementation of the proposed national biodiversity strategy and the Decade of Landcare, and that funding be increased to $10m by 1994.
Recommendation 8 states:
that funding for the OBT program—
that is, the one billion trees program—
be increased to $6m to provide additional resources for the implementation of aspects of program development identified in recommendations 6 and 7.

Recommendations 6 and 7 pointed to the need to develop national standards for revegetation programs, the collection and storage of indigenous native plant seed and the protection and maintenance of eco-adapted seed stock. The recommendations also included that regional seed banks or seed orchards be established at a local or district level under these guidelines.

PARA.TAB: The save the bush program was identified as the most vital program in maintaining biodiversity—a very serious point at issue in the discussions taking place today—outside national parks and reserves, yet its funding represents less than 3 per cent of the decade of Landcare funds. Increased funds for either of these programs were not identified in the Budget at all, which is a very disturbing feature of the current appropriations about which we are talking. I reiterate the importance of these programs in community conservation initiatives and recommend the Government consider increased funding for the programs as well as implementing other recommendations made by the Committee in that report. It is a report that has gone right around the nation and has received wide acclaim from all the people who know what proper research and so on are being done on the environment and biodiversity in particular.

One of the things that worry me about these reports is that committees go to an awful lot of trouble. When parliament is not sitting, honourable members have to travel all over the country. A lot of expense is incurred in thoroughly undertaking public hearings and looking very carefully into these difficulties. We have many local discussions with the people at the coalface who really know what is going on in these areas. We produce these reports and the Government has a declared policy of responding to them within three months. When I looked through the record book earlier today, I noted that the report on hazardous chemicals, which was tabled in December 1982, was responded to in November 1991. That was not a three-month period. Admittedly, it was a pretty important report; nevertheless, the time to consider it was really quite dreadful.

A number of reports have not been responded to within the three-month period. The Protection of the Greater Daintree report was tabled in August 1984. The report on tourism in the Antarctic was tabled in May 1989. The report entitled Tourism in the Indian Ocean Territories was tabled in August 1990. As I said, the report on the moving pictures inquiry was tabled in June, which is more than three months ago. This biodiversity report, with so many very important recommendations for the Government, has not been taken up in a response from the Government. What is more worrying is that, despite the requests for additional funding for the save the bush program and the one billion trees program, there was no mention in the Budget of these very important recommendations to the Minister.

I commend again this report to the Minister and her staff. I ask that very serious consideration be given to the recommendations in that report. They are vital recommendations and something should be done about taking very special notice of them, particularly the recommendations for increased funding, not substantial funding, especially for the save the bush program. The funding needs to be granted immediately so that we can continue with these very important programs that are coming to grips with this problem in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to participate in this debate this afternoon on the allocation of funding, particularly for sport, as brought down in the Budget for 1992-93. It gives me the opportunity to not only clearly enunciate the Government's commitment to sport but also indicate that, as ever, the Opposition is somewhat narky when it comes to its professed support for a number of programs in which the Commonwealth Government has a legitimate role. It is the Oppositions's policy that it will cut funding for sport.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear the last speaker, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), extolling the virtues of one of the Government's environmental programs and calling for increased funding. It is amazing how many members of the Opposition, when given the opportunity, stand up in this place and seek additional funding for programs which this Government has put in place, yet in their own Fightback! document we find that those programs will be either cut or totally eliminated.

I am delighted about this Budget allocation for sport, because as a government we are maintaining the momentum of the allocation of funds for sport which we started some three years ago. Honourable members will recall that, as a result of two parliamentary committee inquiries into sports funding and administration, which were undertaken by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which at the time I had the honour to chair, we made substantial recommendations which the Government of the day, particularly the then Minister for Sport, Senator Richardson, acted on.

What we saw then was a commitment by this Government to sports funding. We saw a commitment which recognised that the Commonwealth had a legitimate role to play in the funding of elite sport, the Australian Sports Commission and Australia's international athletes to compete overseas. It was also recognised that the Commonwealth had a legitimate role to play in putting in place programs such as Aussie Sport and to build the participation base of women in the community, and so on. We saw a major increase in the allocation of funds to sport over three successive Budgets. Now it is the turn of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). She has been able to argue most persuasively with our Cabinet colleagues and we have seen the total sport Budget for the next four years increased by 34 per cent; a grand total of $293m is going to be expended over that time.

People might ask, `Why sport? Why do we need the allocation of Commonwealth funds for sport?'. Simply because if we can encourage a healthy lifestyle and role models in the form of elite athletes who go to the Commonwealth Games, or participate in Ironmen or Ironwomen competitions, or in netball that is now televised and so on, then we are developing role models, encouraging young people in Australia to participate in sport and that has beneficial effects not only for their health, but also for government expenditure on things such as health. If people have a healthier lifestyle, then the call in later life for hospitalisation, medical treatment and so on is lessened.

The Government's commitment to maintaining the momentum in sports funding over the next four years is certainly to be commended. I am delighted to see that the elite programs—mainly through the AIS and athlete assistance, which were recommended in those two sports funding inquiries—I recommended are now also increased by a billion dollars. I am also delighted to see that the funding for the Aussie Sport and the participation program is up by $2m to $7.5m over the next 12 months. There is also an increased allocation for drugs testing. All of those would be welcomed by most members of this Parliament.

It disturbed me greatly when I heard the shadow spokesman for the arts, heritage and sport, Senator Michael Baume, in a radio broadcast on the ABC in the Illawarra some months ago. He attacked the Government and proffered the untruth that this Government was cutting the expenditure on sport. Nothing could be further from the truth, as I have demonstrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fightback.

—I will come to Fightback in a moment. I was pleased that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories responded to the editor of the Illawarra Mercury in a very forthright letter which clearly pointed out that this represented a 35 per cent increase in sports funding by this Government. She went on very adroitly to point out that the program which our Government, the Keating Government, has put in place is in stark contrast to Senator Baume's own policy which promises to cut Sports Commission funding by $7m. Any sensible person would be able to tell those opposite that cutting $7m from a budget of just under $60m must mean cuts to programs. As the Minister said, to pretend otherwise is simply foolish. That does not even beg the question of what will happen to sports funding and to sports clubs under the proposals enunciated in Fightback for the GST.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) made some very telling points on that in his contribution earlier this afternoon. Quite clearly it is a very important issue that any sports loving person—whether he be a participant or simply somebody who enjoys sport and watching it—will have to consider in some detail.

I recall that last year the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) talked about the effect that the GST would have on the average family—a husband, wife and two children—going to the footy match. When we add the 15 per cent to the cost of the train ride to get there, the 15 per cent to the cost of the tickets to get into the outer, the 15 per cent to the cost of getting a seat in the grandstand, the 15 per cent to the ice-cream and the packet of chips at half time at the footy, the 15 per cent to the program being bought on their way home to remember the day, and the 15 per cent to the bus ride, it will cost the average person a great deal more. I think anyone who has an interest in sport would recognise that. Participants and sports associations should also consider what that will mean to the purchasing of equipment and so on. These things are all really important. I doubt very much that people would think that this will cheapen the cost of participating in sport or, indeed, anything of a sporting nature.

Interestingly, an article picked up Senator Baume's comments on what the conservatives might do if they were in government and if he were the Minister for sport. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 August this year there is an article entitled `Tarnish on sport gold feared under Hewson'. It quotes a number of different people and their reaction. For example, the Confederation of Australian Sport, perhaps the leading organisation, brings together over 100 different sporting organisations. Mr Dene Moore said he doubted that, if Mr Reith became Treasurer, he would do anything for sport. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any guy that would come out with his comments in this orgy of self-congratulation that goes on around the Olympics would have to be a pretty insensitive guy, Mr Moore said.

PARA.TAB: In 1987, when he was the shadow minister for sport, he was the architect of the worst sports policy ever drafted in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that just about says it all. As we know, he has moved on to be the shadow Treasurer. If he, along with Senator Baume, are the architects of the Opposition's policies for sport, then I think we are in more trouble than even the Fightback document says. I certainly commend to any person who has an interest in sport the Government's fine record in sports funding, not only in elite sport—looking after our Olympians and seeing the success that came from the most recent Olympic Games in Barcelona—but also in what has occurred in spreading the base level of support, all the programs that are generated for mass participation, such as getting after school activities going, which the Commonwealth Government supports.

PARA.TAB: I also commend the Minister for her persistence in ensuring that the community cultural sports and recreation facilities program is continuing to run. In my view there is a missing element in the Government's sports policy—I have said this before—that is, we need a major international or regional sports facilities program with a considerable sum of money in it so that major projects, such as basketball stadiums or improvements to major football fields and so on, can get part of the funding associated with that from the Commonwealth. At the moment that does not exist. It seems to be State or local government responsibility. It is something that we need to look at. On the whole, this again continues the fine work of the Government in sports funding. It maintains the momentum of sports funding and it addresses all the important issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week we heard the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) comment on the amount of space in the Fightback! document allocated to the environment portfolio. I have no interest in talking at any great length about this matter. However, I must point out that in the Budget Speech, which we are now discussing, the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia (Mr Dawkins) spent a whole four sentences, taking less than seven lines in the printed document, on the subject of the environment.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the House we are still going through the process of trying to raise the level of debate on environmental policy. We are, by now, accustomed to this Government's policy formulation, not by mention in this House, not by debate in this House, not in the Budget Papers, but by press release to all forms of the media. I suppose we should not be too surprised by this behaviour. The hallmark of the present Government has been its total disregard for proper parliamentary process and, once more, I would urge the Minister to view the issue of the environment in its proper perspective and importance, and grant an adequate time for debate for these issues in this place.

My personal interest covers all the areas of the portfolio which we are considering today. The total outlay for the portfolio is $818m, which compares with an actual outlay of $790m for the 1991-92 financial year—an increase of $28m or 3.6 per cent. In line with the genuine goodwill which has been forthcoming from the coalition on matters covered by this portfolio, there is not a lot of contention between me and the Government on many expenditure items. Indeed, it should be pointed out that the coalition has a proud record of achievement on environmental issues in office, and we have developed clear and sensible policy positions from opposition, which I am pleased to note the Government has followed from time to time.

There are a number of specific items that I wish to discuss in terms of the expenditure decisions announced in the Budget. Firstly, in the area of the arts, one can but only praise the decision to increase the staff numbers by 54 in the National Film and Sound Archive. This is an extremely valuable institution and one in which Australia has been eminent for many years. I commend the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) for having succeeded in this regard. I sincerely hope that the positions relate to conservation skills and are not just administrative or clerical positions. However, it must be remembered that the overall funding to the National Film and Sound Archive has fallen compared to last year's Budget.

As for the wider area of the arts, it should be noted that the assistance to the various areas supporting the present rebirth of quality film making and distribution has dropped in this Budget by 7 per cent from the 1991-92 Budget. This is a very disappointing figure, for in considering the interest in and the expertise shown by witnesses who appeared recently before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I would have hoped for a better deal for our film industry in this Budget. It is a real shame that senior Minister Kelly has not seen fit to follow the recommendations of the Committee's report on the moving pictures inquiry, or to consider its conclusions in her own Budget submissions, particularly as the recommendations of the inquiry were not expensive to introduce.

One hopes that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, having ignored the report's recommendations in this Budget, can put her mind to the significant problems facing the Australian film industry, most notably in the distribution of Australian films and documentaries, particularly in Australia. Goodness knows, we have many experts who know how to work the overseas markets, but our problem is in the Australian market because of the influence of the United States international distributing giants. All members of this House should be very pleased with this success of films such as Strictly Ballroom, which has succeeded in overseas sales, to say nothing of the domestic market for this type of film. I take this opportunity to heartily congratulate all concerned with that film and to say how thoroughly I enjoyed it.

One trembles at the thought of commenting on the disaster that was the environment school kit. However, it is very interesting to see inside the cover of the Minister's Budget kit that the Minister, in all her press releases, saw fit to mention the amounts being spent this financial year only on a range of programs. There is no mention of the amounts spent on those programs in the previous financial year in any of her Budget press releases.

Some of these comparisons are quite amazing. For example, subprogram 1.8 in the Budget papers on cultural heritage saw the amount provided `to enhance the development of Australian culture by increasing awareness, appreciation, preservation, and protection of Australia's cultural heritage and historic environment, especially through the national collections and information services,' reduced from $23.2m to a mere $2.7m this year. Not only this, but it should be noted that the Australian National Maritime Museum, the Australian National Gallery, the National Museum of Australia and the National Library of Australia all saw a reduction in their funding for which I have not seen any explanation from the Minister since the Budget was presented on 18 August.Does this Government have any interest in cultural heritage for Australians? I would welcome hearing from the Minister as to why these reductions in funding have come about, but I regard that as a rare chance because she is not even here for her debate.

Lest the Minister might think that I am here only to criticise her, I congratulate her on the decision to increase outlays to some sections of the meteorological service by nearly $19m. This is an area which calls for considerable investigative work. I congratulate the Minister on those increases.

I am most disappointed in the amount of money allocated to the feral pests program to reduce the impact of feral animals such as the fox, the cat and the goat on native wildlife. I think $1.5m is a paltry amount for this type of necessary investigation. Having travelled around Australia in the last year, it is clear to me that this funding is totally inadequate. The feral pests problem presents a real challenge in the area of biodiversity but, as the Minister has not seen fit to talk to any degree in public about the issue of biodiversity, I should not think she will talk at length in this debate. In fact, I suspect that she will not talk at all.

The issue of endangered species was not covered at any length in the Budget Papers. However, I cannot let this debate pass by without commenting on this important subject. What is now emerging is that the Minister has taken it upon herself to ram this legislation through her own Party. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths), who is at the table, will be aware of that.

I would have thought that an issue such as this would have warranted more responsible consultation from the Minister's Department. It is clear that many groups involved in the ecologically sustainable development process have become quite concerned at the apparent haste of the Minister regarding this legislation. As my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) said last week, why the rush? As last week's Inside Canberra notes, there is a lot of real concern about this draft Bill. The publication said:

SPEECH.PARA: Just on a month ago the Government released An Australian National Strategy for the Conservation of the National Species. An extensive program of consultation and working committees to integrate the strategy into economic planning procedures was outlined. Yet within a month an 86 page Bill was circulated to Ministers `Providing for the conservation and management of the species'.
So the Government's process of consultation on such an important matter has lasted for the grand total of one month. The Inside Canberra publication went on to say:

Industry claims that no meaningful consultation with likely affected parties, including other Government departments, has been undertaken by Ros Kelly or her Department. Industry reaction to the legislation is that it is flawed, is based on United States legislation which has been shown to cost jobs, is ineffective in saving endangered species, is costly to administer, and promotes community conflict.

They are the reactions of industry to a proposed Bill. For my own part, I do not wish to comment further because I have not had the privilege of seeing the proposed legislation. The Minister has said that we will know the progress of the Bill after it has been to Cabinet. However, I would like to reiterate my concerns at the apparent rush of the Minister to force through this legislation, and I hope that we may have a sensible debate on this important matter. I would like to ask Minister Kelly, at a time when the continuing tragedy of Australia's unemployment has been confirmed and as there has been an exclusion of this subject from the Budget, whether any jobs will be lost as a result of her proposed endangered species legislation. There was not a mention of it in the Budget Papers, and the Budget is only six weeks old.

PARA.TAB: In the minute or two remaining at my disposal, I wish to correct some of the remarks that have been made in this debate by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). The facts on funding in the Fightback proposition as regards sport are contrary to what has been said by these two Government members in this debate. No cuts whatsoever will take place in the Federal funding through the Australian Sports Commission to Australian sporting organisations. As Fightback clearly states, that funding will be maintained in real terms. Previous speakers have said that there will be a 5 per cent cut in real terms in the Australian Sports Commission's program in the latest Budget and there is to be a $40m total cut in sports funding under the Keating Government over the next three years. This is nonsense because honourable members opposite will not be here for the next three years, but that is what they said. The blatantly political $10m a year community recreation and sporting facilities program, which is administered by the Minister herself on the basis of the political status of the electorate involved without reference to or advice from the ASC, will itself be cut.

A lot of nonsense has been spoken about what will happen with sports. Let me say to the two previous speakers from the Labor side that I have as great an interest in sport as they have. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The estimates before us for the portfolio of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories cover a wide range of subject matter, but it is subject matter that I think most Australians could have some affinity with. It is interesting that in this afternoon's debate mention has been made of the work of a range of the committees of this Parliament that have looked into subject matter under this portfolio.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) raised the issue of the report of the House of Representatives Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Biodiversity: The contribution of community-based programs. I have to agree with him that it is unfortunate that from time to time governments are not able to meet the three-month limit in replying to these reports. I serve on the Committee with the honourable member for Macquarie and can attest to the hard work that goes into putting the reports together. I think that, whatever government is in power, there needs to be a realisation that the parliamentary committee system is a way in which the community can feel that it has some contact with this Parliament and that it can put its views to the Parliament—views that perhaps will be listened to by government.

The honourable member for Macquarie mentioned that one of the recommendations of the report was a suggested increase in funding for programs such as the save the bush program. It has been our pleasure on that Committee to visit a number of projects that have been funded under that program—the one billion trees program and two other community programs that were the subject of the inquiry. Recently I was able to visit some projects in my electorate that have received funding under the save the bush program. I congratulate the Diamond Valley Council's natural environment protection panel, which received a modest grant to help it in its work this year.

The importance of these projects is that in an urban setting where there are remnants of pristine bushland we can give examples in close proximity of the work that can be achieved under these programs. On this tour I was shown two sites that contain over 40 species of native orchids. Through the funding under the save the bush program fencing will be put in to protect these areas without necessarily cutting them off from the community. The panel envisages that in the long term these areas will be used as interpretive displays to try to inform and educate the wider community about the importance of areas that people tend to regard as being roadside reserves or just another park. It is an important program that has potential for a partnership between Commonwealth, State and local governments and community non-government organisations.

The other matter that has been touched upon is sports funding, and the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) spoke about that. Honourable members will remember that he put down two reports when he was Chairman of the Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee. The Committee found that the Commonwealth had a role to fund elite sport but also to be a partner in assisting the other spheres of government in the provision of community facilities. Something like 50 per cent of people over 14 are involved in organised sport, with many more involved in an informal sense. Something like 65 per cent of the population are involved as spectators and something like 96 per cent are involved by watching sport on television. So there is great interest in sport. However, those statistics also show that about 36 per cent of school age children miss out on sport. I think we have to look at that and try to address it. Programs such as Aussie Sport and other programs that try to involve children in sport are very important.

The other area I wish to touch upon is library funding, and I shall go beyond the National Library, which has money put to it as part of these estimates. The second report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies dealing with Australia as an information society is entitled The Role of Libraries/Information Networks and was tabled in this House back in September 1991. I have to agree again with the honourable member for Macquarie that it really does nobody any credit when, some 12 months later, we are still awaiting a response to this report. A number of the issues raised in the report are important and people are interested in the Government's response.

One of the major recommendations of the report was that there should be put in place a national library policy; that the Minister should make a detailed statement to the Parliament about the adequacy of existing library and information networks in meeting Australia's information needs. The local public network system that services most of my electorate is the Yarra Plenty Regional Library Service. From the outset I have to admit that I have had some past involvement in that service. When I was first elected to this place I was the chairperson of the committee of management of that regional library service, so I am well acquainted with the work it does. In the past few years it has kept abreast of the types of things it envisages it can do to improve the service.

One of its problems at the moment is that a major part of the usage of its service is curriculum-based by primary and secondary school students, with a growing proportion by post-secondary students. A consultant's report in mid-1990 showed that curriculum-based library users accounted for approximately 48 per cent of total library users using books in the library and over 55 per cent of total inquiries in the library. That is a major portion of its business, and it is something that has to be recognised.

The report of the Long Term Strategies Committee recognised that and made a recommendation that the Commonwealth, through the Australian Education Council, encourage State governments to provide supplementary funding to public libraries to assist with the development of services provided for secondary students to compensate public libraries for the cross-subsidisation currently being provided to the education sector. The Yarra Plenty Library Service has taken that a step further. It is suggesting that the Commonwealth should pick up some of the deficiency in funding. As I have said to it, whilst I am not totally opposed to that notion, it is not something that is going to be decided in the short term. We will have to sit down and iron out what the shared responsibilities are going to be between spheres of government, and it is likely to take some time. As the Long Term Strategies Committee indicated, it will require a ministerial council of Commonwealth and State Ministers. Hopefully, such a council will recognise that local government plays a major role in the provision of public libraries and will invite local government to any discussions that are held. That is something we need to look at.

It needs to be recognised that there is great pressure on library services throughout Australia because of the inability of other spheres of government to foot the bill. Because there are curriculum-based usages of these libraries, the Commonwealth Government can show some leadership by putting in place a national library policy, even in the context of what the National Library would like with a national information policy. It has long advocated the need for a national information policy, with the library being a significant portion. I hope that in the consideration of the Long Term Strategies Committee report the Government will see its way clear to show leadership and to sit down in partnership with State and local governments and other important non-government players to see how we can improve and make more efficient the national library services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to intervene in this debate as a result of contributions made by many honourable members on the other side on the issue of the impact on sport in Australia of the coalition's Fightback plan. The argument that was reiterated, if I could be tautological, again and again was that the GST would do enormous damage to the costs of people participating in or being spectators at sports events. I thought I would take the opportunity today of making some points not just about what the coalition proposes to do—that seems to be the almost total preoccupation of honourable members on the other side of the chamber, who are supposed to be the Government of Australia, not the Opposition—but about the impact of the tax policies of those opposite on sports events.

PARA.TAB: Just over two weeks ago at the MCG in Melbourne the AFL grand final between the West Coast Eagles and Geelong was held. Having lived in Geelong for some years, I was very disappointed that Geelong lost the game. It would be argued by honourable members on the other side that the costs at that grand final were substantially less than would be the case under a coalition government with a 15 per cent GST. That is the sort of point that has been made over and again today, and I want to make a few points about that.

Those who were at the game or who watched it on television will recall that the players ran on to the ground through the inevitable banners. It is worth our while reflecting on the fact that those banners were subject to a 20 per cent sales tax. The game began with the bouncing of the ball in the middle of the ground—and the ball was subject to 20 per cent sales tax. Those are taxes that will be abolished lock, stock and barrel by the coalition. The cars, and all their parts and accessories, which were crammed into the car parks around the MCG and into the streets around there were all subject to at least 20 per cent sales tax, with the exception of those that were bought in the last few months. The walkie-talkies that the dozens of parking attendants used, and the parking tickets themselves, were taxable at 20 per cent.

When the game was actually under way we had a little bit of a pause from taxation until the game was finally completed. The trophy was given to the West Coast Eagles team—and the trophy itself was subject to a 20 per cent sales tax. I said that we went through the game without tax, but it is worth reflecting that the umpire's whistle was taxed at 20 per cent, his watch was taxed at 30 per cent, the goal umpire's flags were taxed at 20 per cent, the siren, the scoreboard, the advertising hoardings around the ground, the speakers for the national anthem, the singing and so on were all taxable at a rate of 20 per cent by the present Government. The clock that was used to keep the time during the game was subject to 30 per cent tax and, of course, the clocks that told the time around the ground were also subject to 30 per cent tax. The banners waved by the cheer squads and the posters held up by the spectators were taxable at 20 per cent. The buttons, badges and programs purchased by spectators were also subject to 20 per cent sales tax.

So to say that the abolition of that sales tax and the introduction of a 15 per cent GST would somehow make it more expensive to go to the football is, frankly, little short of risible. But it is also worth remembering that the AFL administration itself does not escape the Keating Government's sales tax rip-off. All of the AFL's office equipment—computers, paper, ink and so on—are taxable at a rate of 20 per cent. The toilets, the basins, the paper towels and dispensers that are used by the AFL are all taxable at 10 per cent or 20 per cent.

The next time honourable members look at a football game, be it an AFL final or a rugby league game, it is very important that they take into consideration the enormous range of taxes imposed by the present Keating Government on those games and that they not be continually misled by the arguments from the other side of the chamber that somehow people going to these events will be taxed under the coalition in a way that they are not taxed under Labor.

On 3 November, very soon, while we are sitting here in this Parliament, the Melbourne Cup will be under way and no doubt about 200,000 people—the honourable member for Kooyong would know a more accurate figure than that—

TALK.START.PARA: —About 100,000 will attend.

—About 100,000 people will attend the race. Again, this is going to be an absolute taxation bonanza for the present Government. Once more, it is important that people try to understand that and take it properly into account. For a start, by the time a typical racegoer gets to the race he or she will have paid one of the highest rates of income tax in the world. Although those on the other side of the chamber argue that we have a relatively low burden of tax as a proportion of GDP by OECD standards, the point of the argument is the tax mix. On the basis of the tax mix, we have around the fourth highest income tax burden of any country in the OECD. Under the coalition that income tax burden will be reduced by approximately one-third, by about 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: All those people going to the Melbourne Cup—or nearly all of them; those who are in employment and those who earn more than $5,400 a year—will get a very substantial income tax cut averaging around one-third. Of course, some people in that 100,000 or so crowd—about 8,000 of them—will not have a job; they will be unemployed, the victims of the present recession, who do not pay any income tax. Under the coalition, their Job Search allowance will be increased by 6 per cent.

As if that were not enough, as if the fourth highest rates of personal income tax in the world are not enough to penalise those who go to the Melbourne Cup on 3 November, when the hopeful racegoers climb into their cars—on which of course they will have paid at least 20 per cent sales tax, unless they bought the car in the last few months—and head off to the races, 26c in taxation to the Keating Government will be paid on every litre of petrol that they consume.

The great moment comes and they finally arrive at the races. If they have some money left after having paid the fourth highest rates of income tax in the world and sales tax on their car and fuel tax on the way to the race, they may decide that they are exhausted from this steeplechase of taxation that they have already had to get across and that they need a drink. If they buy a beer, they pay on that beer not only excise but also 20 per cent sales tax. If they buy a Coke, a Fanta, a Solo or a Sprite—the sort of drink that they might buy—they will pay 20 per cent sales tax on that. If they buy wine or champagne, as some people do at the Melbourne Cup, there will be 20 per cent sales tax on that. Those are all taxes that will be abolished lock, stock and barrel by the coalition government, the Hewson government.

If they buy a pie or a hot dog or a packet of chips, the wrappers that those things come in will be subject to 20 per cent sales tax—a 20 per cent sales tax added by the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was the Treasurer of this country. The cups that the drinks come in will be subject to sales tax, and all the confectionery that is bought at the Melbourne Cup will be subject to 20 per cent sales tax. Any pennants or banners at the racecourse will be subject to 20 per cent tax, which is passed on in terms of the entrance fee. The entrance fee will also cover a 20 per cent tax on the race club's fittings, furnishings, carpets, lighting and general accoutrements. All of these taxes will be abolished under the coalition government. On top of that, anything that is bought on that race day, if it has been produced by somebody who employs more than around 15 people, will be subject to a 6 per cent payroll tax.

So the poor racegoers will stagger back into their cars. They may have had a good day at the races, but the statistics show that they will not have had a great day in terms of winnings. They will crawl back into their cars and pay 26c a litre on every litre of fuel they consume on the way home, and simply collapse, exhausted, after a day at the Melbourne Cup, which for them will have been a sales tax steeplechase—taxes that will be totally abolished by the Hewson government and replaced by a simple and equitable GST, which makes a lot more sense, particularly when coupled with a one-third reduction in personal income tax, an 8 per cent increase in pensions and a 6 per cent increase in other benefits.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $398,611,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has become very clear to any dispassionate observer that this Government will do anything and say anything to try to hang on to office. Nowhere is that more apparent than in the area of immigration and ethnic affairs, an area in which I take a particular interest, for obvious reasons. The Government, in an attempt to discredit our Fightback approach to immigration, recently produced a further document in the series following One Nation entitled Poles Apart. We are told that this document was prepared in the political arm of the Australian Labor Party rather than on the administrative side orchestrated through the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). This document was designed to create in people's minds differences of view about the way in which the Government would handle immigration questions as against the way in which the Opposition would deal with these matters.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the particular constituency of ethnic communities within Australia, the Government was desirous of creating a view that, if the Opposition approach was followed, ethnic communities in particular would suffer great difficulty and hardship as a result of the programs we intend to put in place. We are all familiar with this approach because the Government has always resorted to blatant fearmongering in an attempt to shore up its position and to differentiate its approach from ours, particularly in relation to immigration and ethnic affairs questions. When I am not around, I know that some of the apparatchiks of the Government have been known to go into particular refugee communities and say that if a coalition were elected we would be the first people to send the refugees back. I suppose that is a play on the issues we genuinely raise in relation to the way in which the Government dealt with the Chinese students in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square event.

While the Government is trying to create a picture of difference, it is important also to understand the schizoid approach it has taken to this issue. If one follows the comments of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), one would note that his concern is that the Government has been responding to an agenda set by the Opposition and that it is modelling its approach upon the arguments the Opposition has put before the Australian people over the last several years. I shall outline some of those matters where the Government has positively picked up suggestions that have been made by the Opposition. In some cases it could do well if it were to pick up others and take them even further.

It is clear that the Government has been reducing the immigration program. It was projected last year at 118,000 gross and this year it is programmed to come in at 80,000 gross. In the context of the debate about immigration, there has been a tailing off of the program under this Government. The Government introduced an English language test in the concessional family reunion category, with a requirement that English be spoken for particular occupations. This is designed to ensure that principal applicants in the points tested categories who are working in occupations where English is critical to their employment in Australia will be proficient in English.

In the area of concessional family reunion, when I first suggested that this sort of change was important and essential if we were to target our immigration program to those people who are able to settle successfully and reasonably quickly and to limit the cost to the adult migrant education program, which at the moment is unable to cope with the large numbers of non-English speakers who wish to obtain that skill, I was roundly criticised. The Government has also moved to restrict access to benefits to new arrivals in the first six months after entry, following on our suggestion that two years ought to be an appropriate period.

Despite this convergence of views, the Opposition and the Government are still clearly poles apart, but not in the sense that the Government has put it. Clearly, the extent of Australia's economic problems imposed by this Labor Government through its management and the Keating economic policies make it imperative that the immigration program is not only reduced but reduced further than we have seen to date. It needs to be clearly focused to produce a far better outcome that reflects our national interest goals. The coalition has argued that, in past recessions of much lesser magnitude than the present recession, the immigration program fell to between 50,000 and 70,000 net, a much lower figure than is likely to be achieved under the Government's present program. The program has been kept at a much higher than expected level because the Government was reducing over time—I suspect very much in accordance with the agenda set by the honourable member for Calwell—the criteria that people needed to meet in various categories. This is particularly so in the skills categories, where the Government removed the requirement for labour market testing.

This Government also removed the requirement in the concessional family category that there be sponsorship and that families be required to support their relatives when they came to Australia. The untargeted immigration program is well documented. The Government revealed that in 1991 some $400m in benefits was paid to those people who have been here for two years or less. We have suggested that an important restriction be imposed on access to benefits, particularly for those who are sponsored or who ought to have been sponsored, as well as those in the economic categories, although we did not want to impose it in the area of refugee entry. If those elements of our Fightback package were adopted there would be very substantial savings in the order of $250m. I do not believe it is unreasonable to adopt them. The Government's adoption in part of our proposal shows that it is not an unreasonable approach to take.

It is also important to recognise that in the immigration program there is the capacity to make considerable reductions in areas in which there have been rapid increases under this Labor Government. In the area of preferential family reunion we have argued that there needs to be enhanced bona fides testing to ensure that those people who are entering Australia, particularly on the basis of spouse and de facto relationships, are doing so only for immigration purposes. We have also suggested that in the area of employment nomination there is a need for enhanced bona fides testing to ensure that the people who are nominated by employers under that program will be supported by those employers, who obtain their entry to Australia.

In the area of spouse entry we know that there are very simple suggestions that could achieve bona fides testing in a realistic and sensible way. For instance, in relation to spouses and de facto partners who obtain a grant of resident status in Australia, the Government adopted a requirement that they be in that relationship for a further two years after permission is granted for them to stay here. That is an important decision because it has had an effect upon reducing sham arrangements. There is no reasonable reason why those sorts of criteria should not be applied to those coming from offshore. The Government requires people to have been in a de facto relationship for a period of only six months in order for that relationship to be effective for migration purposes. We would lengthen that period to two years to demonstrate that a much more permanent and lasting relationship is intended before people are allowed to use it for migration purposes.

These are the sorts of changes this Government could well adopt in a realistic and sensible way if it wanted to further constrain the immigration numbers. In the area of refugee entry, we have suggested changes that could equally be made to test people's bona fides. That is a matter that ought to be addressed on another occasion in a much more detailed way. The capacity is there for considerable reductions, which the Government does not challenge in its Poles Apart document but which could well be followed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not join the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), in a debate about immigration. I wish to address my remarks to the local government allocation of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. There is no doubt that this Labor Government has a fine record in terms of its relationship with local government. It was, after all, the first government to create a separate ministry for local government. The Government sponsored the Self inquiry into the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and local government which resulted in the current system of financial assistance grants to local councils. In terms of the way in which local government deals with its funds, the Government has moved firmly down the path of allowing local councils throughout Australia to operate in a system of self-determination. There is a general move towards the untying of funds which means that local councils can make local decisions that recognise their particular circumstances. In my experience, they are best able to do this.

PARA.TAB: The Government is involved in a range of partnership relationships with local government. For instance, under the home and community care programs services such as frail aged centres, respite centres and Meals on Wheels are often run cooperatively between local councils and community groups with funding from the Commonwealth Government. A similar program exists in relation to housing and child-care.

In the area of employment, the Government has a proud history of partnership with local government. During the early 1980s there was the community employment program, commonly known as the CEP, in which local government was the major participant, and most recently in this Budget the local capital works program, which sees some $350m being allocated to local government in order to create local employment and provide much needed local infrastructure programs.

Local government is also a major participant in a range of other labour market programs and schemes such as Jobskill. Indeed, councils in my own area participate in these labour market programs. I hope we will see increasing numbers involved in the new labour market programs, such as the local environment action program, which will be up and running very shortly. Of course, local government has a major interest in the area of road funding, and the Government is again providing a large amount of money in this Budget, including an expansion of the very successful black spots program which many local councils have put to good effect.

However, there is one area where I think the Government can improve its administration of local government. I am a little concerned at the way in which local government issues take very much a back seat in relation to their linkage with immigration and ethnic affairs. I believe that local government had a higher profile when the Ministry was linked with the Department of Administrative Services under former Minister, Mr Uren, when he was in this place.

I am not being critical of local government Ministers since Mr Uren—I think they have done a fine job—but it is unfortunate that even in debates such as this the majority of speakers will canvass important immigration issues and often local government will be left on the back burner. Perhaps this does not apply to all speakers, but it is often the situation in relation to debates involving this portfolio that local government gets left out a bit. It may be worth looking at again combining local government with administrative services rather than with the immigration portfolio. I do not think there is any inherent link between local government and the administration of our immigration program that makes it essential that the two be grouped together.

The budget for local government is now in the order of $1 billion in direct Commonwealth funding. I have already mentioned the capital works program. In my local area, something like $2.2m has been allocated to the Caboolture Shire Council. That money is already in the process of being spent. Projects have been approved, including the construction of a community hall at Morayfield and a Meals on Wheels kitchen at Burpengary. Some $430,000 has been allocated to the Esk Shire Council, and that money will go to a range of projects, including the building of a sports facility at Lowood and road works within the townships of Esk, Lowood and other parts of the shire.

This debate invites us to contrast the Budget proposals of the Government with those of the Opposition as contained in the Fightback! document. Fightback would hit local government particularly hard if it were ever implemented. Most directly, under the Opposition's plans local government will suffer a 5 per cent decrease in direct grants. Almost $37m will come off the top of funding to local councils in this country. In addition, another 5 per cent will be taken off State governments, and State governments are a major source of direct funding for local government. I think it is highly likely that State governments, in turn, will pass on their share of the 5 per cent cut to local councils, so there is a double whammy there.

Indeed, the Opposition will specifically abolish programs in which local government is currently participating, such as the capital works program and the sports facilities program. Over the years a large amount of money from the latter program has gone to helping local councils build local sports facilities. There will also be a general cut in labour market programs such as Jobskill. Trainees employed by local government will be a thing of the past if the Opposition ever gets its way.

I suppose the most insidious thing local councils would have to put up with if those opposite were in government would be the 15 per cent GST on local government services. Where exactly this would hit is uncertain because the Opposition has not been able to produce a list to say which local government services will be zero rated and which ones will be deemed to be commercial and, hence, will have the 15 per cent tax imposed upon them. But it is quite clear that the cost of services such as garbage collection will be increased by a 15 per cent tax. The supply of water would most likely be considered a commercial operation, and certainly various recreational facilities such as public swimming pools would have a GST imposed on their operation and entrance fees. Public halls, ovals and things of that nature which local governments run throughout Australia would also be subject to the tax. Since we are not sure what will be subject and what will not, maybe there will be an opportunity in this debate for the Opposition to spell that out a little more clearly; it has been extremely quiet about it in the past.

What does this mean for the average ratepayer? The Brisbane City Council, which is the largest local authority in Australia, has conducted an exercise to try to calculate what the imposition of the Fightback policies will mean for its ratepayers. Its calculation is that every ratepayer in Brisbane city could expect a rate increase of some $211 annually because of the introduction of Fightback. That is an extra $200 slug which I do not think the Opposition has calculated in terms of its other proud boasts about reducing personal income taxes and other taxes. It will definitely be increasing local government taxes, rates and charges.

That is not even the end of it. How will local councils comply with the administrative burdens that will be imposed upon them? At the moment, councils are exempt from the wholesale sales tax system. If councils go out and buy fleets of motor vehicles, which most councils do, no sales tax attaches to that. Under the Opposition's proposals, councils will pay GST on the purchase of motor vehicles. They will then have to submit a form in order to try to get a rebate on the payment of that tax, provided the motor vehicle is being used for business purposes.

So a whole administrative structure will have to be set up within each of the 900-odd local authorities in Australia to claim back tax which at the moment they are not having to pay at all. It has been estimated that the initial start-up cost of putting that administrative system in place will be $10,000 or $15,000, with that sort of annual fee also being added to administration. Obviously, the larger the council and the more complicated its transactions the larger the administrative burden will be. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join in this debate. I must say that I listened with some amazement to the utter nonsense that the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) was peddling. It reinforces what my colleague the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) said a few minutes ago when he described the present Government as it goes through its last stages of the death throes and drew attention to the fact that it will do anything or say anything to try to stay in office. That view was reinforced in the speech of the honourable member for Fisher. I would have thought that someone who came into this chamber would have taken the time and trouble to do a bit of homework before he mouthed the sort of nonsense that has been mouthed in some of the statements from the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: I will speak firstly about the local government capital works program. I will refer to the extraordinary behaviour displayed by the Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons) when he clearly and deliberately misled the House. This was pointed out in a motion that was put before this chamber. I will go on to point out how the Government has failed dismally to adequately respond to the challenge that the Fightback package has put to it, particularly as it affects local government.

If we look at the local government capital works program, there is no doubt that local government has gratefully received the funding and there is no doubt that the majority of councils will use the money very effectively for what it has been designed. But the key point is: why was it necessary? If the Government had not driven us into recession—the recession that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told us we had to have—if the Government had not driven nearly one million people into unemployment, had not driven so many people into part time work when they were looking for more than that and had not driven a record number of people into bankruptcies then the question would then arise: was it necessary to bring this program in at all? While I believe that the majority of councils will use that money very effectively, the tragedy is that it was needed in the first place.

The second point I wish to raise is the extraordinary behaviour of the Minister himself when on 19 August he tabled this marvellous document which has headed `Local Capital Works Program—Notional Allocation by Federal Electorate'. The Minister put his name to it, tabled it and was forced eventually to withdraw it when he realised that if we did a bit of simple arithmetic and added up what was there we would find that, instead of some $345m, which was the Budget allocation, it came to well over $600m. He was prepared to bring this into this Parliament, table it and say, `This is the sort of thing that we ought to be proud of'.

The Prime Minister was prepared to use the figures in Question Time. When we started to look at this table we found some very interesting things. The most amazing was: guess who topped the list? It was the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), with over $20m notionally being allocated to his electorate.

But when we looked into this list further we found that there were 10 electorates in New South Wales which were notionally allocated $10m or more, and all of those just happened to be electorates of sitting Labor members. It may be a coincidence, but it was an observation that I made. When we looked at Victoria we found that there were only five who received that sort of allocation, and all bar one was a Labor electorate. When we looked at Queensland there were only two. Both of them apparently received an identical allocation—McPherson and Moncrieff—but when we looked into it we found that it was something like half that. The Minister was prepared to bring it in here and say, `Aren't I generous?'. If we look at South Australia we see that there was another seat allocated over $10m, a Labor seat. In Western Australia there were two—one Labor and one coalition. In poor old Tasmania the allocations were much less.

The point is that the Minister came in here, tried to make political capital and made a complete fool of himself. When he was asked to explain why he had misled the House he continued to claim that he had not misled the House. That was quite extraordinary. I think his exact words were, `I have not misled the House at all'. What an extraordinary thing to have to say.

With respect to the Fightback package, I think the honourable member for Fisher seems to have some difficulty in reading it, when he made statements like, `Under local government, garbage and water would have an increase of 15 per cent'. He knows, as I am sure everyone in this chamber knows, that the GST will not be put on until a number of other taxes have been removed—taxes such as sales tax, fuel tax, payroll tax and so on. He goes on to talk about what the additional costs may or may not be for people using those services and again he conveniently overlooks, as has been made very clear on many occasions, that under the Fightback package there will be significant tax cuts—major tax cuts of around 30 per cent. For pensioners and those on benefits there will be other compensation. He knows that too. I think he ought to be balanced in his assessment.

He also goes on to talk about the administrative costs that may come for local government. But local government has to claim back its sales tax. It is not as though councils are starting from scratch. If honourable members look, councils still have to claim the tax. If one looks at some of the assessments that have been made by organisations such as the Municipal Association of Victoria one will see very clearly that in its detailed assessment it does not anticipate that there will be much of an increase in the administrative burden.

The Municipal Association of Victoria has gone a lot further than that and said that it believes that on balance most councils will probably find themselves hardly affected at all. When the honourable member for Fisher talks about the 5 per cent cut he again ignores the benefits that councils will get directly—for example, the removal of fuel tax, payroll tax, training levies and so on. In other areas we will have cheaper tenders because people who tender for work now will also be getting those benefits from taking business taxes off. All of those things mean that there will be considerable benefits for local government.

It is interesting to note, when we talk about the benefits for local government, that my colleague Senator Macdonald has on a number of occasions challenged the Minister to demonstrate one council that will not be cheaper to run under a coalition government. He has put that challenge and it seems that the Minister is still unable to respond. The Government really ought to put up or shut up on that point.

To put things in perspective, between 1983 and 1992, if we look at the financial assistance grants that have been given to local government, we see that in real terms there has been a cut of 6.1 per cent under Labor. Here it is trying to criticise others. I think it ought to have a good look at its own record before it goes on. We are seeing the new fringe benefits tax arrangements which again are going to disadvantage local government. So I suggest that the Government certainly does not come to this debate with a clean pair of hands.

The confidence of local government must be sorely dented when it sees a document like this being presented by a Minister of the Federal Parliament. Simple arithmetic will show that the figures in the document do not add up. It is a document that was designed to promote the Government in the most generous way as being very helpful for local government and certainly overstating the assistance, by nearly double, that was being given to each Federal electorate. There is no doubt that local government must be sorely tempted to ask how much longer it deserves to have such a Minister.

There are many benefits that are going to come from Fightback. It is clear that local government, through organisations such as the Municipal Association of Victoria, has assessed and recognised that not only are there direct benefits but also indirect benefits for people who pay their rates and charges. They are going to be very significant and very much to their advantage. I believe that overall local government has much to look forward to under the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that in any of the committee debate on the Estimates in the last week we have heard such dribble as has just come from the mouth of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I was going to agree with a previous speaker in this debate from this side of the Committee, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), that more should be said about local government, particularly when it is associated with the division of appropriations, as it is in this debate, but I now have to put to right a number of misleading statements that have just come before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: The notional allocation by Federal electorate was clearly explained. If the honourable member for Wannon and the coalition had not been blind and had not tried to score cheap political points, they would have seen that clearly laid out in the documentation associated with the Budget Papers, and in what was circulated to those local government areas, were the reasons as to why the allocations were made in the first place, how they came about and how all of us were informed that, as the Federal electorates comprised more than one local government area, they were the total allocations of those specific electorates, not local government areas.

I have two cities in my electorate of Prospect—Fairfield city and Holroyd city. The Fairfield city area, because of its composition, its high ethnic vote, its high unemployment and its high population, received the largest allocation in Australia—over $9m, which has already been put to use. The total in those two areas came to $12m. I did not, through all of the documentation I read, come to the conclusion that one was going to get $12m and the other was going to get $12m. It was very clearly laid out. As I have said before in debate before this chamber, the Minister and his Department should be congratulated for the fairness with which the distribution of funding was made to the 400-odd councils around Australia out of 915 local government areas.

It is ludicrous to say that local government will not suffer under a GST. The coalition does not know what it is talking about if it does not believe that local government has worked out where it will be affected—only on the limited information that has been supplied to it to date, because the Opposition has not come clean about what the GST will really mean to local government in Australia and how local government will be cut.

We do know, for example, that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has stated that direct funding would be cut to local government and local government funding from the States would be cut. When we read further into the Opposition's documents, we find that funding for programs administered by local government would be cut and a number of local government activities would also be taxed. Out of this, the only conclusion we can come to is that the coalition's policies for local government are vague and its attitude towards the effect on local government of the GST is dismissive. It is describing it as merely administrative detail. I put down the challenge to Opposition members. When will their administrative detail become public knowledge? That is the question being asked by local government throughout Australia. That is what it wants to know.

A major problem for local government around Australia is the coalition's 5 per cent cut in financial assistance grants. In 1992-93 terms, that would mean a cut of $36.75m to Australia's 915 local government authorities. The smallest councils, already highly dependent on those grants from the State governments, could not absorb this type of cut. They certainly could not look to the States for help because the States, we have also been informed, would lose 5 per cent in general purpose grants under a coalition government if ever it were to get into power. In other words, over $750m in today's dollars would be cut from the States. If services do not have to be cut, where will the money come from to assist local government? The Opposition would say that many out of the diverse range of Commonwealth programs that are now feeding into local government should be cut, including the Australia Council, the better cities program and, as has already been mentioned by the honourable member for Fisher, the sports assistance program.

The Opposition has also informed us that it would axe the local government capital works program announced in the 1992 Budget which, as I have just reiterated, helped so many of those councils which are suffering at the moment from very high unemployment. It is not, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition, giving people shovels and lining them up in local councils just to do mickey mouse jobs. I believe that the Leader of the Opposition, in his comment on that type of program, and the Opposition are insulting local government and the many Australians who certainly will benefit from that program which is now in place. As I mentioned, the two councils in my electorate have received something like $12m under that local capital works program, which is helping them to pay for capital works that their communities have needed but which they have not had the financial capacity to see implemented.

As a result of this Budget funding, local authorities in my electorate have the benefit of a new and expanded program to help them get their communities working. The local capital works program is providing an immediate, one-off boost to the Prospect electorate, and particularly to the Fairfield region, which, I admit, unfortunately has experienced above average unemployment. The grants which are funding capital works are putting cash into our local economies, creating jobs and, most importantly, building confidence.

Fairfield city has something like 20 projects approved for funding. These projects, which include the construction of an aquatic centre in Prairiewood, the extension of the Whitlam Library and the upgrading of various sporting and recreation facilities, costing $12.5m, received $9.2m in Federal funding and the rest was supplied by the council through its own revenues. The approved list of projects is very well balanced. It covers a range of different functions, including public works, parks and gardens, and recreational and community services.

I believe that Fairfield City Council and its staff should be congratulated on their efforts in organising and compiling the submission for funding. They did it swiftly and with a great deal of commonsense. The cooperation and enthusiasm that this Federal Government program has been met with is extremely encouraging, and I appreciate the opportunities given to me by the Council for consultation on the submissions.

Coming back to the GST, the Leader of the Opposition, as we have just been informed, would eliminate the wholesale sales tax. The abolition of the wholesale sales tax would not help local government because it is already wholesale sales tax exempt. This means that the effect of the GST would be particularly harsh on councils. For example, at present local councils buy motor vehicles without sales tax and they usually have a fleet owner discount. Councillors are aware that the motor vehicles are quite cheap and the trade-in is then taken into account. This would change with the introduction of the GST. While the regulatory and non-commercial activities of local authorities would be zero rated, all activities that qualify as commercial under the Opposition's very liberal definition would be subject to the 15 per cent GST—another 15 per cent slug to the ratepayers. Again, the Opposition will not come clean on this subject. How can we be fully informed and have a fully informed debate on the matter?

There have been suggestions from the Opposition's own committee on GST implementation issues that, like New Zealand, it would end up as a 15 per cent Federal double tax on rates. I suggest that honourable members read the Australian Financial Review of 1 September 1992. The commercial activities of councils certainly would be taxed. This Opposition members admit. I would like them to define `commercial activities' as to whether they include garbage collection and disposal; the supply of water, gas and electricity; swimming pools and the price of going into them; recreational activities; public transport; transport of goods; provision and control of caravan parks, aerodromes, child-care; parking; and agricultural and forestry undertakings.

Some organisations have made calculations which should sound warning bells for all of us. The Commonwealth Office of Local Government found that the greatest impact would be in country areas where councils have a very limited income base. The Office estimates that increases in average rates in New South Wales could be as high as $134 in Armidale, on top of what people already pay now, and $106 in Albury. The honourable member for Fisher has already stated what the Brisbane City Council had calculated would happen if it had a consumption tax. It would add something like $211 to a Brisbane ratepayer's total bill at the moment. This did not even take into account the Opposition's proposed cut to financial assistance grants.

In States where rate pegging applies, such as New South Wales, councils are not likely to be able to fund the GST-related cost increases through their rate collections. They would have to cut, or charge more for, the services they now provide.
