Many Sydney councils, for example, have already increased charges for facilities that should be available at an affordable cost to the community. For example, hall rentals would increase under the coalition's GST. Local communities running a hall for the councils would need to levy a GST and organise all the paperwork required. The GST would also treat the majority of non-profit bodies, such as elderly citizens clubs, sporting clubs and community hall committees, as commercial activities. The impact of treating non-profit community activities as commercial activities is not explained in Fightback and obviously requires further study. Again, we wait for the information.

Local government coordinates and funds many community activities. Every community group would need to keep detailed records of all GST paid on inputs—in other words, supplies. Forms would have to be completed to pay GST or to gain a credit and subsequent refund. The treasurer would need to become an accountant. Either members of the elderly citizens clubs would pay a membership fee increase of 15 per cent plus compliance costs or local government would be asked for increased grants. Ultimately, the whole community would pay and continue to pay. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised that the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) has the record for quorums being called on her; quite frankly, a quorum would have relieved us from some of the rubbish we have heard today.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order! I suggest to the honourable member for Ballarat that it is not in his best interests to call a quorum on himself by drawing attention to the state of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am again grateful to you, Mr Scholes, for your comments from the chair. As far as the honourable member for Prospect is concerned, she really ought to look at what has been said about local government and the GST. I will not take up my speech, though, by telling her what the Municipal Association of Victoria has said, but I suggest that she have a look at who is telling the truth about local government, Fightback and the GST.

PARA.TAB: I want to address today a number of matters in relation to this allocation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I would first of all like to thank a few members of the Whichway Ballarat Committee. You probably know some of these people, Mr Scholes. They were in Canberra on 9 September and met with a large number of Ministers and shadow Ministers. That group was made up of the present Mayor, Councillor James Coghlan; Mr Brian Nunn, who is the Chairman of the Ballarat Regional Board; Mr David Peile, who is the Chief Executive Officer of the city of Ballarat; Mr David Miller, who is on the Ballarat Regional Board; Graeme Shearer, who would be known to you, Mr Scholes, from the trades hall in Ballarat; Mr Frank Sheehan, the former member for Ballarat East; and Mr Ian Brain from the Brotherhood of St Laurence.

This is a group of local government representatives, under the auspices of the Ballarat Regional Board, who are not about handouts but are about doing something themselves. They came to Canberra and put it to the Ministers and the shadow Ministers that Ballarat needed some assistance. They were not looking for handouts; they wanted to work with government to ensure that the diabolical situation that is presently facing Ballarat is addressed as a matter of urgency.

On the September unemployment figures, there are 7,290 people in Ballarat who are in receipt of unemployment benefits—that is, 7,290 people who are former breadwinners; 7,290 people who are family men and women; 7,290 people who are not being given a fair go by this Government. The Whichway Ballarat Committee is seeking to address those matters.

There was some mention after the Budget about the impact of the local capital works program. Indeed, I put out a press release welcoming the fact that money had been put into the Ballarat region. But I also said that there are other regions, including Geelong, which have seemed to receive extraordinary sums of money compared with the amount received by the Ballarat region. I am sure that even you, Mr Scholes, as a defender of Geelong—and also the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur)—would have to admit that the problems being faced in your region are diabolical but that they are no greater or lesser than those in the Federal seat of Ballarat.

The funding amounts are quite extraordinary. Funding for the Ballarat region was some $3 1/2m, but funding for the Geelong region was over $7m. The Ballarat Regional Board has looked into this matter and it has a large number of concerns. I am not saying that we in the Ballarat region are not happy with the money we got—because we are; we are very happy for any assistance—but we do not believe we are being properly treated in relation to this program. I can see no good reason why Geelong and Bendigo should have received the sums of money they did when the region of Ballarat, which is probably suffering more than those two regions, received half the funding.

The issues that have been raised by the Regional Board are as follows. First, the DEET estimate of the labour force for the Ballarat region shows a sharp decline over the four quarters from the September quarter 1991. Was this to correct an earlier statistical error? Second, the estimated levels of unemployment for Ballarat municipalities are much lower than local evidence, such as CES registrations or Ballarat University College survey results, would suggest. Is the DEET methodology at fault? Third, the somewhat arbitrary way that municipalities have been grouped to form OLG regions may have caused Ballarat to miss out on category 1 funding even though the local unemployment rate is consistently above the national rate. If, for example, Ararat City and Ararat Shire were included in the Ballarat region, the average labour force would have exceeded 60,000 and Ballarat would have qualified for category 1 funding.

Fourth, the larger size—that is, in terms of the number of municipalities—of the Bendigo and Shepparton regions made them more likely to become category 1 regions and receive higher levels of funding. Fifth, individual municipalities within category 1 regions received capital works funding, even when the unemployment rate within those municipalities was below the national rate. Yet municipalities such as Ararat missed out on receiving any funds. Sixth, despite having an unemployment rate at the June 1992 quarter of 24 per cent, Maryborough received only category 2 funding because it was part of the Ballarat region. Had Maryborough been grouped with the Bendigo region, the city would have attracted category 1 funding.

Seventh, funding allocations should have been made to individual municipalities on the basis of the numbers of unemployed within each municipality. By allocating the largest proportion of funding in the first instance to regions, the Government has not ensured the funds are being equitably directed to where they are most needed. Eighth, has the Ballarat region therefore missed out on more than $1m worth of additional capital works funding as a result of the arbitrariness of the allocation process?

They are matters raised by the Ballarat Regional Board, but there are also serious matters raised by the Shire of Stawell and the City of Stawell. That area received no funding at all. A meeting of a large number of municipalities was held in the city of Horsham on 8 September, and they were extremely aggrieved that there was no funding given to them at all. On behalf of those municipalities, I urge the Government to look at other areas to address the very real concerns they have.

I invite the chamber to look at the effect of a different tax on local government—the fringe benefits tax—in the recently announced Budget. Let us not hear all this waffle from people such as the honourable member for Prospect about the effect of a GST on local government when we see what this Budget has done, in terms of financial penalties, to local government.

Moving on to immigration, I got the Parliamentary Library to look at the figures for New Zealand born settlers arriving in Australia. It is pretty interesting to see how the Kiwis are voting with their feet. In 1987, 15,360 New Zealand born settlers arrived in Australia; in 1988, 24,870; in 1989, 17,340; in 1990, 8,970; and in 1991, 6,730. I can see that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), is looking incredulous. He may well do, because the Kiwis are now seeing the results of the intestinal fortitude that the Labour Party and then the National Party had in relation to the New Zealand economy. Do not ever forget that it was a Labour Party, a Labour Government, that introduced what we are going to introduce into this country. It gets worse. I will quote from an article about what Heinz has announced in relation to Wattie's. The article states:
Heinz's announcement suggests it will focus its Asian export efforts through Wattie's low-cost operations rather than through its Australian offshoot . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It continues in the next paragraph:

PARA.TAB: The chairman of Heinz, Dr Tony O'Reilly, said, "Wattie's will provide Heinz with an exciting opportunity to expand its presence significantly in Australasia, Japan and the rest of the region, a market with substantial growth potential.

"New Zealand will be a major manufacturing base in the growing Asia-Pacific market. In addition, the New Zealand economy has benefited greatly from Government policies that have encouraged free trade and low-cost operator status over the past five years.

SPEECH.PARA: New Zealand is getting what we should be getting because it has had the guts to go ahead and make the changes, the changes that were introduced by a Labour Party and then were followed on by the National Party. We will lose out to the Kiwis. We can see they are not coming to Australia in the same numbers now because they know darned well that they would be coming into a situation far worse than that which they find in their own country. I bet we will find those numbers dropping off. If we do not follow the lead of the Kiwis, we will go further down the tube.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking this evening on the portfolio of immigration, local government and ethnic affairs, I would like to expand on some comments I made the other day in relation to the report entitled Australia's refugee and humanitarian system: Achieving a balance between refugee and control, which was tabled earlier this year. A refugee crisis of proportions not seen since World War II has been developing on a global scale. Today there are 17 1/2 million refugees and asylum seekers in different parts of the world. One of the most devastating crises the world has seen in recent times is the crisis in the former Federation of Yugoslavia, which has produced 1.3 million refugees and displaced persons. I have recently experienced this traumatic event at first hand, and I will comment on that later.

PARA.TAB: Australia first took part in refugee resettlement in the 1920s. Before the Second World War Australia admitted approximately 7,000 persons displaced as a result of developments in Germany and German-occupied territories. However, it was not until the post-war period that Australia began to play a significant role in refugee settlement programs. Australia joined the International Refugee Organisation in 1947 and has since accepted around 350,000 refugees from other parts of the world, including South East Asia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Lebanon and Sri Lanka.

Australia, like many other receiving nations, is today confronted with complex issues arising from the refugee crisis. One of the key issues is how best to respond to the worldwide refugee crisis while at the same time maintaining a tight and non-discriminatory immigration policy. Today I will mention some of the recommendations made in the report produced in August by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. I believe that these recommendations would facilitate a better approach to Australia's refugee and immigration policy and should be given urgent consideration for adoption by the Government. The report, which took two years to complete, has generated much interest and has been generally received as a well-balanced and constructive document.

The report recognises that a balance needs to be struck between the best humanitarian outcome for asylum seekers and the need to ensure that Australia maintains control over its procedures and systems for admission of refugees. The report is the most comprehensive assessment ever undertaken of the refugee situation in Australia, focussing on all issues concerning asylum seekers. Asylum seekers are persons who seek refuge at Australia's borders and persons who are temporary residents or illegal entrants seeking asylum in Australia. One of the most contentious issues arising from the report is the outstanding question of People's Republic of China nationals arriving in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre. In my speech to this chamber on immigration on 5 May this year I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in June 1989, 20,000 Chinese students in Australia were given four-year temporary visas to remain. This decision to grant those visas was virtually a unilateral decision of an emotionally influenced Prime Minister who, in one fell swoop, corrupted the immigration program of this country . . . this year about 14,000 dependants are expected to join the students in Australia . . . Of course, social security and other benefits were extended as a consequence . . . Prime Minister Keating has compounded the original emotion-ridden decision of Prime Minister Hawke to destroy the equity, credibility and morality of Australia's refugee and humanitarian program . . .

The majority of the Committee members supported the view of the coalition on this matter and urged reconsideration of the Federal Government's undertaking given by former Prime Minister Hawke in 1990 and restated by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) earlier this year. The coalition supports the move for Chinese nationals to test their claims for residency against normal selection criteria when their special visas expire in June 1994. This view is given support in the following extract from the report:

The policy . . . has contributed significantly to the immense burden which has been placed on Australia's refugee determination system over the past three years . . . It has resulted in many thousands more Chinese arriving in Australia after the Tiananmen Square incident without appropriate bona fide checks. The decision to grant a four year permit to Chinese students has produced community resentment, particularly among groups like the Sri Lankans, Lebanese and Cambodians, who have at least as good if not better claims to protection . . .

The coalition position supports consistent and principled decision making. The same criteria should apply to all refugees from all parts of the world. It was also decided that a situation where some refugees had attained a quasi-guest worker status had to be avoided. A quasi-permanent class would not give right to all entitlements to benefits accessible to Australian citizens, no matter how long they lived here. It would create problems already evident in other countries where these arrangements are presently undertaken, such as Germany.

PARA.TAB: Germany has been quick to respond positively and in a humane way to the refugee crisis in the former Yugoslav Federation and eastern Europe. However, along with enormous economic problems, Germany is facing a massive crisis, with around 800,000 refugee claimants from 1990 to 1992 arriving in an almost uncontrolled fashion. Many of these refugees are fleeing from the war in the former Federation of Yugoslavia—from Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina and elsewhere where there is conflict. Having just arrived back from a very brief visit to the war-torn capital of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Sarajevo, and having seen the dreadful conditions experienced by people in that city and understanding some of the conditions being faced by those affected by fighting in other parts of the country, I can well understand the immense pain and suffering and fear that is being endured by the population.

The Committee in its report has recognised that priority should be given to those in greatest humanitarian need. Australia's offshore humanitarian program is evidence of this commitment. One of the most important concessions offered by Australia as part of this program is the so-called Yugoslav concession, which has been of considerable benefit and support to people who have been seriously and directly affected by the conflict in the former Federation of Yugoslavia. The spirit of this commitment is reflected in the Committee's recommendation that the policy of giving short term extensions of temporary stay to particular groups in humanitarian need be continued.

The Committee recommended that short term extensions of stay not only should be given to individuals in a class or group affected by civil disorder, but also should be considered for individuals in groups whose homes or livelihoods have been affected adversely by a major natural disaster. It is also recommended that in cases where an extension or repeated extensions of stay in excess of one year have been given, before any further permit extension is granted the applicants ought to be expected to show not only that they are citizens of the country affected by the civil strife or natural disaster but additionally that their homes, livelihood or families are in areas affected by the conflict or disaster, or that they would be required to return to the area affected by the disorder or disaster if returned home. This is very important. While offering support to refugees, this recommendation is consistent with ensuring that asylum is provided for those deemed in need of assistance. Once conditions improve for the refugees, appropriate measures would be taken to return them to a hopefully safer environment in their home country.

One of the most significant aspects of refugee claimants in Western countries such as Australia is that these countries are both the first and last asylum. Australia as a developed nation cannot look to other nations for assistance in meeting refugee demands. It is therefore vitally important that all immigration processes are sharpened to ensure that swifter and more efficient procedures are established. As immigration law expert David Martin stated in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: If (government officials) are blocked from developing swifter and more efficient procedures, or from systematic implementation of negative decisions (for example, because of effective, if short-sighted, refugee advocacy or judicial intervention), all signs point toward a proliferation of barriers and obstacles,—which are much harder for activists and judges to affect. This is not in the best interests of refugee and asylum seekers. . .

The Committee recognises in the report that relevant Commonwealth departments, such as the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department, should monitor overseas experiences in dealing with large scale movements by refugee claimants. The message that is coming through is that monitoring of refugee movements worldwide is essential. Australia is participating in a cooperative global initiative and therefore has to be informed and aware of the collective international implications of these refugee crises. To sum up, I believe that the Committee has made some very sound recommendations that should be taken on board immediately. What is certain is that the refugee crisis is an international problem that will continue up to the turn of the century and beyond.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not intend to discuss the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill at any length. We accept the Government's proposition and we wish it godspeed, so I will yield sooner rather than later to my good friend the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes).

—I wish to make a few remarks on the appropriations for the Parliament. I think it is fair to say that the amount of funds appropriated to the Parliament over the period I have been here has probably quadrupled in real terms; it might even have increased by a greater amount than that. That is largely because the Parliament has changed and it undertakes a far broader range of functions. But what I want to deal with more is whether or not the Parliament has itself been prepared to make the necessary adjustments to carry out the business which it now is required to carry out.

PARA.TAB: In my estimation, the Bills that go through this Parliament now—the amount of legislation—are far more numerous and far more complex than in 1967. It affects and touches almost the total range of aspects of our community. Many aspects were not legislated for anywhere in 1967; others were largely the province of the States or were substantially looked after by the community as a whole. The Parliament has not given itself the necessary procedures and processes which would enable it to carry out that amount of business. On an estimate that I made recently for another purpose, it would seem that in the first 70 years of this Parliament the House met on more days of the year than it passed major pieces of legislation; and I count group legislation in that. It now passes about one Bill for every hour of sitting time which is devoted to government business. That is not sufficient time to provide scrutiny; it is not sufficient time to actively involve the House of Representatives in the procedures of governing this country and the decision making processes which it is responsible for.

From my experience, the Cabinet, the Executive—which is a function of the Crown, not the Parliament—has also streamlined, if that is the word, its procedures, so that the ERC probably has had more say in the final shape of this Budget which we are passing tonight than has the Cabinet itself. The House of Representatives rubber stamps the Cabinet decision and the Cabinet rubber stamps the ERC decision. That may well be good for government. It may well be the way in which Executives have to operate. The Parliament has certain specific responsibilities. I want to make a plea for something I have been trying to get people to take up for the last 15 years, that is, enabling the Parliament to carry out its duties. If more legislation is brought into the Parliament than the Parliament can deal with, and that has been true at least since 1972, then the Parliament will truncate its proceedings because the Government program will be met—it does not matter who is in government—and therefore the House will abdicate its responsibilities or concede its responsibilities to the Executive.

There are means by which, without sitting for hundreds of days—which is one of the alternatives—and continuing to use the 1900 practices, which we are still using in this chamber, that we could give a lot more time to the legislative process and the examination of Budgets. A government has a majority in this House; otherwise it is not a government. So the House is not going to go through a process of some sort of independent assessment, no matter who is in government; but it does have a responsibility to look at and to examine Budgets.

What I have proposed on a number of occasions, and I think we have reached the stage where we either do it or we stop going through the pretence of dealing with legislation—which is what we do on many occasions—is to use what many other organisations, including parliaments elsewhere in the world, have been forced to use, which is to allow the Parliament to function as a plenary and a committee body whereby a committee of the House, consisting of less than the total number of members and able to meet concurrently with other committees, can deal with legislation, statements and other matters that it is felt should be examined and in which members have an interest.

A committee sitting in this chamber on Wednesday afternoon—I use that only as an example—after Question Time, the House having dissolved into committee, could do exactly the same business, with properly framed Standing Orders, as the House itself does. At the same time, at least two other similar committees could meet in committee rooms of this House, which we now have, and treble the time available for debate on that one day. Using only one day we could double the sitting times available to this House.

The problem that we have is that it is convenient to keep going the way we are, and we will do so until we reach the stage where we will be merely standing up and moving that Bills be passed, and members will be coming to Canberra for the sole purpose of being here, but taking little or no part in the procedures.

We pass a lot of legislation and spend a lot of money on the Parliament. It is not too difficult a task—indeed it would relieve a lot of responsibility from the front bench on both sides—to adopt that sort of procedure. That would also make room, because the time would then become available, for the House to have genuine debates. There have been about half a dozen good debates that honourable members can remember in the last four or five years. A censure motion now goes usually for two or three speakers. Without having a shot at anyone, because we behaved the same when we were on the other side of the House, I have to say that censure motions tend to become less and less important in the procedures and more and more a vehicle to initiate debate. But there was a time when they were debated all day. There was a time when, when such a motion was moved, the Prime Minister used to adjourn the House until the next day of sitting. That certainly made them important. But the House no longer has that luxury. Debates on the economy should take place in this House, and they should take place regularly. The last time that we had a genuine debate on defence or foreign affairs is almost beyond living memory, with the exception of the Gulf war debate, which was a good debate. Honourable members contributed to that debate and showed that they can contribute when the opportunity is there.

It is now some five years since the Procedure Committee of this House was set up to examine the Standing Orders of the House. None of the significant reports of that Committee are embodied completely in the Standing Orders. In fact, the committee system under which we are now completing our second parliament still operates under a sessional order. I have to say that the members and the Chairman of that Committee over a period of time have faced great frustration. We can spend hours going through Standing Orders, which is not the most exuberant occupation, then make a report to the Parliament, only to find that the parliament expires, the next parliament expires, and the next parliament expires, and it is still not debated.

I do not want to go any further on this but I want to make the plea that at some stage—in the next parliament; not this one, I presume—we look at the way the House does business. I will not be here, but the House has to look at the way that it does business, and it has to change the 1900 methods that it uses, or else find a means by which it gives up pretending to pass legislation which in fact it does not pass.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 is to remove uncertainties about the enforcement of laws concerning truth in labelling of Australian wine. In 1989 legislation to implement a wine label integrity program was carried in this House with the support of the coalition parties. The program was developed at industry request and required wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety and region of origin of the wine. These records were required to be made available for audit upon request by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The first inspections were in the Clare Valley in South Australia in 1990, and no breaches were detected. However, over 200 audits have revealed certain technical deficiencies which make enforcement of the legislation difficult. The first is that, whilst the Act requires that records be kept, there is no requirement that these records be accurate and complete. The second is that the manufacturer must provide the records even if they are self-incriminating, but the manufacturer is then protected from prosecution should the records disclose false labelling. There is therefore doubt as to whether a successful prosecution concerning false labelling could be launched under the present Act.

This Bill attempts to overcome these problems. There are four aspects to the legislation. First, it makes it an offence to knowingly or recklessly fail to make and keep such records, or to make and keep false, misleading or incomplete records. Secondly, it amends the section which requires a person to provide information to the Corporation on request, but indemnifies that person from prosecution where such information is furnished. The amendment removes the label integrity program provisions from section 42 but otherwise leaves the section unchanged.

Thirdly, it allows a person, with reasonable excuse, to refuse a request from the Corporation to provide records. It would be a reasonable excuse if the records were self-incriminating. Where a person chooses, with reasonable excuse, not to provide the records, the Corporation must obtain a warrant to obtain the records. This would allow those records to initiate a prosecution, thus achieving the original intention of the legislation.

The Bill also enables the Corporation to retain records for 60 days or, if a prosecution for a label offence is initiated within 60 days, until proceedings and appeals are ended. A person will be able to inspect or copy the records given to the Corporation.

Finally, the Bill honours a commitment that the Government made to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to enable a person to copy evidence seized by an inspector and it reduces the period of validity of an offence warrant from one month to a maximum of seven days.

The coalition supports this legislation. I believe it indicates one of the very positive features of the Australian wine industry. Our wine industry is one of the great success stories of Australian industry at present. It does not matter whether one sees it as a primary industry, a manufacturing industry or one marketing a product. On behalf of the coalition parties I want to congratulate everybody associated with this very great industry in this country because it epitomises growth, and geographic and varietal diversity. Not only is production increasing but, because of where it is located in many different areas of Australia, it is providing some interesting developments and differences in variety and type of wine produced. The wine industry obviously has quality control as a high priority; hence this legislation. It is one of our best examples of value adding of a primary product. It is also one of the best examples of a growth industry for exports.

There is a lesson for some other industries in relation to the organisation of the industry. In 1990 the Winemakers Federation of Australia came into being to bring together three different industry organisations. They now cover 95 per cent of production. As a result, the industry is now able to speak out on different issues of concern. Obviously, like any other industry, it has concerns. I quote from the 1990-91 report of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, which highlights the damage being done to the industry by invisible taxes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Taxation on domestic production bleeds into export costs as input items are inflated through a whole range of invisible taxes.

PARA.TAB: The impact of these invisible taxes should not be underestimated and have been estimated as high as 30 per cent of all taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: In that report the industry made the point that one of its major challenges for the future and its ability to grow and prosper is to tackle issues such as taxation that will affect our capacity to remain internationally competitive. This, of course, is where the coalition's Fightback policy comes in. In a number of discussions with the industry, it has been very positive in relation to the impact of Fightback. Input taxes are removed under Fightback. As the industry indicated, there are many taxes that are more or less hidden at present, but they are there nevertheless. These taxes are removed under Fightback, which means that the industry can be more internationally competitive.

PARA.TAB: As production increases and the percentage of exports increases, that international competition requirement increases also, particularly where the Australian industry is competing against other countries which already have similar tax incentives. I think of New Zealand and France as two examples where, by having a GST or VAT system, those input taxes are removed. Of course, for exports the GST or VAT is fully rebated, and that is a very significant factor when one looks at the competitive situation of different countries and export markets.

At present there are hidden export taxes on our wine, as there are on every other export from Australia. That has been calculated as equivalent to a 5 per cent export tax. Senator Button has been quoted a few times today in this place, but to my knowledge he has never withdrawn his comment where, through his Department, he acknowledged that there is this export tax, which has been calculated by Treasury at $1.8 billion per year. The French, the New Zealanders and others that have this system and where those inputs are rebated at the point of export have a considerable advantage over our wine exporters. That is one of the reasons why the wine industry is enthusiastic about Fightback.

Last year the industry exported $234m worth of wine, which is a tenfold increase in six years. After something of a false start a few years ago, this export growth is very soundly based. It is anticipated that by the year 2000 the industry could be one of our major export earners, with $1 billion a year in export income for Australia. To achieve the growth that is necessary, more than $1 billion of investment will be required for vineyards, wineries, et cetera. One has to acknowledge that a number of those wineries are having cash flow problems. It is certainly not an easy industry for many individuals or companies at present.

One of the other important features of the industry is that it is value adding to an excellent degree and in a logical and natural way. In a recent article by Andrew Clark in the Australian Financial Review, referring to developments in the industry in Europe he made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian wine export story is a successful grafting of old-fashioned business values with hi-tech.

He also said that Australian wine is achieving a real premium on the British market because, while it only has 2.7 per cent in volume in that market, it has 12 per cent of wine costing more than $12.50 per bottle. The industry has a far better percentage in relation to the quality section of the market than the volume section, and that is what value adding is about. One can look at other markets where the Australian wine industry is increasing not only its volume of exports but also the value of those exports to an even greater degree. This comes back to the importance of quality control, with value adding, with brand marketing, and with responsibility for individual labels. That is why this legislation is being supported.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the wine industry does provide some very good lessons for other sections of the broader horticultural industry, where there is not the same reliability and quality with exports and there is not always an ability to value add. I take `value adding' to mean not just further processing but obtaining as high a price as possible for the raw product by gaining a premium for quality. Not all of those industries are as world competitive as the wine industry obviously is, from its record in exports and against some fairly fierce import competition. The coalition parties support the legislation and wish the wine industry a very successful and expanding future, not just in Australia but as one of the major export industries for this country in the coming years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1992, which seeks to remove some technical problems with the provisions of the Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 and to strengthen the laws covering truth in labelling of our wines. These are essential for the successful marketing of our product overseas. They may seem minor changes, but we will all recall the recent incidents in European countries where all kinds of substances found their way into wine bottles, to the disadvantage of those producing the wine. This may seem an extreme example, but it is pretty crucial that we maintain the confidence of overseas markets in the quality and integrity of our product. I note that this Bill enjoys the strong support of the major wine industry body, the Winemakers Federation of Australia. I am pleased to note the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd) in support of the thrust of this amendment, although, since he made some critical comments about the present taxation regime, as is the custom in this House I will have to reciprocate with a few remarks about the Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: The wine industry is just one of the success stories of Australia's manufacturing renaissance under the present Government. It is one of South Australia's key rural industries. We in South Australia have some major winegrowing areas in the Barossa and Clare valleys, in the Coonawarra in the State's south-east, at McLaren Vale just south of Adelaide, and in the Riverland, which is a major wine grape producer. The Adelaide Hills and Langhorne Creek are smaller producing areas but their wines are of no less quality for that. Many wine companies have their headquarters in my electorate, and I am pleased to see them there.

Although the industry is important in its own right, it also contributes significantly to South Australia's attraction as a tourist destination. The individual wineries have cellar-door tasting for the general public, which always makes for a pleasant afternoon and is busily patronised. Each of the major regions has good accommodation and fine restaurants which together contribute to a fine-living ambience that is attracting increasing numbers to South Australia and the tourism industry.

All of these regions stage regular gourmet festivals when famous Adelaide restaurants—and of course our restaurants also win many prizes—move for a weekend or perhaps slightly longer to temporary facilities at the wineries. The public is encouraged to move around and sample the different foods and wines that are available. I am hoping that plans presently being unveiled for a new international standard resort at the Barossa Valley will soon be finalised and that overseas visitors will come in greater numbers to enjoy these festivals. You will note, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Pheasant Farm in the middle of the Barossa always features very highly in the awarding of prizes for restaurants in Australia, and justly so.

Our wine industry is world class and highly competitive. Its 97 per cent share of the Australian market represents a substantial turnaround from our position only 10 years ago when—it is very hard to believe; when researching this speech I was surprised when reminded of it—Australia was a net importer of wine. We are now a net exporter, with overseas sales accounting for 20 per cent of total production, and we have increased from negligible levels of just a few years ago to 77.6 million litres, which is worth $234m in 1991-92. The industry is now confident of achieving exports of wine worth $1 billion by the turn of the century and, given the burgeoning markets of well-off, well-earning middle-class people in the Asian economies to our north, as their consumption habits shift a bit more in our direction this is a very realistic goal.

I add in passing that wine is an example of how our country has been helped by the immigration program of the last few decades. This industry has been substantially boosted in postwar years by the large number of continental European migrants who brought with them an established wine culture. Wolf Blass, whose headquarters are right in the middle of the central business district of Adelaide, is perhaps the best known of them. After the 1960s, as this culture struck firm roots, production shifted away from the old fortified wines such as port and sherry, which we had been traditionally used to, to table wines, which have now proven much more successful in the penetration of overseas markets.

The wine industry is a good example of what this Federal Government is attempting to achieve with other rural industries. Because of the policies of former coalition governments, too many of the Australian primary industries were in the business of merely exporting raw products—grains, sugar, wool, iron ore, coal and natural gas. Because these are being transformed to finished products overseas, the returns to Australia in terms of value added have been limited. Our failure to add value in the past and its legacy have been a cause of our recent current account deficit problems.

We will go a long way to eliminating this current account deficit if we can emulate the wine industry more widely. This wine industry is the result of various stages of production that are carried out in Australia—crushing, distilling, blending, packaging and so on—which add approximately seven times the farm gate value of the raw material to the finished product. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to imagine what the effect would be of adding seven times the value of the entire primary export crop of this country right across the board. Basically, in the wine industry this means that wages are paid to 10,000 Australian workers, $1.2 billion worth of sales to Australian retailers are cashed up, transport costs are paid to Australian transport companies, the costs of packaging materials are paid to Australian packagers, and also $400m worth of Commonwealth and State taxes are derived from the industry. This can be reinvested in our domestic economy in various ways and needs to be in capital equipment, building and financial services.

As in other industries that have been successful recently in breaking into overseas markets and lifting their export volumes, the Federal Government can claim at least some part in the success story of the wine industry as a result of the assistance that has been provided. I hasten to add that the bulk of the success story is attributable to the wine industry itself, but we have tried in our own way to provide assistance. In the five years to 1991, when exports from this industry had their exponential growth of more than 20 per cent per annum, the Australia Wine and Brandy Corporation and individual wine exporters received more than $20m in export market development grants, and more will follow as a result of the liberalisation of the eligibility for this scheme that was announced in this year's Budget.

The industry has also received grants worth more than $500,000 under the marketing skills program and the innovative agricultural marketing program, as well as more than $1m each year in research and development grants. In fact, the wine industry is seen by the Government as being so important that it has supported the establishment of a cooperative research centre for viticulture which will be funded to the tune of $14m over the next seven years.

The Government has tried to apply the same philosophy to the wine-making industry as it has to other industries. We have had a good look at the industry, made an assessment of the opportunities the industry says are available, and tried to respond to its needs by supplementing and assisting it with an intelligent package of measures suited to that industry, driven not by ideology or by the stated needs of the industry but by policy objectives on a national level supplementing what the industry requires. This is called government intervention, and in this industry it has been pretty successful.

I am optimistic that a similar policy process can be developed with respect to other agricultural industries in this country with a view to producing processed food for export, particularly into Asia where the booming market provides plenty of opportunities for the import of processed food products from Australia. I think the opportunities are unlimited, but we will need considerable imagination to transform an agricultural primary producing base which has traditionally oriented itself towards the European market and culture to one which is oriented towards the growing and newly developing taste style of east Asia. But if we do not do that the industry will fade.

The industry competes with French exports. This is difficult, but not because the French have a GST. The French have a GST because they could not collect any tax from their farmers. The farmers would not pay income tax because if one asked them what their income was they would say `Zilch; zero'. Since tax could not be collected from them in the form of income—which they claimed not to have—it had to be collected in the form of expenditure, which no-one thought was a good idea but it was the only way to do it.

Having introduced it in France, when the European Community was formed it had to be introduced into every other country, including Germany, otherwise the other countries would have different tax collecting and, therefore, different economic structures. So in order to unify and make uniform the tax collecting system of the European Community—at that stage six countries—everybody got lumbered with a GST that was developed for the French farmers who had no income. There are now 14 countries in western Europe and other countries—one is New Zealand—applying this tax, although there was no need to apply it in the first place since they did not have an extensive peasant farming community that refused to pay income tax. But I digress.

The reason for the success of French exports was initially that their wine enjoyed considerable reputation due to marketing and its quality over a period of years. We found it difficult to compete with them, that is true. But the important reason these days is that they are heavily subsidised, which we do not propose to do. However, we do propose to assist in the development of export markets.

The Federal Opposition—since the Deputy Leader of the National Party said something about our taxation policy, it would be churlish of me not to reciprocate—has proposed a rather different orientation towards industry policy in this sector and in the wine industry. As in other sectors and so in the wine industry, the Fightback policy is rather one of leave it and let it die: if it cannot survive without government assistance, then it should not survive at all. I note that the Opposition's then spokesman on trade, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), foreshadowed in 1990 the elimination by 1995 of the export market development scheme and others like it—which, as I have pointed out, assisted the wine industry considerably in breaking into foreign markets. This is somewhat surprising, given that the electorate of Mayo contains some significant wine growing areas. Some of them are extremely quality oriented in their production. But perhaps the winemakers of the Adelaide Hills and Langhorne Creek were unaware of that posture.

I might also point out that the Cooperative Research Centre for Viticulture would likewise appear at risk under the Fightback package. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), the shadow Minister for science and technology, is of the view that the CRCs are of questionable value. He also has the research and development project in his sights and wants to reduce this by $100m a year by dropping the concession from a 150 per cent to a 125 per cent write-off. The wine research would suffer proportionately.

The wine industry will be offered two separate packages at the next election, each having a different orientation. It has seen the success under ours. If it wants to, it can take its chances under the Opposition's.

Finally, I might add in this context that I recently attended the national conference of the Australian Winemakers Federation, held in the foothills of Adelaide in an extraordinarily pleasant old winery which had been converted to a dining room. The major discussion that was held during and shortly after lunch was a panel discussion of whether the industry could export $1 billion worth of product by year 2000.

I was extraordinarily impressed with the detail and sophistication of the discussion which followed. This was not at an abstract or theoretical level but was at a very particular level and was extraordinarily detailed. The members broke down the rate of growth that would be required to be sustained over the next eight years, the rate of market penetration of which varieties of wine at which prices, and approximated the market growth in Europe, Asia, Africa and elsewhere. The discussion was very lively and, as is their want, was quite colourful.

The general agreement seemed to be that we would need about $1.2 billion worth of investment in the industry to achieve a billion dollars per annum exports of wine by year 2000, and that these investments would need to be made in approximately these proportions: about $600m in new land brought into the industry; about $460m in inventory; and $120m in new equipment. They raised some of the problems which the Deputy Leader of the National Party referred to about raising this cash, which would be difficult to generate within the industry itself.

They would probably be looking for large investors, possibly banks, but more likely the large insurance funds which are coming onto the market in this country, as the means of raising the investment required. In addition, they thought that the old stocks of vines would need to be grafted with new varietals. I noted that the six largest wineries would need, as they do now, to do most of the exporting, but they felt that the smaller quality exporters would still need to get into the marketplace in order to enhance the reputation of Australian wines as a whole.

In general, they felt that the industry enjoyed natural advantages of having extensive land and a pollution free product. Because of the high research and technology levels, which Australia is acknowledged so widely throughout the world as possessing, they felt that we should engage in the export of technology. During the conference, I was contemplating how many industries in this country actually export their technology. Acknowledging that it is in the forefront of the industry on a worldwide basis, I could not come up with too many others. Certainly, that is the way that the winemakers see it.

There was even discussion around the table at which I was sitting about whether there ought to be some check on the export of this technology which was enabling the foreigners to catch up rather quickly. So I will draw this to the attention of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free), as he is in the House. The general feeling was that $1 billion worth of product exported by year 2000 was an achievable goal which could be mapped, as progress was made towards it, and be realistically achieved.

I happily note that in this objective South Australia and its quality wineries around the metropolitan area of Adelaide, and also the bulk producing area of the Riverland, will play a huge—and I hope a disproportionately huger—role over the next decade. In other words, this industry is a credit to both Australia and to the proportion of it which exists in South Australia, the State from which I am a representative. I commend to this House this amendment which will assist that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to support this amendment, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1992, and to support the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, and also the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley). I was interested in what the honourable member for Adelaide had to say about the GST. I found his explanation for the existence of a consumption tax in Europe very interesting, to say the least. I knew the French farmers were powerful, but I did not know that they were so powerful that they could affect the whole of Europe in the way that they were taxed. Needless to say, the wine grape growers and the winemakers, particularly those who are interested in export, would greatly welcome, and welcome with open arms, the introduction of the GST, because it would take a tremendous amount of tax off their production and also off their export sales.

PARA.TAB: In 1989 legislation was passed to implement a wine label integrity program. This was done with coalition support. The program was developed at industry request and required wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety and region of origin of the wine. These records must be made available for audit upon request by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation.

Two hundred audits have shown that there were technical deficiencies, which have made the enforcement of legislation difficult. This Act, which we are speaking about tonight, helps to overcome this problem, as other members have already stated in the House.

As honourable members would know, anything that assists the integrity of our wine industry is of the utmost importance. According to the industry funded Wine Export Council, Australian wine producers—and the honourable member for Adelaide has already touched on this—can expect to boost export sales from the current $234m to $1 billion by the year 2000. That is an extraordinary increase. It helps our balance of payments figures and is wonderful for those people who are in the wine industry, and for the Treasury of Australia and Australia generally.

Overseas sales have increased seven-fold since 1986. That is remarkable in itself. This has been due to a massive marketing effort which has seen sales surge in the British, Swedish and United States markets. Not only has the volume of sales of wines increased, but the wines have gained international recognition.

This year we are running significantly ahead of last year's impressive record. Our wines are internationally respected and recognised. We are also known as the lowest cost producer of varietal table wines in the world. One of the greatest assets, and this relates to the quality and labelling, is the cleanliness of the Australian product. Mention has already been made here of how free of pollution this nation is, particularly in its agricultural and horticultural areas. If I may be parochial in relation to the Riverina, because that is what I would like to speak about tonight, I will inform the House of the implementation of a low chemical grape and wine production called Riverina Clean. I do not know whether honourable members are aware that the Riverina is the second largest wine region in Australia. It is certainly the largest in New South Wales. I think a lot of people, when they talk about wines, tend to forget the Riverina. We produce 66 per cent of Australia's semillon, 20 per cent of its shiraz, and 20 per cent of the total wine output of Australia.

In the Riverina we have a hot, dry area which has to be irrigated. There is a low disease risk. There are low levels of artificial inputs, especially fungicides. Local growers are encouraged to control and monitor the use of chemical inputs in grapes and wine. The first crop to be used in the vintage—of course, there have been trials—will be available as Riverina Clean in 1993.

People might ask, `Why is the Riverina noted for its wine? Why is it that the Riverina grows grapes to produce wine?'. In the Riverina, our major resource is our people. We have people from diverse European cultures. We have Italians with their horticultural skills and we have the Australian resourcefulness. This has benefited viticulture and oenology. The stable climate, modern wineries and the varietal wine plantings give the region national and international success. As I said before, 66 per cent is semillon. We also have sufficient plantings for shiraz, colombard and gewurtztraminer wines. They are full-bodied, ripe, and are moderate in their alcohol content.

Probably the most famous wines produced in the Riverina today, because of the mild, humid, warm autumns, are the botrytis wines. These are formed by the infection of the botrytis. This increases the sugar to extraordinary levels and it gets its own distinctive—and as we call it—`noble' flavour and aroma. Since 1982 botrytis semillon has been recognised as one of the best sweet wines of the world. Five countries—France, Germany, Hungary, Austria and Australia—produce this type of wine.

One of the wines that stand out is the DeBortoli wine, but DeBortoli is not the only winery in the Riverina. It is interesting to note that most of the wineries are family-owned concerns. We have Cranswick Smith, DeBortoli, LillyPilly, the famous McWilliams, Miranda Wines, Riverina Wines, Rossetto Wines, Toorak Wines, West End Wines and Wilton Estates. Many people say, `We didn't know that the Riverina produced wines'. While we are talking about the Riverina, it is interesting to note that Henry Lawson worked in Leeton in 1916. This is what he said about the Riverina:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a spread of green, all chequered off, with little homes, and trees, and clear, green fringed canals and channels—just like English brooks—set in the midst of a bare, scorching, dusty red and parched yellow Dead Land that's a lot older than Egypt.

There is no problem in placing a DeBortoli sauterne alongside Penfolds grange hermitage, the great north-eastern Victorian fortified muscats and tokays, the 20-year-old Lindemans semillons, the similarly aged Leo Buring Rhine rieslings, and the best Petaluma chardonnays as Australia's greatest wine styles. I am very proud to stand here in the Parliament and say that these wines of the Riverina are equal to the world's best. I spoke earlier about the need to have a clean product. I was concerned the other day to receive a letter from the CSIRO which said:

You may have seen or heard recent media reports to the effect that CSIRO's Division of Entomology is in financial crisis and proposes to close several programs and declare up to 35 of its staff redundant so that the Divisional budget can be balanced within the next three years.

We know that there have been cutbacks all over the place because of the recession we are facing and the problems our economy is now attempting to overcome, but I think it is very foolish to cut research and development, particularly in this area. The horticultural industry spends millions of dollars every year on chemicals to control insect pests such as codling moth, oriental fruit moth, budworms and other leaf rollers. Failure to use chemicals results in infested fruit which is unmarketable. Market demands plus environmental concerns mean that it is necessary to reduce pesticide usage urgently, including in wine grapes. Some growers are already attempting to do this. For instance, the Apple and Pear Growers Association has been a leader in the push to find alternatives to pesticides. As I said earlier, in the Riverina we are trying to produce `Riverina fresh' with reduced pesticides and reduced chemicals in winemaking.

PARA.TAB: Scientists have responded to the need for alternative control methods by looking closely at nature to find ways to control pests. One of the most promising areas of research has been the study of pheromones—natural secretions of female moths which are used for communication. The idea is to use synthetic pheromones to mix the signals produced by females and therefore disrupt mating. The method is clean, green and plays a key role in alternative pest control technology. It can be used in conjunction with other forms of biological control such as insect growth regulators or biological control agents to keep the number of pests down using reduced amounts of or no chemicals. Research has reached the point where already one form of pheromone, Isomate M, has been commercialised by the Australian company Biocontrol Ltd and is available to farmers. Isomate M is a pheromone dispenser system developed from CSIRO research that is used against oriental fruit moth in peach orchards in Australia, the USA and France.

My plea here tonight is to ask the Government, and of course the leaders of the CSIRO, to think very seriously about this funding cutback. I am not sure whether honourable members are aware that Australian scientists are leaders in this pheromone technology research. As I have said, one company has already taken up the cudgels to produce pheromone and export it. Honourable members can imagine the great benefit it has in saving insecticides, in confusing these insect pests and in making a much better product that is much cheaper and much cleaner. This refers not only to the apple and pear industry—the pome fruits—but also to the grape industry, and I believe there is some research going on in the sugar industry. I believe that pheromone is limitless in its possibilities for the control of insect pests.

As I said before, I have risen to support this amendment to the Act. I reiterate the importance, as other members have, of the wine industry to Australia, what a successful industry it is, and what great work people in that industry are doing for our export industries and for the welfare of people in the different areas of Australia who grow grapes for the production of wine.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be opposing the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill 1992. The Bill amends the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991 to include as a schedule to the Act the agreement made on 11 May this year between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and a number of Premiers and Chief Ministers. It follows the agreement made between the Premiers and Chief Ministers at the Adelaide conference from which the former Prime Minister was excluded.

PARA.TAB: At present, the functions of the National Road Transport Commission relate to obtaining uniformity in road transport; that is, it applies only to those vehicles over 4 1/2 tonnes, which are known as heavy vehicles. Its functions include seeking uniform legislation, road charges and road user charges, principles for determining road charges and road use charges, and guidelines for the preparation of regulatory impact statements.

The additional functions that have been conferred on the Commission by the agreement in May include the extension of the Commission's functions to light vehicles, that is, those under 4 1/2 tonnes, the assembly and publication of information on road-related charges applying to light vehicles, the assistance in developing indicators for assessing the performance of the road system and matters related to that performance—for example, are our road constructors efficient?—the assembly and publication of information on road safety, and the monitoring of the use of alternative fuels.

The functions of the National Road Transport Commission are not to be extended to road charges or economic regulation of the transport industry in this area. It is clear that the Government did not want to lose its influence over the taxation of motorists, and I think this highlights the basic flaw in the Government's approach to this whole matter. It is clear that the Government has not been serious about getting as close as possible to the ideal charging system.

It is clear that the Government was not prepared to sacrifice its milch powers over road users in order to achieve the most appropriate road transport reform. It is clear, because of this, that the charging regime recommended by the National Road Transport Commission for heavy vehicles is not the best possible because of the constraints that the Government placed on the Commission. I quote from the April 1992 Discussion Paper on Heavy Vehicle Charges put out by the National Road Transport Commission. When the NRTC was talking about sales tax, an area that the Government was not too keen to have publicised, the Commission, to its credit, made the following observation:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence on the relative level of sales tax payed by the road transport industry was discussed in Section 3.4. Based on that evidence, the Commission considers that the amounts payed are excessive, especially given the "intermediate good" nature of road transport. Further, the level of sales tax has either been reduced, or a reduction is under active consideration, for many other areas of industry in general.

To the credit of the NRTC, it was prepared to put this into the public debate. It shows very clearly that the Government is not serious about getting the costs of transport down. It highlights, of course, the benefits under the Fightback package where in fact we address that very point.

PARA.TAB: I will go on with the NRTC's recommendations. Given the problems that I have already highlighted, it is worth observing that in its road user charge the Government has highlighted the fact that the 18c a litre is a notional charge, which really means it is a bit illusionary and is not related to anything as far as road construction or road spending is concerned. We could go so far as to say that the figure does not do a lot other than give the Government a warm inner glow.

I want to make it clear that I am not criticising the work of the National Road Transport Commission, but the Government is using the NRTC and is not really serious about addressing the whole problem of road funding. As I have said, it has highlighted the 18c a litre notional charge, and yet this will not be given to roads. It is, in other words, just another general revenue tax.

Furthermore, it is worth noting that the Government has said that it will continue to index the tax component. That means that the notional 8c a litre could become 16c a litre within a few short years, given Labor's record in this area. Of course, if Labor were around for long enough—and I am sure that the good people of Australia will realise that that is not in their best interests—it could mean that road transport operators would be paying up to 34c per litre to the Government every time they filled up their trucks. Yet on present indications, only about 5c of that would go back to roads. It is clear that as long as the Government can continue to use road users as a source of general revenue by having only a notional charge, then an adequate level of road funding cannot be assured.

I think it is worth noting that the Government really has an appalling record on road funding. For all its years in office, bar 1992-93, road funding has fallen dramatically in real terms. This is despite the huge increases of around 150 per cent in the revenue gained through fuel excise. The $2 billion roads program—of which $600m was announced in February and $1.4 billion was announced late in July in the annual Budget allocation—means that the Government has belatedly acknowledged that our roads are sorely in need of an additional injection of funds.

But this funding only brings us back to the level of where we were a decade ago. There has been a decade of neglect under the Labor Party. I think all of us know of many examples of that. One has only to drive around any part of the country to see that roads which seven or eight years ago were in quite good condition are today becoming increasingly rough. In fact, a number of councils have been forced to rip up sealed roads because they can no longer afford to maintain that asset.
