PARA.TAB: Of course, these figures that the Treasury did in its analysis were considered rather conservative by the industry. In fact, some in the industry suggest that the savings under the Fightback package could be up to double those cited. That is a very significant boost to the nation through getting the cost of transport down. It is not just for heavy vehicles or trucks; we will also have big savings for motorists. As all honourable members must be aware by now, we are talking about 19c a litre, or around $11 every time a motorist fills up an average family car.

I think the important point to note about the NRTC is that it is seen as an independent body, but it has been given a flawed charter within which to work. Nonetheless, it has done its best, given those limitations. The coalition intends to do the proper job and give the NRTC a clean slate to deal with; in other words, it will remove all these taxes and then ask the NRTC to do its job properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are passing the buck.

—We intend to reduce the cost of doing business in this country. Part of this reduction in costs will arise because we will greatly reduce the cost of transport in this country. In answer to the interjection from the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), I say that we want to have an independent body with which the industry can work, and we want to get the politics out of it. I know that is embarrassing for the Minister because he loves going out and cutting ribbons and announcing new road projects, particularly with all his friends.
—I have had a lot of practice.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! Both the Minister and the shadow Minister will address the Chair, not each other.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important point to recognise is that we are dedicated to getting the cost of transport down. We recognise that this is a very large country, that we are more dependent on transport than almost any other country, particularly given the size of our population and that, therefore, we must have the most cost efficient and best transport system that we can have. As we all know, transport is a major part of our daily lives. It impacts on us every day. Getting that cost down is so important. That is why the Fightback package goes out of its way to get the taxes off road transport, which is something that the Government would do well to emulate.

PARA.TAB: More importantly, we have also made it very clear that we will return all revenue raised from road user charges. This is something that the Government still fails to understand. As I have pointed out, the Government has made a notional allocation out of its current fuel tax, and it is nothing more than notional. It is not dedicated to roads. I believe that it is just a way of easing the Government's conscience to make it look as though it is doing something. It continues to refuse to return that revenue to roads. I believe that the NRTC itself is less than flattering in some of its comments on the Government's approach.

The coalition is very determined to get the politics out of roads, as I said before. We want to get the politics out and allow the road needs to be assessed on an ongoing and stable basis so that we can allow some real planning for the future instead of turning the tap on and off, as the Government has done. We have seen the run-down over the last few years and then a sudden rush of blood in February. Those opposite say, `We must be seen to be doing something so we'll have a big spend up'. This stop-start nature not only means that we are not getting the best decisions being made; we are also not getting the best value for money. Anyone who is involved in road construction will say that it is continuity that allows the real economies to be made. If we have this stop-start approach, often the equipment that is being applied is not necessarily the best and often, with some spending programs, there is a rush to be seen to be doing something and, therefore, the money is not always spent in the most effective and efficient manner.

I think it is also important to note, in the context of the broader agenda of micro-economic reform, that the labour market reform, which will be so important for the future of this country over the next decade, will yield very significant benefits to the road transport industry as a whole when we have a change of government. There is no doubt that, given more flexible working hours, we will be able to reduce the congestion in our cities. I believe this in itself will save not only time for the people doing business but also a lot of fuel. If we can reduce congestion, obviously we can reduce the amount of fuel, and that in itself will help to reduce some of the pollution that occurs in our cities.

I also believe that this policy will create an expansion of the economy which will lead to more business for road transport. Again, we will be making a positive contribution to dealing with some of the problems facing this nation. Clearly, there are some significant savings to be made by improving the efficiency of road construction and road maintenance. The coalition is committed to getting these efficiency gains, and our agenda, as has been pointed out so clearly, will help achieve this very point.

So the coalition is not opposing this Bill, but we do have a very different approach to the whole question of road transport. I believe it is a very much superior approach to that of the Government. But the most important and overriding factor is that we are really on about getting the cost of transport down in this nation, and getting it down significantly. It is only by doing that that we can help to improve the wealth generation, which we all know is so desperately needed in order to create new jobs for so many people who have lost them. I believe that the coalition has a vastly superior policy. It is one of which all members on this side of the House are very proud. It is one that will certainly offer Australia a much better future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in this debate. I am also pleased to take part in this debate. I was quite interested in some of the comments of the honourable member for Wannon. He said that the Opposition wants a cost effective transport system and that it will have real road planning. But I wonder how it will do that. We heard much about the taxes that were to be taken off and how much the price of fuel was going to come down. We heard a comment about the road user charge, but we are yet to see the documentation to find out what the real amount of road user charges will be.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Wannon said that the Opposition was looking for an ideal charging mechanism. We would like to know what this ideal charging mechanism is in the Opposition's view. It most certainly is not mentioned in Fightback. Why will members of the Opposition not say what the road user charge will be for heavy vehicles? I heard the honourable member for Wannon say that the Opposition was interested in more business for road transport. That is okay. But I think, if we are going to talk about an integrated transport system in Australia, perhaps we should be looking to take some of the heavy vehicles off our roads and have more heavy freight transported by rail rather than always putting it on the road.

We hear many things in this chamber. Sometimes we are really amazed and sometimes we think we are in a different country from the speaker. I heard the honourable member make the comment that this Government had an appalling record on road funding. I could not believe it. I guess we all get a little parochial, and I can talk only about the area I represent. When I first came to this Parliament, with the advent of the Labor Government—and I drive to and from Canberra—I would drive my car to Canberra, as you would too, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you drive to Canberra, and I would have to trundle through Mittagong, competing with the heavy vehicles; through Berrima, where there was an accident two or three times a week; through Goulburn, where there is a heavy vehicle every 60 seconds, as the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) keeps quoting; along the Federal Highway to Canberra, where I would get behind trucks.

What has happened now? I drove down here this morning. Mittagong is bypassed, and the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) was up there opening the bypass the other week; Berrima was bypassed a couple of years back; and the Goulburn bypass will be opened by Christmas. Further south, the Cullerin Range deviation will be opened in the not too distant future. So where is this appalling record? Certainly, in my electorate it is not an appalling record. When I go around Australia on parliamentary duties I see fine roads, especially the national highway. I am always amazed at this story that councils are ripping up roads, and the funding is not Federal funding to start with. The Opposition can never say which councils are ripping up roads. The honourable member for Wannon could not say that this evening.

We are pleased that the Opposition is not opposing the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill. There is not a lot that it could oppose in it because this Bill amends the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991 and gives effect to the light vehicles agreement formulated at the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in May 1992. The agreement involves a regime for vehicles weighing 4.5 tonnes or less, their drivers, other road users and related matters. This will expand the powers and functions of the National Road Transport Commission to include regulation of all motorised vehicles and not just those vehicles weighing more than 4.5 tonnes. In addition, the Commission shall exercise responsibility for policy development for light vehicles, excluding the determination of charges.

The National Road Transport Commission was formally established at the beginning of this year. Anyone concerned with transport in Australia would understand how it was hailed as a major step towards achieving fundamental and lasting reforms of road transport—reforms that would benefit all Australians as a result of a more efficient road transport industry sector. For the economic well-being of this country, it is essential that Australia has a proper transport infrastructure. This should cover not only roads but also rail, air and sea. We often see projects come on without an adequate transport infrastructure. I know in the Illawarra area a few years back that the coal loader there was built without an adequate transport network, neither road nor rail. We have suffered ever since. I believe it is essential that we have an adequate transport network in this country.

In the past, our road transport has been governed by a myriad of different regulations, including the basics of travel rules, regulations and laws. How many people have driven interstate and been faced with confusing and potentially dangerous situations of when to give way, when to turn to the right, or who has the right of way? Small things in themselves, but potentially very dangerous—especially to a confused driver in a different State.

The management and development of the regulations covering light vehicles has meant duplication of work amongst States. The National Road Transport Commission will play a significant role in facilitating and ensuring continued cooperation amongst the States and Territories to reach a solution to these problems. It will create the basis for a nationally consistent legislative framework which will streamline administration processes in government bureaucracies across the country.

There are clearly benefits in a consistent national approach to roadworthiness, standards for all vehicles and the administration of these standards. A truly national registration scheme would also facilitate exchange of information on defective vehicles. When we are talking about defective vehicles, I am always reminded of the very bad bus accident in southern New South Wales a few years ago. This bus had been passed as roadworthy in South Australia; at that time it did not meet the standards in New South Wales. Many times in the past a truck or bus in one State would be passed as roadworthy and be free to travel anywhere in Australia. Indeed, some drivers or owners of buses and trucks would have their vehicles registered in a particular State because they knew that it was easier to get it registered there than in another State. As has been shown, not only were they potentially dangerous; they were dangerous.

There would also be safety benefits in achieving consistent traffic regulations for all vehicles covering road rules, signing and speed limits. Consistent registration and regulation systems and procedures would also facilitate checks on stolen vehicles. We all know how important this is because stolen vehicles in Australia cost this country millions of dollars a year. Anything that can at least trace these vehicles is to be applauded.

Australian governments have made considerable investment of taxpayers' funds in roads, especially this Labor Government which I believe has a record second to none in the amount of funds allocated to roads. But this investment, or the asset from the investment, requires constant maintenance and upgrading. An important function of the Commission will be to assist in the development of indicators that can provide better ways of assessing how we, as a nation, are coping with this task.

The Commission will collect and publish information on important issues affecting road transport. Information will be assembled and published on a comparative assessment of the performance of road authorities and systems. This will assist all levels of government by providing a better, more balanced view on delivery of road funding programs.

As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, chaired by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), looking at the efficiency of the road construction and maintenance industry, I know how important this is. Over the last year we have spoken with many road authorities and appreciate how important and beneficial this monitoring process will be in giving us the best return for the taxpayers' dollar.

I must say that this is an aspect that worries me considerably about the Opposition's proposal on its goods and services as it applies to road transport. Members of the Opposition are boasting that they will cut the cost of fuel, but nowhere have they indicated to anyone's satisfaction how roads will be funded. There is, of course, the hidden tax—the $6 billion hole in the Opposition's Fightback program. To continue road funding and maintenance at its current level—a level that members of the Opposition are always criticising is not enough—they would have to slug road users massively on road user charges. They do not say how much it will be, but it will be anything between $17,000 and $30,000.

The honourable member for Wannon produced a table this evening. It did not show what the road user tax would be on these trucks and it did not show the increased car registration which, in most States, would be more than double. A person will pay more than double for car registration and will be hit with a road user tax. It is no good arguing against that. Those opposite could not achieve the funding for roads that we are achieving today without a massive road user charge.

It is all very well for those opposite to come in here and say that they will abolish seven taxes. A couple of them are State taxes and a couple of them are taxes which do not even apply to road users. They are not saying, and they must come clean on this, how much they are going to hit the motorists of Australia, the trucking industry of Australia. It surprises me that the honourable member for Wannon has spoken about this matter this evening. Why has the trucking industry not embraced the Opposition's proposal? The reason is that the trucking industry is terrified. If the honourable member for Wannon does not believe that the trucking industry is terrified, I invite him to come down to the Illawarra, talk to any of the coal truck owner drivers, explain to them about the road user charge and defend the drivers down there. Kenworth drivers will pay an additional $30,000 a year. Others will pay from $17,000 to $30,000 a year. I invite anyone from the Opposition to come to the Illawarra, but especially the honourable member for Wannon. I will line up the Kenworth owners and he can explain to them where they will find the additional $30,000 that they will have to pay in road user charges.

An important role for the Commission will be to monitor the use of alternative fuels—something that we have not done enough of in this country—and publish information on road safety. Successful and lasting reforms which will facilitate a better, more efficient road transport environment have been a priority for this Government. The expansion of the terms of reference of the Commission to include light vehicles is certain to bring benefit to all Australians. I have much pleasure in commending this Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that Australia is a nation on wheels. When we go on the roads today and see the increase in the traffic, we realise how important it is to have efficient road transport and that our roads are good. This will certainly be reflected in the economy of the nation and it will certainly be reflected in the safety of the people who are travelling on the roads. Australia is a country divided into States. Each State has its own responsibility with regard to registration and traffic rules generally and road taxes of certain kinds. I know that as Australia has grown the Minister and, I assume, the State transport Ministers have seen the opportunity to bring about uniformity and recognised that there should be uniformity between the States and the Commonwealth in many aspects of road transport and passenger services.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a very large continent, and perhaps we have done particularly well in building a national highway around the country and in regard to our other arterial roads and our rural and urban road systems generally. It has been very important that this be achieved. Because we are a nation on wheels, we depend greatly on efficient transport. As we are being squeezed in terms of our competitiveness with the rest of the world we are realising more and more that we have to be efficient, we have to tighten up and we have to have some uniformity throughout Australia. That is why the Opposition supports the National Road Transport Commission Amendment Bill. There is much that we can say about it because it is very important. The bottom line is that we need better roads—we all know this—and a more efficient transport system generally.

One of the important factors that we have to keep in mind is road safety. There has not been a lot said in the debate so far concerning road safety and the confusion that can occur when crossing the border from one State to another because the rules in one State are different from the rules in the State that one has just left. One has to be conversant with those rules and know which are applicable to the State in which one is travelling, and one has to know the rules of the road generally.

Road safety is a very important factor. Too many people are dying on our roads. It concerns me that many people die not on the most dangerous sections or the black spots—as the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) would explain, he is providing specific finance for some of these areas of our highways and arterial roads—but on the straight stretches. I wonder whether our driving rules and the training and experience that our drivers have, particularly the young people, are sufficient for the modern requirements of this country.

In other parts of the world, in Europe, England and the United States of America, we find that older countries that have much more transport than we do and many more vehicles on their roads perhaps have better drivers. Now that we have a uniformity between the States and the Commonwealth is involved, I hope that the Commission will look very closely at teaching our people to drive properly.

Many Australians who are getting on in years have never driven a motor car. When someone's husband dies and a vehicle remains in the garage, the wife he leaves behind may be afraid to use the vehicle because she has never had to drive. Such people are frightened and nervous of going out on the road. They are nervous because of the accidents and near accidents which occur on the roads around our countryside. I hope that greater emphasis will be placed on learning to drive and that more stringent requirements will be imposed to make people aware that they are not the only ones on the road; that there are others around the corner, on their right or their left, of whom they must be very careful indeed. I hope those two factors of road safety and driver training will be addressed further in the future. I trust that this will be a requirement of the Commission once it gets into operation.

Licensing, regulations and advice on the funding of roads are covered in the Bill. I wonder how this will be done. We do not want a duplication of what we have at present. As the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), said earlier this evening, roads are a political thing. We cannot afford to have them too political. We need an independent body that recognises where our future lies. We need better roads such as the Pacific Highway, which we know will be extended over the years to come. We need a body which plans adequately for the future.

I am not fully conversant at the moment with what is occurring between the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Communications and the State traffic authorities and as to how far their planning for the future goes. I hope that these things can be addressed and that we do not get a duplication; that our National Road Transport Commission does not take the form of a great big bureaucracy. We must be very careful of this. I see that the Ministers involved will have to meet at least once a year and will keep a close eye under the legislation on the expenditure and the operations of the Commission.

I want to say something about road building, which I believe is very important. As one who travels country roads quite a deal, I feel that insufficient research has been done into the proper way to build a road. Having served on a local council with a good engineer, I know the value of a good engineer to a council. He can build a road: this is the important thing. That might seem a simple thing to do, but it is not easy to get the aggregate for the road and see that it is spread out properly, to see that the drainage is right, to ensure that the camber is correct and to see that the road is safe generally. I do not think sufficient research is undertaken even now to ensure that our roads are built properly.

As I said earlier, a lot of work is being done on the Pacific Highway. Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I am sure that you would agree with me that much of that work is being done very quickly by private contractors. There are various sections which cannot always be seen from the existing highway because they are in the bush on the sides. Many of the turns and so forth are being cut out, which is great to see. The area between Nabiac and Taree is a typical example. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know that section of the road as you have been to see it.

Great savings can be achieved if more road works can be let out to private enterprise. State road traffic authorities—and I see them in operation in various parts of the States—receive a certain amount of money per year. They do not like to put staff off. In addition, we see valuable machinery sitting at the sides of roads not being used. This country cannot afford this. We have to be efficient. The Government is trying to build up efficiency and we in the Opposition support it in this regard. As I said earlier, to make this country competitive, we must be efficient in getting our goods to the wharves and from there overseas to the markets for which our farmers and industries are producing. We have to pay even more attention than we are now to letting our works out to private contractors to get the job done quickly, and we should encourage local government bodies to do the same thing in their bridge work and their kerbing and guttering work, as is being done in the telecommunications area.

We will find otherwise that a road traffic authority or the Department of Main Roads, or whatever it happens to be that is receiving a certain amount of money, will want to keep its plant there and its staff engaged. It will therefore spread that out over a period. I might be wrong; I have not got the evidence. I make that comment only because of what I have seen on the sides of the roads, but it irks me tremendously when I see valuable plant sitting idle and not being worked.

The other day I asked one of the contractors on the job doing major work how things were going. He said that they were doing quite all right but that, as contractors doing a job, they were often held up because of the supervision they have from the State authorities. Everything has to be tested. They have to wait for somebody to make a decision. It is often hard—I am sure the Minister finds this at times—to get a person who is sitting in an office to go out and do a test and to make a decision and say, `This is what we intend to do'. These are all factors that I believe must be addressed if we are going to get value for the dollar we spend on the roads. That is important because it is intermingled with the general economy of the country, and I want to stress those points.

I ask the Minister, when he is responding, to advise whether we can assume that this will not affect the toll road systems. If the States want to continue on, even with uniformity, are they free to do this? Will they also be free to impose their own petrol tax? If we happen to get into government, they will not have to do so, and I think that will happen. Perhaps the Minister will not have to answer that because it is a foregone conclusion. But these are things people will ask me, and I think they are important.

Generally, I think the legislation is in order, as long as it does its job effectively and as long as we can teach people to drive better, to give them greater safety upon the road, and build better roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief contribution in support of this amendment to the Act and, in doing so, to express my congratulations to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), for the way he has been able to progress the reform of the road structure through the establishment of the National Road Transport Commission, moving it a step forward through this amendment tonight. I also want to talk more broadly about the formation of the National Rail Corporation, which is integral to the role of road and rail.

PARA.TAB: I was delighted to hear the contribution of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), which I think was totally in accord with the Government's view. However, in the last minute or so of his speech I think he let the cat out of the bag. He is widely respected in the Opposition ranks as an expert in road funding, and I distinctly heard him ask the Minister if it would be on for private toll roads to charge their own petrol tax. He did not mean to say petrol tax; he meant to say road user charge. This is going to be a key point of the whole debate, so I thank the honourable member for Lyne for letting the cat out of the bag and revealing just that little bit more about the plan to make up for the lost petrol tax.

The Minister will have picked up that the honourable member for Lyne mentioned significant contracting out to the private sector for the construction of roads. This all leads us to more and more private roads, privately constructed and privately owned. Now we are starting to hear about privately charged petrol tax. I want to come back to that, but I do not want to lose my train of thought. I am a little excited about this point because I think it could take us somewhere.

I started by mentioning the Road Transport Commission and the National Rail Corporation. I do not think anyone in this place should lose sight of the magnitude of the reforms that are reflected. We hear the Opposition talk frequently about the problems on Australia's waterfront, never acknowledging that over 20 years manpower on the waterfront has been reduced from 27,000 to 2,700. When the Industry Commission—God bless its soul—did an assessment of efficiency problems in the Australian economy, it also determined that the waterfront reforms that were needed in capital equipment, plant, layout and manpower issues cost the economy $1 billion per annum. That is the worth of fixing up the waterfront, and this Government recognises that and has moved on it.

The same Industry Commission has determined that the road-rail imbalance and the misuse of resources are worth something in the vicinity of $6 billion to $8 billion per annum. It is not nearly as sexy and it is not an issue that Opposition members wander around talking about. All they ever want to say out in the country is, `We need more road funds'. They have never addressed the fact that it is six times the problem of the waterfront.

Turning to that imbalance between road and rail, to put it in very simple terms, it has never made sense to have 2,000 trucks, day and night, going up and down the Hume Highway between Melbourne and Sydney parallel to the standard gauge railway line and competing with rail for freight. It has never made sense for one single truck to haul a load across the Nullarbor when one train is equivalent to 90 or 100 trucks. That kind of imbalance between long distance and short distance transport is what a lot of these reforms have been about, and dramatic progress is being made in tackling that $6 billion to $8 billion problem.

In the process, through the Premiers Conference agreement, for the first time in the history of this nation the States have come to accept that the Federal Government should take up the role of coordinating these activities. The formation of the National Road Transport Commission last year was the major step in setting the road transport process going, in coordinating vehicle weights, speed limits, all the things that the heavy transport industry is continually facing when it crosses State boundaries. That was the first issue that had to be dealt with. The Minister went through an extensive and dramatic process of negotiation to reach the point where we formed the Commission, and in this legislation we are extending the brief. The brief contains some highly significant developments because it is now moving gently towards the issue of vehicles under 4.5 tonnes. It is not taking over at this point the regulation and operation of that field, but it is starting to look to the development of national legislation, which will be cooperatively drawn, and at comparative information on the funding of roads and the taxes that are appropriate to it.

That brings us to a matter that I started to touch on before. We have a very interesting paradox at the moment, particularly on the other side of the House and particularly with members of the National Party. Being one of the Victorian country members of the Government, I run across a lot of my National Party colleagues and hear what they have to say. They continually wander around rural Australia calling for more road funds. At the same time, they tell people that in the Fightback package they are going to scrap petrol taxes.

Something is a bit amiss here because nobody ever seems to ask the question, `If we do not have a petrol tax, who will pay for the roads?'. If anyone is asked that question what is quietly said as an afterthought to someone on the side of the hall is, `Oh, well, there will be a road user charge'. When asked, `How much?', the answer is, `We do not know. We will have to wait until we get into government to sort it out'. As the honourable member for Lyne has said tonight, a road user charge will really in effect be a toll on private roads and will replace petrol tax.

I happened to have the pleasure last Wednesday of addressing a local government forum in Melbourne with the Opposition spokesman on local government. I made the point then that, particularly in respect of local government, what is being talked about here is fraudulent. I just do not know any other way to describe it when those opposite are saying to bodies such as councils, `We are going to maintain your road funding but you will benefit from a drop in petrol taxes'. The road user charge will make up for petrol taxes and therefore the claim to the Australian motorist and the Australian transport operator that they are going to get all this relief from fuel tax when, on the other hand, they will have to pay a road user charge, is fraudulent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Double registration; don't forget the double registration.

—Double registration is another issue. If the Commission is to raise its revenue by registration charges and a levy through the bowser—that tends to be the formula agreed on by both sides of the House—one must replace the other. If that is not planned to be the case, where do the councils sit? They can either not maintain their local roads or lift their rates. Either way, a promise of lower petrol costs to the consumer in Australia is just fraudulent; I do not know any other way to describe it.

PARA.TAB: I return to the expanded brief for the Commission. It is also planned to ask the Commission to look at the efficiency of road construction and maintenance. At the moment an inquiry is being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, chaired by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He will be bringing down a report on that fairly soon. He and his Committee are widely respected throughout the road construction industry, and I know that there has been some very interesting input to that inquiry. He will be highlighting a number of areas where efficiencies can be obtained in the standards and materials that we use and the way in which we construct roads.

Quite frankly, I think we spend too much on roads in Australia; we just do not spend it very well. The Minister at the table has been a real pioneer, along with the honourable member for Shortland, the former Minister, in dragging us back to a much more sensible road construction program based around a national highway structure, a State highway structure and a local road structure.

It is very apt that the NRTC is being given a brief to look not only at the management and operation of the heavy vehicles and the light vehicle fleet in Australia and at fair ways of having road users pay their way but also at what it is that they are paying their way for. Of course, that is the road system and the enormous amounts—the billions of dollars of funding per year—that go into constructing and maintaining that system.

It is also very interesting that we are giving the Commission a brief to look at the use of alternative fuels. One emerging alternative fuel in Australia is LPG. I understand that about 10 per cent of vehicles in Melbourne and Sydney now use LPG. It is very interesting that the Opposition plans this 15 per cent consumption tax. All I can say about it is that LPG and GST do not mix. Any number of operators—in particular taxis and those commercial operators who have made very finely tuned commercial decisions to install LPG equipment in their vehicles based on the difference in price between LPG and ordinary petrol—will find under the Opposition's plan that a 15 per cent consumption tax added on to LPG will make it more expensive than it is now because there is basically no excise on LPG at the moment. If at the same time the excise is removed from petrol, that would reduce the price of petrol. So all those people who have made a conscious commercial decision to pay the $1,500 to convert their vehicle to LPG will all of a sudden realise that LPG and GST just do not mix. That is something that needs to be spelt out. Perhaps the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) or the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who are to follow in the debate, will give us some more detail on this aspect.

The examination of alternative fuels is an important task for the NRTC to undertake. If we just take the LPG example in the balance of payments equation, again the policy of those opposite is a paradox of stupidity because we are self-reliant in LPG. We produce our own; we do not import it. We are not self-reliant in petrol; we import petrol. So it is in Australia's interests, in the interests of the balance of payments, that we encourage more motorists to shift to LPG so that we will use fewer imports and more of our own domestic fuel supply.

So, again, an increase in the price of one and a reduction in the price of another is a disincentive to the exact trade equation that we are trying to work out. I do not think that a lot of this has been very well thought out as the whole 600 pages was baked together.

The Commission has a real role. I am not saying that it should look at LPG first up as an issue. It has to look at the range of alternative fuels available to give us efficiency and economy, but also bearing in mind the balance of payments equation.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, ENVIRONMENT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Brereton:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Arts, Environment and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is one of an increasing amount of omnibus legislation that is now being presented, particularly in this portfolio and in the transport and communications portfolio. It would appear that we come back here time and time again to undertake these omnibus activities within this portfolio. I wonder if the Government should consider whether the time has come for a total review of all the legislation falling within this portfolio because, quite obviously, piecemeal legislation such as this does not promote good government. We believe that there should be a consistent approach to administration, and if we are back here every other week of the sitting period making these minor amendments it does not indicate that we have this good administration.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing terribly earth shattering in this Bill tonight. It amends five Acts and repeals two Acts. The two Acts that are to be repealed are the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act 1987 and the States Grants (Air Quality Monitoring) Act 1976. In reality, both of these Acts have served their purpose. Their time has run out and the Government has decided to repeal them. That is one of the easier parts of this legislation.

I will run through the other five Acts individually. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act increases the value of contracts the Director of Parks and Wildlife may enter into. They rise from $100,000 to $250,000, and obviously the Opposition does not have too much trouble with this. It is consistent with the increases that have already been approved by a number of other authorities. There is virtually a one-word amendment to the Australian Heritage Commission Act. It corrects a small drafting error, and we have no problems with that.

The interesting one, however, is the Australia Council Act. The amendments enable the Minister, rather than the Governor-General, to appoint members of that Council. We think this is quite interesting because a number of other bodies which have boards appointed by the Governor-General fall within this portfolio. They include the Australian Film Commission, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian National Maritime Museum, the Museum of Australia, the Australian National Gallery, the Australian National Library, and the Australian Film, Television and Radio School. We really wonder what this is all about.

Admittedly, the chairman would still be appointed by the Governor-General, but the proposed new section in the Bill—31A—allows the Minister to delegate in writing to the Council the power to appoint members, but not the chairman, of the various boards. I suppose an example could be the Aboriginal Arts Board. As I said, the appointments are now made by the Minister in reality, but this amendment gives greater power to the Minister and I think creates the possibility of political pressure on the Council. We do not think the Government should allow appointments of members of the various boards to be made by the Council.

In the case of the Arts Council, we have already been through the situation in Queensland where week after week in the local newspapers there have been accusations of favouritism in the allocation of grants by the Council through its various boards. Mr Sweeney, who is the representative of the Arts Council in Queensland, is quite vocal about this, and I think he has presented some rather good information about how Queensland has missed out in the allocation of some of these funds. As the years go by, so Mr Sweeney's vehemence increases as he makes what I think are very valid points about the imbalance of the activities of the Australia Council in terms of those Queensland grants. I think the only thing this piece of legislation will do is give further weight to those claims. There will be more about this in the other place.

The other matter which I think is quite interesting concerns the amendments to the National Gallery Act. These amendments change the name of the gallery from the Australian National Gallery to the National Gallery of Australia. One really wonders why this is necessary and why so much expense should be gone to to make this possible. The Government says that this change is in line with other institutions, such as the National Library of Australia and the National Museum of Australia. The other thing that is quite interesting is that we have just established the Australian National Maritime Museum, which runs completely counter to this argument. There is no doubt that there is some potential to create confusion with other institutions, such as the National Gallery of Victoria. The old name—the Australian National Gallery—was very much a statement; there was no confusion there. I really wonder what the purpose of this change is because there is no doubt that the gallery is known throughout the world by its present title. There should not be a need for that change.

We are told that the change will not make the gallery more efficient, and I would not think it would have the capacity to attract any more visitors than it does now. My mind boggles at the amount of letterheads, envelopes and every thing else in the administration of the Australian National Gallery that will have to be changed and the unbelievable expense that will be involved with this minor amendment. Obviously, the Opposition is not terribly impressed with that.

The final reference I would like to make tonight is to the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act. The amendment enables the National Capital Planning Authority, with the approval of the Minister, to manage national land which is used, or is to be used, for the special purposes of Canberra as the national capital. This legislation formalises the arrangement which was made on 1 July handing over most of the national land from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories to the NCPA. The Department of Administrative Services retains control over some of the land, but the Minister is granted no new powers under the Act.

This is quite interesting because the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has put forward for consideration by the Joint Committee on the National Capital a proposal to nominate Canberra for World Heritage listing. If the city, or parts of it, are declared national land the position of the ACT Government in deciding whether or not to proceed to Heritage listing may be weakened. While we would not oppose this piece of legislation, I think it is only right that we highlight the concern over the power which is entrusted to the Minister in light of the possible World Heritage listing of Australia's national capital.

With those brief comments, I reiterate what I said at the beginning of my contribution tonight: this is one of a number of omnibus Bills which seem to be coming in week after week from this portfolio area. I repeat the Opposition's request that we should look to a major review of the legislation within that portfolio to see whether we can sort it out once and for all.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating some minor amendments to a Bill that relates to the portfolio of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. A number of those areas relate specifically to the environment, particularly national parks and wildlife conservation and the Australian Heritage Commission. This Bill is a good time to review some of the achievements of the Government in environmental protection because it enables us to range widely within the portfolio.

PARA.TAB: As I look back to 1990, the Government has had a stunning set of achievements with respect to what it has been able to do in the protection of the environment. I will run through some of those achievements. For instance, the Government has nominated Fraser Island, the sub-Antarctic islands, Macquarie Island, and stage three of Kakadu for World Heritage listing. We have established the ecologically sustainable development process. We have set greenhouse gas emission reduction targets. We have established the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. We have moved to introduce endangered species legislation and establish a national biodiversity strategy. We have tackled urban environment issues such as air and water quality, cleaning up beaches and waste minimisation. We have simplified the environmental impact assessment process by minimising duplication between governments.

I have to contrast those sorts of achievements with those of the coalition whose environmental credentials are rather poor. It has opposed the nomination of many World Heritage areas. World Heritage listing is perhaps the most significant manner by which a country can foreshadow to the world that it has areas which must be kept, held and managed properly for all time.

Australia is a world leader in implementing the World Heritage Convention. In fact, we have nine properties on that World Heritage List. They are: Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef, the Willandra Lakes region of western New South Wales, the Lord Howe Island group, the western Tasmanian wilderness national parks, the Australian east coast temperate and subtropical rainforest parks, Uluru National Park—which encompasses Ayers Rock and Mount Olga—the wet tropics of Queensland and Shark Bay in Western Australia.

Our view on these matters is that the Commonwealth needs to accept and has accepted, in our case, the ultimate responsibility for World Heritage. In discharging that responsibility we have sought to ensure, as far as possible, that no-one should be worse off as a result of the protection of the environment. One will have seen, as each issue arose and we listed each area, that we have a good record of providing assistance to communities as part of those decisions. Protecting the jobs in local communities affected by environmental decisions is not only fair but essential.

What bothers the Government is that the coalition in government would allow the State governments to hold the power of veto over World Heritage matters. Australia's international obligations would therefore be abrogated whenever a State government opposed the protection of a place that is of international heritage significance. That would inevitably lead to international embarrassment for Australia and the destruction of environmental assets.

If we look at issues such as the management of Kakadu and Uluru, we will find that this Government has been committed to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service managing the Kakadu and Uluru World Heritage areas. These areas are acknowledged by international conservation bodies, such as the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, to be currently managed at the highest standards with the full support and encouragement of the local Aboriginal people. By contrast, the coalition, we know, is committed to handing over Kakadu and Uluru national parks to the Northern Territory Government to circumvent legislation which does not allow activity that would damage the ecology of these areas.

Let us take one area off the coast of Queensland. We have agreed with the recommendations of the Tony Fitzgerald inquiry into Fraser Island and have nominated the island for World Heritage listing this year. We and the Queensland Government have put together a $16 1/2m adjustment package to make sure that those local communities on Fraser Island and on the mainland can develop new job creating industries in the area. The same week as we were celebrating the news that the World Heritage Bureau had recommended Fraser Island for World Heritage listing, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said that a coalition government would consider allowing sand mining to resume on Fraser Island. Not even Malcolm Fraser, as a former coalition Prime Minister, would allow that. An Opposition spokesman—a National Party member, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott)—said at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: Fraser Island and Kakadu are good examples of how mining can be carried out without harm to the environment.

Fortunately, Dr Hewson has now backed down on this issue. But it does show a lack of knowledge and commitment of the coalition to environmental issues. In south-western Tasmania the Government has protected the Franklin River and over 100,000 hectares of Tasmania's eucalypt forests. By contrast, the coalition opposed in 1983 the protection of the Franklin River and eucalypt forests and would allow mineral exploration and mining in the forests of south-western Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: The broad question of the balance between environment and development is always a difficult one to answer. We have worked hard and are determined to achieve what we call ecologically sustainable development to ensure that the environment and development are balanced. We recognise that Australia needs development, but we also need to take care of our natural environment to ensure sustainable growth for the future. As part of that process, we have established the ecologically sustainable development process to integrate environmental concerns with environmental growth. We also have in place a comprehensive set of procedures which ensure that when a proposed resource development program is examined it is done so expeditiously and with the correct integration of economic, environmental, Aboriginal, social and other issues.

The coalition perpetuates the myth of black and green tape, as the Leader of the Opposition calls it. It does that because it does not understand the requirements of the integration of environment and development. The Leader of the Opposition plans to fix a time limit on development approvals for major projects. In an address to the Liberal Party convention on 5 July this year he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government hasn't got its act together and hasn't gone through the environmental and Aboriginal heritage impact studies and so on, well, the project can go ahead anyway. It's the only way.

In other words, he would set up a process which he would abandon despite the fact that all of the correct and necessary information would not have been made available by the various players. It is part of the myth that is peddled by the coalition that the Government has held up many projects, such as the Marandoo iron ore project in Western Australia. Since the Commonwealth lifted export controls on iron ore, as it announced in the One Nation statement, the Commonwealth has no formal involvement in this process whatsoever. The question of forests has provided a fair amount of conflict in the environmental arena. We need to keep in mind that since European settlement Australia has lost nearly half of its forests and about three-quarters of its rainforests. We have done a great deal about that while we have been in government.

PARA.TAB: Nearly one million hectares of tropical rainforests were protected through the Queensland wet tropics World Heritage listing. As I mentioned, in Tasmania over 100,000 hectares of tall eucalypt forests are now secure in a World Heritage area. Both of those listings were vehemently opposed by coalition governments.

Some exciting news in Western Australia is that a substantial area of forest will now be conserved under the Australian Heritage Commission and the Department of Conservation and Land Management agreement. The recently released draft national forest policy statement includes a Government commitment to protect the best of our old growth and wilderness forests by 1995. Further, on the question of forest conservation and the development process, or what became known as resource security, I can inform the House that the Government is committed to ensuring adequate conservation and protection of our native forests while concurrently encouraging a thriving forest products industry and providing more and better jobs for Australians associated with that industry.

We believe that our Forest Conservation and Development Bill would have achieved this objective and facilitated substantial investment in plantations in Australia. Unfortunately, that legislation was defeated by the coalition in the Senate and with it the prospect of balance and the thousands of jobs and significant plantations that it would have brought to the industry. The coalition recently introduced its own resource security Bill into the Parliament. Unlike the Government's Bill, the Opposition is prepared to allow industry to have almost unfettered access to Australia's native forests without the commitment to jobs, to investment and, importantly, to the appropriate safeguards to cater for rare or threatened species.

Another area of concern to us was that community groups were sufficiently well endowed to enable us to have a proper degree of debate and consultation about conservation. People need to realise that it takes time, resources and dedication for community groups to organise responses to various development proposals. While community groups have the dedication to do that, it has been our view that policy should provide resources and time. Under the grants to voluntary conservation organisations scheme, the Federal Government has provided just over $1m for administrative funding to conservation groups.

Given the limited financial resources of most of those organisations, that funding has been very important to make sure that the Commonwealth could rely on the information or the views that were fed to it by conservation groups. That addresses the relative power of communities against development interests so that we could strike the right balance between those various interests. Under the coalition's proposals in Fightback, those grants would cease. That would include all voluntary conservation organisations. It is already the coalition policy, as has been stated, to withdraw funding from the Australian Conservation Foundation under the GVCO scheme I mentioned before.

It is essential that proper time for debate and discussion and assembling arguments be made available. Fightback proposes to impose a 12-month decision making time frame for project approvals, which will make it pretty hard for community groups to respond properly and intelligently to development proposals. One of our more recent schemes is the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. Our decision to create the Commonwealth EPA reflects our need to concentrate on and protect the urban environment, which

SPEECH.PARA: means our air, water, land and ocean systems. Alternatively, Fightback demonstrates that the Opposition understands neither the structure of the Commonwealth EPA nor the significance of the work it undertakes.

PARA.TAB: The coalition proposes to halve the budget of this brand new Environment Protection Agency, which means that the Commonwealth would no longer be able to maintain a meaningful role in environment protection and the States would once again assume the major responsibility. It seems to me that without the Commonwealth taking a leading role, there would be no national environmental quality standards and the reforms aimed at developing a uniform national system of environmental assessment would surely falter.

The Australian Heritage Commission was established in Whitlam's time, in 1975. The Commission is now working closely with State governments to undertake what we call regional assessments of National Estate values. I used the example before of the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management, in which regional assessments had been used to overcome land use conflicts. The coalition wants to wield the knife here and has stated that it will place an immediate freeze on the entry of places with National Estate values onto the register until there has been a complete review and a culling of some of the places on the register. To me that shows a lack of understanding of the Australian Heritage Commission and the role of the National Estate in protecting Australia's heritage. The coalition has vowed to cut $1m from the Australian Heritage Commission budget, which would make it very difficult—probably in the end impossible—to continue this work on regional assessment.

The Opposition's desire to introduce a goods and services tax will also impact on the environment. As the world works towards lowering its dependence on fossil fuels to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, the Opposition plans to move in exactly the opposite direction. A leading Australian conservation organisation has estimated that the coalition's policy would increase petrol consumption by between 13 and 24 per cent, thereby increasing air pollution and total greenhouse gas emissions by between 2 and 4 per cent, not to mention the effect of increased oil imports on Australia's trade balance. Alternative fuels are a worry. LPG and natural gas have a much lower carbon content than petrol and oil.

I turn to the Opposition's policy regarding the Bureau of Meteorology. What is essential is that we have good information so that we can make judgments about the management of the portfolio, but particularly the environment. The Opposition has vowed to cut $10m from the Bureau of Meteorology. The savings would be made in the administration of the Bureau of Meteorology, making up moneys by charging the public for meteorological information on a fee for service basis, which means that access to weather information would become somewhat more scarce and expensive.

To achieve those savings, we understand from the Bureau that we would have to consider closing the following: Willis Island, which provides for cyclone early warning; provincial weather services across Australia in places such as Alice Springs, Port Hedland, Rockhampton, Launceston and Cairns; upper air stations at Giles and Longreach; and the national cooperative observer network. The potential dangers in the Leader of the Opposition's cost slashing exercise include a reduction in the quality of forecasts, which would jeopardise cyclone and other weather warnings. The implications for industries including farming, tourism, fishing, and air and sea services are serious. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for allowing me some breadth in the discussion of these matters under the portfolio Bill.

The Pork Council goes on to say this, which is important:
However, offsetting these gains are three other factors:
1. Pig producers will pay GST, at an estimated average rate of 4.8%, on their personal expenditure. This may not be fully offset by income tax cuts.
2. More importantly, from a total industry perspective, relative pig prices are likely to fall. This is because pigmeat, being relatively free of taxes at present—
I emphasise that—

will probably rise by more than some other expenditure items at the point of retail sale when GST is introduced. Because pigmeat supply is inelastic, the price back to producers will fall as a result. It is impossible at this stage to predict what the effect on prices will be.
3. There will also be increased costs, either as accountancy services or in the producer's own time, to meet the documentation requirements for the new tax.

I think that sums up very clearly that the tax will have a massive effect on the pig industry. It is important to note that the pig meat industry at the present time—I hope in the future it becomes an export orientated industry—is basically a domestic industry. As such, all pig meat will be taxed at 15 per cent. That means that if a family is going to spend $100 on pig meat over a month or two weeks or whatever, 85 per cent of that will go in buying the product and the other 15 per cent will be in tax.

PARA.TAB: The other important aspect that is often forgotten in regard to Fightback is the effect of industrial relations. The Opposition has indicated that it will destroy the award system we have, and workers' wages will go down. Working families will therefore have less money to spend on food and clothes, which will be taxed at 15 per cent. That means a massive reduction in the purchasing power and capacity of working families to buy the essential foods and ingredients of life. That will impact directly on the pig meat industry.

To take this even further, the ACIL report indicated how farmers would be better off. I have said this many times in the House before and I will continue to say it. An analysis of four farm incomes ranging from $55,000 to $71,000 net free of debt indicated that, as a consequence, farmers would be better off. But the fact is that the majority of farmers do not earn that sort of money. In fact, yesterday the Sunday Mail said that farmers were on the brink of ruin in Queensland and that more than 7,000 of Queensland's 25,000 farmers are in danger of going broke. If that is the case—and I believe it is, because of drought and commodity price drops—it is a joke to assume that the ACIL report and the NFF analysis are correct. It is a total mockery when we have the hillbillies of the National Party, and in particular the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), talking about a crisis, then wanting to put a tax of 15 per cent on the farmers they say are going broke, but adopting the ACIL report, which talks about net incomes of between $55,000 and $71,000 net free of debt as the basis for the analysis that Fightback will be beneficial to farmers. The fact is that it will not be. The pig industry knows it, and the Pork Council of Australia has said so in its publication. (Time expired)
