TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to record my congratulations to the Victorian Parliamentary Liberal Party on its outstanding victory at the recent State election. Mr Jeff Kennett and his team staged a magnificent victory in Victoria, and Victoria has been restored to its rightful place as the jewel in the crown of the Liberal Party. Honourable members will be aware that the coalition gained a 6 per cent swing throughout Victoria, resulting in a majority of up to 38 seats. It will be the largest government majority since 1907. The Victorian Labor Party has been decimated and is now paying a heavy price for the years of economic and social mismanagement by the Cain and Kirner governments.

PARA.TAB: The election results have significantly changed the political map of Victoria. The Labor Party has been soundly rejected by the voters in areas where it has held sway since the late 1970s. Labor's incompetence has seen its hold over seats now restricted to the Labor heartland of Melbourne's inner western and northern suburbs and a handful elsewhere, while rural Victoria and outer northern, eastern and southern Melbourne electorates deserted the Labor Party in droves.

In the area covered by the Federal seat of Isaacs, the Liberal Party recorded some magnificent victories. The Transport Minister, Peter Spyker, was trounced by Geoff Leigh in the seat of Mordialloc, recording a 9.4 per cent swing; Inga Peulich gained a 9.9 per cent swing in Bentleigh to remove Labor's Ann Barker; and, in Chelsea province, Sue Wilding defeated the Health Minister, Maureen Lyster. In the seat of Sandringham, Murray Thompson recorded an outstanding swing of 15.2 per cent to retain the seat for the Liberal party, and Chris Strong had an excellent win in Higinbotham province. The seat of Carrum remains in doubt, and it can only be hoped that John Robinson is justly rewarded for conducting a fine campaign by defeating the former Police and Emergency Services Minister, Mal Sandon.
In reviewing the election results within the Federal electorate of Isaacs, I note that defeated Transport Minister and Labor candidate for Mordialloc, Peter Spyker, is on the record as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: My next job locally is now to make sure that we win the seat of Isaacs back in the next Federal election.

The voters in the electorate of Mordialloc passed judgment on Peter Spyker's performance, and Victorians passed judgment on the Cain and Kirner governments, in which Peter Spyker served as a senior Minister. On that basis, I would be delighted if Peter Spyker involved himself in the next Federal election campaign in the electorate of Isaacs.

PARA.TAB: I also wish to take the opportunity to record my congratulations to the State Director of the Liberal Party, Mr Petro Georgiou, for masterminding a brilliant election campaign. The Victorian Liberal Party is very fortunate to have someone of his calibre as the State Director. The successes of Petro Georgiou last week rival the outstanding performance of the Victorian division at the 1990 Federal election. The recently retired State President of the Victorian division, Michael Kroger, must also receive a great deal of praise for the victory.

There is no comfort whatsoever in the Victorian result for the Keating Government. Victorians and all Australians expect and demand good government. Victorians have passed judgment on the failed Cain and Kirner governments, and the same fate awaits the Keating Government some time in the next six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is always amusing to listen to this intellectual shadow of the former member for Maranoa, Mr Ian Cameron, speaking in this House.
—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie might get my title right.
—Sorry, Mr Speaker; you are right. Your absence has confused me.
—Otherwise his chances of getting the call again will become severely limited.
—Mr Speaker, if you do not stop interrupting me, I will not get the speech finished.
—That also crossed my mind.

—In the grievance debate I was talking about the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). I got to his second point before I was rudely interrupted by the efflux of time. His second principle was that of multicultural harmony, whereby we would receive people from other countries in proportion to the numbers of people from those countries already in Australia. He went on to say that this would benefit such people as the Italians and the Dutch. Of course, he did not mention the Greeks, but the clear purpose of this concept is to give weight and preference to the people of his own ethnic background, in spite of the fact that they do not want to come here anyway. In other words, he is displaying a clear racial preference in immigration. It may be one based on delusion, but it is still a clear preference. Why is he not attacked by the media? It is because he is just acting, as all the professional ethnics do. They have the licence to do so. They want more people like themselves. That is the bottom line. They support multiculturalism because it furthers their objectives and gives them more power.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Calwell attacked me for saying that the White Australia policy was the correct policy to adopt at Federation and that only after the end of World War II was it sensible to review it; yet his proposed policy is based on quotas as the population stood while the White Australia policy was still well and truly in operation. He says that the quota system is how things work in the US. In fact, while the US still has a quota system of a sort, his proposal harks back to the earlier US system which was scrapped in 1965 because it was considered racist.

Let us consider it. Between 1917 and 1925 the US passed a series of restrictive immigration Bills based on the concept of national origins; that is, the intake was designed, in its national composition, to mirror the ethnic composition of the US at certain dates—a major plank of the proposal of the honourable member for Calwell. This looked and sounded much better than the White Australia policy, but in practice it was much more restrictive.

The great irony is that this system, which the honourable member for Calwell now embraces, was specifically designed to exclude southern Europeans from the United States. Also ironically, a number of southern Europeans, who had wanted to go to the United States and found themselves blocked, were unable to migrate and came to Australia instead. The honourable member for Calwell now turns this system on its head and uses it to favour southern Europeans. This is an absolute joke.

Why not make the quotas relate to the population as it stood at Federation in 1901? This is an equally sensible date. We had the White Australia policy then as well. Clearly, that would not meet the objective of the honourable member for Calwell. We know what that objective is; I have made that quite clear. It has been the opportunists and frauds who have manipulated and distorted our immigration program in recent times, with the assistance of cowardly politicians and members of the trendy new class more concerned with their own status and power than their much vaunted equity.

My position is this: mass immigration is a concept whose time has passed. The great majority of Australians, migrants and non-migrants, do not benefit from it or support it. Immigration should be cut to 50,000 and held at or below that figure for a long term. We must scrap the policy of multiculturalism, which is a corrupt game of patronage that is costing the Australian public dearly both financially and socially.

While I have strongly attacked those professional ethnics, I do not believe that they represent the people whom they claim to represent. I believe that the vast majority of migrants, of whatever background, support me in wanting what is best for this country and our children. Southern Europeans have made a proud contribution to this country, and I ask them and all other migrants to disown and reject those professional ethnics who falsely claim to represent them. We are all Australians and we cannot create a better world for our children if our country is divided, as the experience in Europe so clearly shows.

I cannot conclude, however, without making a few remarks towards the god-daddy of them all, the original professional ethnic—the honoured Al Grassby, society's friend. I see that the taxpayers of Australia, through the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, have been ordered to pay him $180,000 towards his court costs for his conspiracy to pervert the course of justice charge, which has just been dismissed. I note that he intends to return to the immigration field, in his, to use his words, `proper capacity as a consultant in relation to immigration and related matters, which is my field of expertise'. All I have to say about him is that one day his true record as Immigration Minister will be exposed to the full light of day. It may be long after we have all passed away, but it will eventually happen because, as Mr Grassby knows, no-one can defame the dead. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Back in May 1988 the tax file numbering system was introduced into Australia. I want to remind the House that the then Treasurer said at that time that `the tax file number will not establish a citizen identification system'. In August 1990 there was an extension of the use of the tax file number. It now applies to every person who is a client of any major agency and it is, therefore, a general purpose citizen identification system. He also said that the tax file numbering system will be administered exclusively by the Taxation Office for tax purposes. In August 1990 it was extended to apply to many other purposes.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Australian Taxation Office is now proposing to extend the tax file numbering system to students in year 10. At the moment, a pilot study is being undertaken in Tasmania to encourage students in year 10 to apply for a tax file number—not students who have employment and are earning a wage. The basis for doing this is that it is believed that it will improve the integrity of the taxation file numbering system.

When we really think about it, if it is going to be voluntary, we will find that only 4 or 5 per cent, maybe 10 per cent, of Australians will apply. Hopefully none of them will take up this option. I believe that it is only a blind by the Australian Taxation Office to extend the identification system far beyond what was intended. The Australian people back in 1987-88 had a vigorous debate as to whether we should have an Australia card, and clearly rejected that option. Here we find a very powerful government agency trying to use the educational system in Australia to get young people to voluntarily become part of the tax file numbering system.

I believe that questions need to be asked as to what the purpose for this really is. Has this been authorised by the Government, or is it just the arrogance of one of our departments going ahead and extending an identification system far beyond what many Australians would regard as acceptable? I think that this just further illustrates the fact that the Australia card concept is now becoming a reality in Australia by default. I believe that, as Australians, we should be questioning the Australian Taxation Office as to whether this is fit and proper. I believe that, in this day and age, teachers are under considerable pressure to carry out the basics of education and teaching, let alone to become a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office. Therefore, I say to the teachers out there that they ought not to have anything to do with this, that they ought to reject the concept of trialing such a system in Tasmania. Hopefully it will not see the light of day anywhere else in Australia.

The Taxation Office is wanting to encourage schools by paying them $5 for every child who is prepared to apply for a tax file numbering system. Clearly this is purely a bribe to get schools involved to become a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office. I think that we ought to be aware of these types of matters which the Office is trying to extend to young Australians aged 15 and 16. It is not what I believe we ought to be doing in this country. I hope that this extension of the long arm of the Taxation Office can be cut off and the Big Brother state can be prevented in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I moved a private member's business motion that this House support a positive investment climate for the South Australian automotive industry. I pointed out that the Opposition's zero tariff proposal for the year 2000 would devastate that industry by allowing cheap imports. Yesterday the Adelaide Sunday Mail carried an article by the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), who sought to repudiate this position. There are a number of differences between us. First, there is no motor car industry in the world that does not receive government assistance. Japan's industry receives the least, but while it was being built it was most heavily protected. Similarly, Australia's industry only came into existence due to a protected domestic market. Removing that protection involves dangers. The honourable member for Barker accepts that if it were wrong it would be a tragedy—one, I might add, that could never be undone.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, last week's report by the Centre for Policy Studies at Monash University on the Impact of Tariff Cuts must be treated with some caution. It was commissioned by the industry lobby for a known anti-tariff sector—the Australian Mining Industry Council. It makes some heroic conclusions about the car industry's growth prospects without protection, although it acknowledges that employment might shrink. But it makes no mention of South Australia's automobile industry. I repeat: it has nothing direct to say about the size, output or employment level of that industry in South Australia. It is a projection based on an economic model with no announced geographic dimension. In contrast, government policy of maintaining some tariff protection is based on careful consideration of such economic modelling by the Industry Commission and also extensive empirical investigation of the industry itself and its offshore counterparts and competitors.

The policy of going to 15 per cent nominal and 35 per cent effective real tariff protection by the year 2000 was advocated neither by theory nor by the industry, but by policy objectives. We seek to produce, and are already producing, cheaper, better cars, some of which are exported, and to maintain an Australian car industry much of which is in South Australia.

Thirdly, not all members of the Opposition support the zero tariff option. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) has circulated in his electorate a copy of his speech on the car industry in this House on 10 September. This carefully crafted document argues that the South Australian car industry is non-negotiable. He cautions against accepting economic forecasts for more than 12 months into the future and says he will not stand on the tarmac and wave goodbye to that industry. He, like the State Leader of the Liberal Party, Dean Brown, is not happy with the zero tariff policy. Nor am I. No Opposition politician standing for an Adelaide seat at the next election spoke in that private member's debate. The anger in Adelaide against zero tariffs is sufficient for them to want to maintain a distance.

It has always been possible to get support for zero tariffs from some Australians, notably those in regions or sectors of the economy which do not seem to benefit directly from Government industry protection and promotion policies. But if Australia wants to become a modern economy, with a range of production and technology and a diverse body of exports including elaborately transformed manufactures, it can no more rely wholly on the free market than its equivalents in Europe, North America and Japan. Australia needs an active industry policy from Government, and South Australia's car industry will be wiped out without one.

I repeat the point that I made last week. It is a point that has often been stated by the South Australian car industry, and I am pleased to note it was repeated again today by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at Question Time, but it is a point that is ignored by the Monash study and the Opposition front bench. It is this: if the marginal unit cost of production in a 400,000 run in Japan, plus the $500 unit transport cost to Australia, is less than the marginal unit cost of production on an Australian production run, why, given zero tariffs, would a multinational car firm produce any in South Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short time available to me tonight I would like to address the question of friendly society bonds and the pension income test and bonuses. I quote from a letter from the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca):

SPEECH.PARA: There have been various changes to the treatment of Friendly Society Bonds over time, but basically bonuses on Friendly Society Bonds in respect of the period before 1 November 1983 are not taken into account under the income test.

Bonuses on investments in Friendly Society Bonds purchased before 1 January 1988 are counted as income following maturity or early surrender of the bonds. Bonuses accruing to Friendly Society Bonds purchased after 1 January 1988 are assessed as income for social security purposes on an ongoing basis.
The problem for one of my constituents is that he purchased bonds in 1982. I will quickly read from a letter from my constituent:
I feel very distressed and angry about the governments turnaround in this matter.

PARA.TAB: When we put the money in ARPA in 1982 it was to be towards our retirement home as—

SPEECH.PARA: this lady's husband—
was due to retire in September 1992.

PARA.TAB: Due to ill-health, he was obliged to retire in September 1986, but now he is suffering from—

SPEECH.PARA: a certain disease. It is their desire to get home to their family in New South Wales. They have been counting on this money to help bridge the gap between property values in Ballarat and those in New South Wales, a reasonable distance from Sydney. They have now been told that the bonuses will be regarded as income, except for the original $2,000, and the Department of Social Security will deduct $40 per week from their joint pension until half of what was earned has been taken from them.

PARA.TAB: I would ask that the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) look at this question. It appears to me that the large number of people who took out friendly society bonds in 1982 are being wrongly treated. It seems to me that they were taken out in good faith on the basis that any bonuses would not affect their pension income. There have been a large number of changes. I believe they are being prejudiced, and it is a matter which should be addressed.

A large number of these people were getting towards retirement. Those investments were made in friendly society bonds on the basis that they would not affect their pension income. Most of these people are now at retirement age, and it is far too late for them to alter their investment process. It is a matter that I believe is affecting a large number of Australians, and a matter that should be addressed as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Minister state in answer to question No. 521 (Hansard, 13 March 1991, page 1959) that Australia's Seventh Periodic Report to the Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (CERD) would refer to the Swan Brewery site case in which the High Court gave judgment on 20 June 1990; if so, in what terms did the report refer to the case.

(2) Further to the answers to question Nos 996 (Hansard, 8 October 1991, page 1492), 1324 (Hansard, 30 March 1992, page 1438) and 1550 (Hansard, 24 June 1992, page 3876), will Australia's Eighth Periodic Report to CERD, due in October 1992, refer to the (a) legislative, (b) judicial, (c) administrative or (d) other sequels to the judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Paragraph 112 of Australia's Eighth report (UN Document CERD/C/194/Add.2 of 19 June 1991), representing a consolidation of Australia's Seventh and Eighth periodic reports in one document, states:

"In a recent court case (1990), the High Court held that the Crown in right of the State of Western Australia is bound by the Aboriginal Heritage Act 1972 (WA), and is therefore prohibited from destroying or damaging Aboriginal sacred sites or objects on those sites other than in limited circumstances. As 93% of the land area of Western Australia is Crown land, this will provide significant protection for Aboriginal heritage in that State."

(2) I have been advised that Australia's Ninth Periodic Report to CERD, detailing significant developments between January 1991 and June 1992 of relevance to Australia's obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, will refer to certain legislative sequels to the 1990 High Court decision in Bropho v. State of Western Australia. I undertake to advise the honourable member of the relevant reference upon the report's completion.
